meanings.definition: strange or silly:
examples: The idea is exciting for those who believe in it, wackadoodle for those who don't.

meanings.definition: a person whose behaviour is strange and different from that of most people, or who does, says, or believes things that are not based on reason:
examples: He may be a wackadoodle, but he's not guilty of any crime.

meanings.definition: in a pleasing and exciting or silly and unusual way:
examples: Her next film was a wackily surreal fairytale based on a graphic novel.
The miniature golf course is laid out with some wackily designed obstacles that make for a fun challenge.
The group's whackily celebratory vibe was perfect for the occasion.

meanings.definition: the quality of being unusual in a pleasing and exciting or silly way:
examples: The band's wackiness delighted the crowd.
The song is way too full of its own wackiness and is quite intensely annoying.

meanings.definition: a number of usually flat and/or small objects pressed tightly together:
examples: a wad of banknotes

meanings.definition: to fold or press together something to form a mass:
examples: He wadded his towel into a ball.

meanings.definition: any soft material used for filling a space, especially in order to protect something or to give something shape:

meanings.definition: (usually of a person or animal with short legs and a fat body) to walk with short steps, moving the body from one side to the other:
examples: The ducks waddled down to the river.
A short, fat waiter waddled over.

meanings.definition: (usually of a person or animal with short legs and a fat body) a way of walking with short steps, moving the body from one side to the other:
examples: With a quack and a waddle, the duck continued on its way.
Towards the end of her pregnancy, she developed a waddle.

meanings.definition: a heavy stick
to walk through water or other liquid with some effort, because it is deep enough to come quite high up your legs, or thick :
examples: The river was full but we managed to wade across.
We waded a shallow river.
They had to wade through a swamp.

meanings.definition: to walk in water that is not very deep:
examples: We rolled up our trousers and waded at the edge of the lake.

meanings.definition: to walk into or through an area of water that is not very deep:
examples: We waded across the stream.
They come to the creek and waded in to drink.

meanings.definition: to start to do or say something in a forceful way, often without thinking about it carefully:
examples: Even when she knows nothing about it, she wades in with her opinion.
When the crowd started throwing bottles, the police waded in with tear gas.

meanings.definition: to start to do something in a forceful and determined way:
examples: If there’s a problem, she’ll wade in without hesitation and try to solve it.

meanings.definition: to become involved in a difficult situation, often without thinking about it carefully
to spend a lot of time and effort doing something boring or difficult, especially reading a lot of information:
examples: We had to wade through pages of legal jargon before we could sign the contract.

meanings.definition: to spend a lot of time and effort doing something boring or difficult:
examples: Some readers will not want to wade through the details of how the data were gathered and analyzed.

meanings.definition: (especially of a tail or finger) to move from side to side or up and down, especially quickly and repeatedly, or to cause this to happen:
examples: The little dog's tail wagged in delight.
He wagged his finger sternly at the two boys.

meanings.definition: to be absent from school without permission:
examples: There were days I would wag school and go for a ride on my bike.
I used to wag it a lot. I didn't like school.

meanings.definition: (especially of a tail or finger) a movement from side to side or up and down:
examples: With a single wag of her finger she managed to convey her total disapproval.

meanings.definition: a humorous person who likes to make jokes

(esp. of a tail or finger) to move from side to side or up and down, usually quickly and repeatedly, or to cause this to happen:
examples: When she came in, the dog sprang to its feet and wagged its tail.

meanings.definition: a particular amount of money that is paid, usually every week, to an employee, especially one who does work that needs physical skills or strength, rather than a job needing a college education:
examples: a very low/high wage
an hourly/daily/weekly/annual wage
He gets/earns/is paid a good wage, because he works for a fair employer.
The job pays very low wages.

meanings.definition: to fight a war or organize a series of activities in order to achieve something:
examples: Doesn't the president need Congress' permission to wage war on another country?
They've been waging a long campaign to change the law.

meanings.definition: an amount of money that is paid to an employee, esp. for each hour worked:
examples: an hourly wage

meanings.definition: to begin and continue a war, a fight, or a plan to achieve something:
examples: A desperate medical battle is being waged against the virus.

meanings.definition: an amount of money that is paid, usually every week, to an employee for their work:
examples: This deal represents an hourly wage rate of $9.83.
We pay the highest wages of any theatrical employer in the world.
Some college education is required to earn a decent wage in the United States.
The employees accepted a 4% wage rise.
If you are a good employer, you will pay a fair wage.

the total amount that an organization pays its employees during a particular period:
examples: The organization has 130 staff and a wage bill of $4.3m.

meanings.definition: a difference in pay between different groups of people or for different jobs:
examples: As graduates and non-graduates get older, the wage differential widens.
The pay differential between employees and management is too great.
The report says that female faculty members still earn less, but that various factors lie behind the salary differential.

meanings.definition:

meanings.definition: a situation in which the average level of pay increases faster than official rates of pay.

a person who works at a job for money, esp. to support a family
a person who earns money by working:

→

examples: The national unemployment rate is so low that wage inflation is bound to follow.

meanings.definition: the amount of money that a particular type of worker or group of people usually earns:
examples: The market dictates what wage levels for various occupations should be.
The state of New Mexico is raising its minimum wage level to $7.50.

meanings.definition: the money that you earn, especially when it is given to you in notes and coins in an envelope:

meanings.definition: in the US, the laws that deal with working conditions, hours, etc.:
examples: The firm violated the state's wage and hour laws when it failed to provide breaks for its workers.

meanings.definition: a rise in prices that causes a rise in the amount that workers earn, which increases the cost of producing goods, making prices rise again:
examples: A sharp fall in the value of sterling could ignite a wage-price spiral.

meanings.definition: a rise in prices caused by a rise in the amount that workers earn, which increases the cost of producing goods:
examples: The economy can continue at its current pace indefinitely without wage-push inflation.

meanings.definition: paid regularly for work:

meanings.definition: used to describe work that a person is paid to do:

meanings.definition: an amount of money that you risk in the hope of winning more, by trying to guess something uncertain, or the agreement that you make to take this risk:
examples: She put a cash wager of £50 on the race.
He tried to eat 50 hard-boiled eggs, for a wager.

meanings.definition: to risk money by guessing the result of something:
examples: More than $2 billion was wagered legally on sports in Nevada in the last 12 months.
He is so confident of victory he has wagered on himself.
I'll wager you £5 that they'll get there first.

meanings.definition: used to say that you are certain that something is true or will happen in the future:
examples: I'd wager (that) she's interested in you.

meanings.definition: To wager is also to suggest as a likely idea:
examples: I would wager that not one person in ten could tell an expensive wine from a cheaper one.

meanings.definition: (of a person) funny in a clever way :

meanings.definition: using or expressing humour in a clever way:

meanings.definition: in a way that is funny and usually very clever:
examples: The DVD includes a special feature in which the two lead actors comment waggishly on the action in the film.

meanings.definition: to (cause to) move quickly up and down or from side to side:

meanings.definition: the movement of a golf club (= specially shaped stick for hitting the ball) backwards and forwards over the ball before moving it right back to hit the ball:
examples: He teed up the ball, took a couple of waggles, and then swung.

meanings.definition: an area of flat, rectangular pieces of wood or another material attached to the lower parts of the walls in a room:

meanings.definition: (of the lower part of a wall in a room) covered in an area of flat, rectangular pieces of wood or another material:

meanings.definition: the part of the body above and slightly narrower than the hips:

meanings.definition: the part of a piece of clothing that goes around or covers the area between the hips and the ribs:
examples: The skirt had an elasticated waist.

meanings.definition: the part of the body above and slightly narrower than the hips:
examples: These jeans are too tight around my waist.

a

If a substance is waist-deep or if you are waist-deep in it, it reaches up to your waist:
examples: It had snowed heavily overnight and the drifts were waist-deep outside the house.
The group was trapped in a cave underground, waist-deep in water.

meanings.definition: a strip of material that forms the waist of a pair of trousers or a skirt:
examples: He had a gun tucked into the waistband of his trousers.

meanings.definition: a piece of clothing that covers the upper body but not the arms and usually has buttons down the front, worn over a shirt
having a particular type of waist:

meanings.definition: narrower at the waist or in the middle:
examples: The coats were old-fashioned in cut, waisted and full skirted.

meanings.definition: used with adjectives to describe the type of waist that a person or piece of clothing has:
examples: a slim-waisted boy
a high-waisted pair of trousers

meanings.definition: an imaginary line going round the narrowest part of your waist:
examples: a bulging/expanding waistline

meanings.definition: the part of a piece of clothing that covers the waist
the measured size of your waist:
examples: When he went off his diet, his waistline started to grow.

meanings.definition: to allow time to go by, especially while staying in one place without doing very much, until someone comes, until something that you are expecting happens or until you can do something:
examples: I waited for her outside while she went in to see the doctor.
The dentist kept me waiting for ages.
There were a lot of people waiting to use the phone.

meanings.definition: to be done or to happen at a later time:
examples: The meeting will have to wait until tomorrow, because I'm too busy now.
The paperwork can't wait until tomorrow (= is urgent and must be done now).

meanings.definition: a period of time when you stay in one place until someone comes, or something happens, or until you can do something:
examples: We had a three-hour wait before we could see the doctor.
The long wait for the doctor/to see the doctor really made me anxious.

meanings.definition: to allow time to go by, esp. without doing much, until something happens or can happen:
examples: I waited in the car.
Wait here for me – I’ll be back in a minute.
The dentist kept me waiting for ages.
Several people are waiting to use the phone.
Please get in line and wait your turn like everyone else.

meanings.definition: If something waits, it is being delayed or is ready:
examples: The meeting will have to wait until tomorrow.
An envelope was waiting for me when I got home.

meanings.definition: to serve meals to people in a restaurant, as your job
to serve meals to people in a restaurant:
examples: She waited tables to pay for college.

meanings.definition: used for getting someone's attention, or when you suddenly think of something important:
examples: Wait a minute – I know what we can do.

meanings.definition: said in order to interrupt someone or to get their attention, or when you have suddenly thought of something important:
examples: Now, wait a moment - I don't agree with that.
Wait a minute - I've just had an idea.

meanings.definition: a wait-and-see situation is one in which someone is not sure what to do and decides to wait before taking any action:
examples: Many investors are taking a wait-and-see approach while there is still uncertainty in the currency markets.

meanings.definition: to stay in a place and do nothing while you wait for someone to arrive or something to happen:
examples: We spent the whole day waiting around for something exciting to happen, but nothing did.

meanings.definition: to serve meals to people in a restaurant, as your job
to stay in a place after all the other people have left:
examples: The teacher made us wait behind after class.

meanings.definition: used to show that you are about to say something surprising, funny, or difficult to believe: used to tell someone not to not start until the correct moment:
examples: Depending on who you believe, the problem is either too much political interference or - wait for it - not enough.
Wait for it! I haven't said "go" yet.

meanings.definition: to be expecting someone or something and be prepared to deal with him, her, or it:
examples: When the thieves left the building, the police were waiting for them.

meanings.definition: If something is waiting for you, it has been left or prepared for you to collect, use, enjoy, or deal with when you arrive:
examples: An envelope was waiting for me when I got home.
Uma had a cup of coffee waiting for me, along with a plate of biscuits.

meanings.definition: to delay serving a meal until someone arrives:
examples: Don't wait dinner for me - I'll be home late.

meanings.definition: to stay at home because you are expecting someone or something to arrive, or someone to phone you:
examples: I waited in for the plumber all morning, but he didn't turn up.

meanings.definition: If someone or something is waiting in the wings, they are not yet active or important, but are ready or likely to be so soon:
examples: The team has several talented young players waiting in the wings.

meanings.definition: a list of people who have asked for something, especially a place at a college or in a class, or a ticket for something, that is not immediately available but may be in the future:
examples: In the Washington area 1,520 people are on the wait list for a new kidney.
Officials said the wait list for the program is currently at 20 families.

meanings.definition: to put someone on a (= a list of people who have asked for something, especially a place or ticket to do something, that is not immediately available but may be in the future):
examples: In case a wait-listed booking is confirmed, immediately inform the customer over the phone.
There are many people, around 99,000 right now, waitlisted for organ transplants.

meanings.definition:
→ 
        
         waiting list

someone who has been put on a 
        
         wait list   (= a list of people who have asked for something, especially a place or ticket to do something, that is not immediately available but may be in the future ):
examples: You might feel like you're the only college wait lister out there, but you're not alone.

meanings.definition: to serve food and drink, especially to customers in a restaurant:
examples: The staff who waited on us at dinner were excellent.
She waited on tables (= served meals as a job) to earn some extra money.

meanings.definition: to do everything for someone so that that person does not have to do anything for himself or herself:
examples: While she was pregnant, her husband waited on her hand and foot (= did everything for her).

meanings.definition: to wait until you know the result of an activity before doing or deciding something:
examples: The lawyers are waiting on the jury's verdict.

meanings.definition: to wait until something unpleasant has ended:
examples: I'd rather wait out the storm than drive home immediately.

meanings.definition: people whose job is to bring food and drinks to customers at their tables in a restaurant:
examples: The wait staff were helpful and attentive without being intrusive.
The atmosphere is lively and the wait staff are great.
I always have a good time there and the waitstaff is really great!
We were shown to our seats by friendly wait-staff, and the restaurant had a great atmosphere.

meanings.definition: said when you are excited about seeing another person's reaction to something special or unusual:
examples: Wait till you see what Rachel's wearing!
Wait till he hears the news.

meanings.definition: to not go to bed at night because you are expecting someone to arrive:
examples: I'll be home after midnight, so don't wait up for me.

meanings.definition: to wait until it is really your turn to do or get something:
examples: If people were more polite, they would wait their turn.

meanings.definition:
past simple and past participle of 
        
         wait
to allow time to go by, especially while staying in one place without doing very much, until someone comes, until something that you are expecting happens or until you can do something:
examples: I waited for her outside while she went in to see the doctor.
The dentist kept me waiting for ages.
There were a lot of people waiting to use the phone.

meanings.definition: to be done or to happen at a later time:
examples: The meeting will have to wait until tomorrow, because I'm too busy now.
The paperwork can't wait until tomorrow (= is urgent and must be done now).

meanings.definition: a man whose job is to bring the food to customers at their tables in a restaurant
a person whose job is to serve meals to people in a restaurant:
examples: A waiter came to the table to take our order.

meanings.definition:
present participle of 
        
         wait
to allow time to go by, especially while staying in one place without doing very much, until someone comes, until something that you are expecting happens or until you can do something:
examples: I waited for her outside while she went in to see the doctor.
The dentist kept me waiting for ages.
There were a lot of people waiting to use the phone.

meanings.definition: to be done or to happen at a later time:
examples: The meeting will have to wait until tomorrow, because I'm too busy now.
The paperwork can't wait until tomorrow (= is urgent and must be done now).

meanings.definition: a situation in which you delay taking any action, so that you can watch how a situation develops and see what it is best for you to do:
examples: In a contest like this, the stronger team can afford to play a waiting game.

meanings.definition: a list of people who have asked for something that is not immediately available but will be in the future:
examples: The hospital has a two-year waiting list for minor operations.
The course is full, but I can put you on the waiting list, in case someone drops out.

meanings.definition: a list of people who asked for something that is not available now but that might be in the future:
examples: The flight is full, but I can put you on the waiting list in case someone cancels.

meanings.definition: a list of people who have asked for something that is not immediately available, but that they will or might be able to receive in the future:
examples: There are no more places available for that session, but I can put you on a waiting list.
I'm afraid there's a waiting list for the new phone.

meanings.definition: a room in a place where people can sit while waiting, as in an airport or a doctor's office
a room where people can sit while waiting, as in a bus station or a doctor’s office
a waiter or waitress (= a person whose job is to bring the food to customers at their tables in a restaurant), used so that you do not need to state what gender the person is:
examples: When eating out with children, don't let the waitperson serve meals to the kids first.
If you want creative cuisine, an extensive wine list, or platoons of waitpersons, this restaurant isn't for you.

meanings.definition: a woman whose job is to bring the food to customers at their tables in a restaurant
to not demand something you have a right to, or not cause a rule to be obeyed:
examples: The bank manager waived the charge (= said we didn't have to pay), as we were old and valued customers.
If they waive (= remove) the time limit, many more applications will come in.
He persuaded the delegates to waive (= give up) their objections.

meanings.definition: to remove a player from a team's roster (= list of players) and make that player available to other teams:
examples: He was waived in June and signed with the Tigers in July.
In order to activate their new player, they needed to waive another from the roster.

meanings.definition: to not demand something you have a right to or not cause a rule to be obeyed:
examples: The bank waived the charge, because the mistake was their fault.

meanings.definition: to decide that you will not ask for something, although you have a right to do so, or that a rule will be ignored:
examples: The bank waived the overdraft fee.

meanings.definition:
past simple and past participle of 
        
         waive

He persuaded the delegates to waive (= give up) their objections.

meanings.definition: an agreement that you do not have to pay or obey something:
examples: We had to sign a waiver, giving up any rights to the land in the future.

meanings.definition: the act of a sports team removing a player from its roster (= list of players) and making that player available to other teams:
examples: The shortstop was placed on waivers and claimed by the Cardinals.
The pitcher was claimed off waivers by the Phillies.

meanings.definition: a document that prevents or allows an action that is different from the usual thing:
examples: Applicants pay a $30 to $40 entry fee; fee waivers are available.

meanings.definition: If a sports player is on waivers he is leaving one team and joining another:
examples: The Coyotes have claimed center Joel Perrault on waivers from the St. Louis Blues.

meanings.definition: an official decision that a rule, or agreement does not have to be obeyed, or that you will not ask for something that you have a right to:
examples: Contributors signed a waiver giving up any rights to future profits.
The company recovered $12 million of its start-up costs from a waiver of state income taxes.

meanings.definition: a type of seaweed (= a plant that grows in the sea or on land very close to the sea) that is used in East Asian cooking:
examples: Wakame is usually sold in dried form, so you need to soak it before using it.
The Japanese restaurant is famed for its tofu and wakame miso soup.

meanings.definition: to (cause someone to) become awake and conscious after sleeping:
examples: Did you wake at all during the night?
Please wake me early tomorrow.
I woke up with a headache.
Jane's hand on my shoulder woke me out of/from a bad dream.

meanings.definition: the waves that a moving ship or object leaves behind:
examples: The wake spread out in a v-shape behind the ship.

meanings.definition: an occasion when the family and friends of a dead person meet in order to look at the dead body the night before it is buried, or when they meet after a dead person has been buried to drink and talk about the person's life
to become awake and conscious after sleeping, or to cause someone to stop sleeping:
examples: Did you wake at all during the night?
The noise of the storm woke the kids.

meanings.definition: an area of water whose movement has been changed by a boat or ship moving through it:
examples: fig. The storm left a massive amount of destruction in its wake.

meanings.definition: a gathering held before a dead person is buried, at which family and friends talk about the person’s life

wake-up-and-smell-the-coffee.name: wake up and smell the coffee

meanings.definition: used to tell someone that they are wrong about a particular situation and must realize what is really happening
to start to understand that a situation or problem exists:
examples: Governments are finally waking up to the fact that the environment should be cleaned up.

meanings.definition: to (cause to) become conscious after sleeping:
examples: Come on, wake up - breakfast is ready.
He woke himself up with his own snoring!

meanings.definition: to start to react to a situation after a period in which you have done very little, or to make someone start to react to a situation:
examples: Companies need to wake up and pay attention to the public's increasing concern about the environment.

meanings.definition: to cause someone to stop sleeping:
examples: I get up, shower, go to school, go home, sleep, wake up, and do it all over again.
If you cry you'll wake your brother up.

meanings.definition: to make someone notice a situation and do something about it:
examples: There is nothing like a disaster to wake people up.

meanings.definition: a word or words that you say in order to make an electronic device, or a feature on a device, ready to work:
examples: If you don't say anything else, your device will go back to sleep until the next time the wake word is uttered.

meanings.definition: If something that happens is a wake-up call, it should make you realize that you need to take action to change a situation:
examples: For the insurance industry, these floods were a wake-up call.

meanings.definition: a phone call that you arrange to be made, for example in a hotel, to wake you up at a certain time
a telephone call or signal to wake you in the morning, typically in a hotel
a shocking event that changes the way many people think:
examples: Fish and Game officials got a wake-up call in a survey on wildlife-related issues.

meanings.definition: if something is a wake-up call, it makes you realize that you need to change the way you do something, to avoid a problem in the future:
examples: The 30% drop in annual profits served as a real wake-up call for high-street retailers.

meanings.definition: a phone call that a hotel guest can arrange to get to wake them up at a particular time:
examples: I'd like a wake-up call at 7, please.

meanings.definition: to be pulled along the surface of the water by a boat, while doing jumps and turns on a board:
examples: I play tennis, water ski, wakeboard and snow ski.
We took it in turns to wakeboard, a cross between water-skiing and snowboarding.

meanings.definition: a board for doing jumps and turns on water, while being pulled along by a boat:
examples: The video shows you how to get up on a wakeboard.
This stunning ad features a man on a wakeboard doing various impressive tricks as he speeds across the water.

meanings.definition: a sport in which you are pulled along the surface of the water by a boat, while doing jumps and turns on a board
not able to sleep, or used to describe a period of time when you are not able to sleep:
examples: We spent a wakeful night worrying about where he was.
She lay there wakeful the whole night.

meanings.definition: in the manner of someone who is not sleeping or not able to sleep:
examples: I could hear my upstairs neighbour wakefully pacing in his bedroom very late at night.
He lay in bed very wakefully all night, staring at the ceiling.

meanings.definition: the state of being wakeful (= not asleep or able to sleep):
examples: She began to drift between sleep and wakefulness.
Symptoms of jetlag include sleepiness during the day, wakefulness at night, and general fatigue.

meanings.definition: to (cause to) wake from sleep:
examples: I shook him but he didn't waken.
Waken me at 7.00, would you?

meanings.definition:
past simple and past participle of 
        
         waken
to (cause to) wake from sleep:
examples: I shook him but he didn't waken.
Waken me at 7.00, would you?

meanings.definition:
present participle of 
        
         waken
to (cause to) wake from sleep:
examples: I shook him but he didn't waken.
Waken me at 7.00, would you?

meanings.definition: said to someone in order to wake them up from sleep:
examples: Gloria knocked on the door and shouted "Wakey-wakey!"

meanings.definition: the moment when you wake:
examples: For a moment, between waking and sleeping, he couldn't understand where he was.

meanings.definition: used to refer to a period of time or an experience during which you are awake:
examples: Children are in school for 15 percent of their waking hours/life between birth and the age of 16.
She seems to spend every waking moment/minute/hour (= all her available time) at the piano.

meanings.definition: a cancer of the immune system that grows slowly and causes severe tiredness, nose bleeds, and weight loss
a cancer of the immune system that grows slowly and causes severe tiredness, nose bleeds, and weight loss
a salad made from apples, celery, and walnuts mixed with mayonnaise (= a thick, cold, white sauce made from oil, vinegar, and the yellow part of eggs):
examples: Waldorf salad is one of those classic American restaurant dishes.
To make a Waldorf salad, chop the apple, celery, and walnuts and then mix with mayonnaise and a handful of grapes.

meanings.definition: a country that is part of the United Kingdom
to move along by putting one foot in front of the other, allowing each foot to touch the ground before lifting the next:
examples: I walked home.
A cat was walking along the top of the fence.
He walks two miles to work every morning.

meanings.definition: to go with someone to a particular place, for example because you want to protect them from danger, or show them the way:
examples: He offered to walk her home/to the station.

meanings.definition: to take an animal, especially a dog, for a walk:
examples: She walks the dog for an hour every afternoon.

meanings.definition: to not be charged with a crime, or to be allowed to leave a court after being found not guilty of a crime:
examples: If police don't get the right evidence, he'll walk.

meanings.definition: to suddenly leave a job or other situation because you have not been given what you want:
examples: Pay essential workers $650 a week or we walk.
"Get real or we walk" UK warns Brussels as Brexit trade deal talks resume.
You give me twenty percent discount on the price or I walk.

meanings.definition: In cricket, if a batter (= the player who tries to hit the ball) walks, they choose to leave the field without waiting for the umpire (= the person who makes certain that the rules are obeyed) to make a decision about whether they are out (= their turn to bat is finished):
examples: He nicked an outswinger to the keeper and walked without waiting for the umpire to lift his finger.
The batter refused to walk, even though all the fielders knew that he had hit it.

meanings.definition: in baseball, to receive four balls outside the hitting area and be allowed to go to first base, or to throw the ball outside the hitting area four times so that the batter is allowed to go to first base:
examples: The first batters either missed or walked.
He would have had a perfect game, except he walked a batter in the final inning.

meanings.definition: to pass or win something, such as an exam or game, easily:
examples: She'll walk the interview - the job is practically hers already.

meanings.definition: a journey that you make by walking, often for enjoyment:
examples: He went for/took a walk around the block, to get some air.
They went on a ten-mile walk to raise money for charity.
Every afternoon she takes her grandfather out for a walk.

meanings.definition: a path or route where people can walk for enjoyment:
examples: Do you know any nice walks around here?

meanings.definition: a way of walking:
examples: He has a strange waddling sort of walk.

meanings.definition: walking speed:
examples: She slowed the horses to a walk.

meanings.definition: in baseball, an occasion when a batter is allowed to go to first base after the pitcher has thrown the ball outside the hitting area four times
to move along by putting one foot in front of the other, or to move a distance in this way:
examples: I walked home.
We just walked past a famous actress.
They walked all around Chinatown.
I walk to work every morning.
It’s not that far – you can walk it in half an hour.
We must have walked miles today.

meanings.definition: To walk someone to a particular place is to walk with the person until the place has been reached:
examples: He offered to walk her home.

meanings.definition: To walk an animal, esp. a dog, is to bring it outside with you to walk.
an act of moving along by putting one foot in front of the other, or moving a distance in this, esp. for pleasure or exercise:
examples: He went for/took a walk around the block.

meanings.definition: to be unkind to someone and treat that person without respect:
examples: You shouldn’t let him walk all over you like that.

meanings.definition: to stop being involved in a situation because it is difficult to deal with or does not give you any advantages:
examples: You can't just walk away from a marriage at the first sign of a problem.

meanings.definition: to escape an accident without being badly hurt:
examples: She overturned the car, but walked away from it without a scratch.

meanings.definition: to win a prize or competition very easily:
examples: He walked away with all three gold medals.

meanings.definition: to win something easily:
examples: The German soccer team is once again favored to walk away with the championship.

meanings.definition: to change an opinion that you had expressed before or admit that a statement you made was wrong:
examples: He has since walked back his opposition to the bill.
With massive video evidence, he walked back his claim that he was spat on.

meanings.definition: to not be charged with a crime, or to be allowed to leave a court after being found not guilty of a crime: to leave a prison or other place where you have been kept as a prisoner: to be able to walk somewhere without anyone stopping you or attacking you:
examples: They were not arrested or charged and walked free after a seven-hour interrogation.
One of the women charged with this 2017 murder is set to walk free.
He walked free from court in October after judges ruled he was suffering from temporary mental illness.
After two weeks of negotiations the hostages walked free.
He describes the scene on the day when Nelson Mandela walked free from his island prison.
He said that he wanted to ensure that women, children, the elderly, and students can walk free on the streets without fear of being attacked.
A gunman walked free around Virginia Tech's campus, but authorities had no idea where.

meanings.definition: to go into a room and see what someone is doing, when they did not want to be seen:
examples: She walked in on me when I was getting undressed.

meanings.definition: to get a job very easily:
examples: She walked straight into a well-paid job after graduating from university.

meanings.definition: to get a job very easily:
examples: She walked straight into a well-paid city job after leaving university.

meanings.definition: to win or succeed easily:
examples: The team should walk it on Saturday.

meanings.definition: When people talk about walk(s) of life, they are referring to different types of jobs and different levels of society:
examples: Members of the gym include lawyers, teachers, plumbers, and hairdressers - people from all (different) walks of life.

meanings.definition: to leave a place because you are angry or unhappy about something:
examples: She threatened to walk off the film set because of the conditions.
He refused to discuss it and just walked off in a huff.

meanings.definition: to walk in order to try and get rid of pain or an unpleasant feeling such as anger:
examples: I'm going out to walk off this headache.
She twisted her ankle and tried to walk it off, but it hurt too much.
He managed to walk off his bad mood.

meanings.definition: In baseball, a walk-off hit is one that allows a player to score the winning run (= point) and causes the game to end:
examples: Ortiz hit a walk-off home run in the twelfth inning.
A walk-off single allowed the runner on second base to score.

meanings.definition: to win something easily:
examples: She walked off with the top prize.

meanings.definition: to steal something or take something without asking permission:
examples: Who's walked off with my cup?

meanings.definition: to take something without asking:
examples: Who walked off with my drink?

meanings.definition: to feel extremely excited or happy:
examples: After the delivery of her baby, she was walking on air.

meanings.definition: to be very careful not to offend or upset someone:
examples: I find in business these days I'm walking on eggs; I have to be careful with everything I say.
Sometimes everyone feels like they are tiptoeing on eggs, but with friends we can be ourselves.

meanings.definition: to leave an event such as a meeting or performance because you are angry or disapprove of something:
examples: All the parents walked out (of the meeting) in protest.

meanings.definition: to suddenly leave your husband, wife, or partner and end your relationship with them:
examples: He walked out on his wife and two kids.

meanings.definition: to stop working or leave your job because of a disagreement with your employer:
examples: Workers are threatening to walk out.

meanings.definition: to leave an event before it is finished because you are not enjoying it or because you do not agree with it:
examples: It was such a bad movie that I felt like walking out in the first fifteen minutes.

meanings.definition: If workers walk out, they go on strike (= stop working at their jobs in order to express a complaint):
examples: Airline pilots are threatening to walk out next week.

meanings.definition: to refuse to continue working and leave your office, factory, etc. to show your employer that you are unhappy about something:
examples: Workers are threatening to walk out over pay.

meanings.definition: to suddenly end your relationship or involvement with someone or something:
examples: You can't afford to walk out on your job.

meanings.definition: if someone walks out on a job, etc., they leave before finishing it because they are not happy about something:
examples: Workers who walked out on the job could be sacked for breach of contract.

meanings.definition: If you walk right into something, you are caught or tricked by it because you did not know what was happening:
examples: We set a trap and they walked right into it.

meanings.definition: to show that something is true by your actions rather than your words:
examples: We're at this meeting because we're environmentalists who walk the walk.

meanings.definition: to show that something is true by your actions rather than your words:
examples: We're at this meeting because we're environmentalists who walk the walk.

meanings.definition: to practise something, for example a performance, without an audience being present:
examples: Let's just walk through the scene one more time.

meanings.definition: to slowly and carefully explain something to someone or show someone how to do something:
examples: She walked me through the six-page document.
He'll walk you through the procedure.

meanings.definition: to practice something, or to show someone how to do something from beginning to end:
examples: They can walk you through the process one more time, to give you some practice and confidence.

meanings.definition: the act of doing something or checking something in order to find possible problems:
examples: The firm built a model of the laboratory, so that the lab's future users could do a walk-through and make suggestions.
The gas company offers a free walk-through inspection of your home to identify potential savings.

meanings.definition: a set of instructions showing you how to use something, for example, new software:
examples: This walkthrough is for members of staff using the software for the first time.

meanings.definition: especially in baseball, the year before a player ends their contract (= legal agreement) with a sports club, and is then able to agree different conditions, join another club, etc.:
examples: It seems like players are always more motivated in their walk year, or the last year of their contract.
He is said to have had the greatest walk year in Major League Baseball history.

meanings.definition: used to refer to a space used for storing things that is large enough for a person to enter and walk around in:
examples: a walk-in wardrobe
a walk-in refrigerator

meanings.definition: used to refer to a place that you can go to without an appointment (= an arrangement made in advance):
examples: It's a walk-in dental clinic.

meanings.definition: someone who goes to a place without an appointment (= an arrangement made in advance):
examples: Although the restaurant will take walk-ins, reservations are recommended.
With the track sold out and no walk-ins allowed, a crowd of about 51,000 is expected.

meanings.definition: large enough for a person to enter and walk around in:
examples: a walk-in closet

meanings.definition: allowing people to come without planning to do so in advance:
examples: The walk-in clinic is slowly getting busy.

meanings.definition: a college athlete (= person who is very good at sports) who was not officially asked to join a team before the start of a season but who is able to join the team later, usually because they have shown they have enough skills in a test of their ability:
examples: He made the University of Miami squad as a freshman walk-on.
She is a former walk-on who will be the most experienced returning player.

meanings.definition: A walk-on part in a play is a very small part in which the actor is on the stage for a short time and speaks very few or no words.
a building with several floors and no elevator (= a device for going from one floor to another) or an apartment or office in such a building
a building with four or more floors and no elevator (= device for taking people from one floor to another), or an apartment on an upper floor in such a building
the price you pay for something such as a ticket if you buy it just before using it, rather than buying it some time earlier:
examples: Tickets booked online for the same day will be charged at the full walk-up price.

meanings.definition: to be very careful not to offend or upset someone:
examples: If you're sick you don't want people treating you differently, and you really don't want people walking on eggshells around you.
When he's tired we spend the day treading on eggshells as he becomes stubborn and grumpy.
I was always on eggshells when my family came to stay.

meanings.definition: If you walk/tread a tightrope, you have to deal with a difficult situation, especially one involving making a decision between two opposing plans of action:
examples: Many manufacturers have to walk a tightrope between pricing their goods too high and not selling them, and pricing them low and losing money.

meanings.definition: of an area, pleasant, easy, and safe to walk in:
examples: In spite of San Francisco's many hills, it's a very walkable city.

meanings.definition: that is close enough for you to be able to reach it by walking:
examples: The restaurant is walkable from the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

meanings.definition: an occasion when an important person walks around a public place, meeting and talking to members of the public:
examples: The princess went on a walkabout in the town centre.

meanings.definition: a long journey by an Australian Aboriginal, especially on foot for cultural reasons:
examples: They meet an aborigine boy on ritual walkabout away from his tribe.

meanings.definition: an organized event in which people walk a long distance in order to raise money for charity (= organizations that give money, food, or help free to those who are in need, or that provide money for causes such as medical research):
examples: She is organizing a walkathon from Palms Marine Base in Southern California to Dubois, a distance of over 1,500 miles.
Her son was an organizer from an early age; he staged a cancer walkathon at age 12.

meanings.definition: in baseball, to receive four balls outside the hitting area and be allowed to go to first base, or to throw the ball outside the hitting area four times so that the batter is allowed to go to first base:
examples: The first batters either missed or walked.
He would have had a perfect game, except he walked a batter in the final inning.

meanings.definition: to pass or win something, such as an exam or game, easily:
examples: She'll walk the interview - the job is practically hers already.

meanings.definition: a person who walks, especially for exercise or enjoyment:
examples: She's a very fast/slow walker.
They've been keen walkers ever since they read about the benefits of exercise.

meanings.definition: a seat on wheels that a baby can sit in and use its feet to move along, before it is able to walk
a metal frame with four legs that you place in front of you and lean on to help you move forward if you have difficulty in walking, for example when old
A walker is also a metal frame to help people who have difficulty walking, by using it to support them as they move it in front of them.
a small radio held in the hand, used for both sending and receiving messages:
examples: The policeman was speaking to the station on his walkie-talkie.

meanings.definition: a small radio held in the hand and used for both sending and receiving messages
said to a dog to tell it that it is time for a walk:
examples: Walkies, Shem, come on, walkies!

meanings.definition: the activity of going for a walk, especially for pleasure:
examples: We're going walking in Wales for a week.
We're going walking in the park after work.
a pair of walking boots
a walking stick

meanings.definition: the sport of walking fast over long distances
in basketball, the act of taking three or more steps with the ball without dribbling it (= hitting it against the floor repeatedly), which is against the rules:
examples: Getting called for walking can lead to your team losing possession of the ball.
After you stop dribbling, it counts as walking if you move your pivot foot before you pass or shoot the ball.

meanings.definition: a type of strong boot that covers the foot and ankle, designed for long walks in the countryside:
examples: Stephen always kept an anorak and a pair of walking boots in the car.
This is a traditional sturdy walking boot that provides the foot with a firm support.

meanings.definition: a type of football in which the players walk instead of running. It mainly follows the usual rules of football, with some small changes:
examples: Walking football has become increasingly popular and is suitable for older people who may have mobility problems that stop them playing faster-paced games.

meanings.definition:
→ 
        
         Zimmer frame
If you give someone their walking papers, you ask that person to leave a place or a job because they have done something wrong:
examples: Three players got their walking papers last week.
She was called into the boss's office and given her walking papers.

meanings.definition:
→ 
        
         marching orders
a specially designed long stick, often made of metal and used in a pair, that gives you support when you are walking:
examples: On uphill stretches, adjustable walking poles can transfer more than half your weight to the upper body.
Try walking poles to save your knees and help you balance.

meanings.definition: a wooden or metal stick with a handle at the top that you can lean on to give you support or help you to balance when walking:
examples: The video clip shows him trudging through the snow with a walking stick.
She was leaning on a walking stick after her recent knee surgery.
He still manages to get about with the aid of a walking stick.
He has got rid of his wheelchair, carer and walking-stick and on a good day can climb all the stairs.

meanings.definition: a large insect with a long, thin body that looks like a small stick:
examples: Walking sticks reproduce both sexually and asexually, which means that they do not need a mate to reproduce.

meanings.definition: a brand name for a small audio or video player with small headphones, that you can carry around with you
the act of leaving an official meeting as a group in order to show disapproval, or of leaving a place of work to start a strike:
examples: Senior union workers staged (= had) a walkout this afternoon at the annual conference over the proposed changes in funding.

meanings.definition: the act of leaving a place to show that you are unhappy, or (of workers) the act of stopping work because of a disagreement with management:
examples: Some people who were unhappy with the changes staged a walkout during the meeting.
The airline barely averted a walkout by flight attendants this past June.

meanings.definition: a situation in which workers refuse to continue working and leave their office, factory, etc. to show their employer that they are unhappy about something:
examples: Cabin crew staged a walkout costing the airline $150m.
avert/call off a walkout
hold/join a walkout
a 24-hour/mass walkout

meanings.definition: a situation in which a group of people leave a meeting to show that they do not agree with something:
examples: The meeting ended in a walkout by the union negotiators.

meanings.definition: a game or sports event that is won very easily by one side or one person:
examples: The semifinal should be a walkover for France.

meanings.definition: the act of winning one stage of a competition without having to compete in it because the person that you should be playing against is no longer taking part
various levels of social position or achievement:
examples: In my work I see people from all walks of life.

meanings.definition: an occasion when you practise something, for example a performance, without an audience being present
a detailed set of instructions on how to do something, for example use a computer program or game
a passage or path, especially one that is covered or raised above the ground
a vertical structure, often made of stone or brick, that divides or surrounds something:
examples: The walls in this apartment are so thin you can hear just about every word the neighbours say.
The walls look a bit bare - can't we put some pictures up?
We had to climb over a ten-foot wall to get into the garden.
The Berlin Wall came down in 1989.

meanings.definition: any outer part of a hollow structure in the body:
examples: the wall of the uterus/stomach
an artery wall

meanings.definition: a mass of people or things formed in such a way that you cannot get through or past them:
examples: The demonstrators formed a solid wall to stop the police from getting past them.

meanings.definition: in football, a row of players who stand ten yards away from where a free kick is taken in order to make scoring directly from the free kick more difficult:
examples: Rooney curved the free kick past the Newcastle defensive wall and inside the far post.

meanings.definition: a large, powerful, usually fast moving mass of something:
examples: After the rains, the houses were washed away by a wall of mud/water.

meanings.definition: a way of feeling or behaving that completely prevents two groups of people from communicating with or understanding each other:
examples: There is a wall of mistrust between the two groups.

meanings.definition: a vertical structure that divides or encloses something:
examples: The walls of the fortress were more than eighteen inches thick.
We’d like the walls painted white.

meanings.definition: A wall of people or things is a mass of them formed in such a way that you cannot get through or past them:
a large piece of material or sewing that is hung on a wall as a decoration
an exercise in which you stand facing a wall with your hands on the wall and lean towards it while keeping your feet flat on the floor:
examples: Add strength training, such as weightlifting or doing wall push-ups, to your exercise routine.
To prevent cramps, try doing a few wall pushups before going to bed.

meanings.definition: an exercise in which you lean your back against a wall and bend your knees to an angle of 90 degrees, as though you are sitting on a chair:
examples: The wall sit is a classic home exercise for the thighs.
Wall sits are a great way to improve lower body strength and endurance.

meanings.definition: to surround something with walls or tall structures:
examples: The valley is walled in by high mountains.

meanings.definition: to build a wall around a place:
examples: The embassy is walled off from the street.

meanings.definition: to fill a space in a wall with brick or stone:
examples: We had to wall up an old window.

meanings.definition: a street in New York that represents the financial centre of the US:
examples: On Wall Street today, the Dow Jones rose 55 points following good economic figures.

meanings.definition: a street in New York City that represents the financial center of the US:
examples: On Wall Street today, stocks closed higher.

meanings.definition: a street in New York where the New York Stock Exchange is, and that is the financial centre of the US. Wall Street is used to refer to the financial world in the US in general, and to big businesses and their interests rather than small ones:
examples: On Wall Street, the Dow Jones rose 30 points.
Wall Street prices/shares/stocks
Wall Street analysts/bankers/economists
Wall Street firms/investors/traders
Both Wall Street and Main Street were badly affected by the downturn.

meanings.definition: the events in October 1929, when shares on the New York Stock Exchange lost a lot of their value, causing serious economic problems in the US and Europe and leading to the Depression:
examples: Economic advisors said there was a danger of a Wall Street crash if investors stopped buying American assets.

meanings.definition: the events of Monday, October 19, 1987, when shares on the New York Stock Exchange lost 508 points, causing problems in stock markets around the world
the events of Monday, October 27, 1997, when shares on the New York Stock Exchange lost 554 points causing problems in stock markets around the world
having a condition that makes both eyes turn outwards, so that more white is showing than normal:
examples: In this self-portrait, the artist looks slightly wall-eyed.
He had an old shotgun and a walleyed dog.

meanings.definition: (especially of carpets) covering the whole floor:
examples: a wall-to-wall carpet

meanings.definition: continuous or happening very often or everywhere around you:
examples: I went away to college thinking it would be wall-to-wall parties and all the freedom I wanted.

meanings.definition: covering the whole floor:
examples: wall-to-wall carpeting

meanings.definition: an animal found in Australia and New Guinea that is like a small kangaroo
(in compounds) a person who has a particular duty:
examples: I made the tea yesterday so it's Mira's turn to be tea-wallah this afternoon.
a rickshaw-wallah

meanings.definition: added to nouns to describe a person who has a particular duty or job, or with a particular appearance:
examples: a rickshawallah

meanings.definition: material consisting of two sheets of heavy paper with a layer of plaster between them, used to make walls and ceilings before putting on a top layer of plaster
a large, thin, rectangular piece of building material used to make the walls inside some buildings
a large printed drawing showing information in a simple way, that you stick or pin to a wall
a large piece of paper that has pictures and information printed on it and is hung on a wall:
examples: Our wallchart year planner will help your staff plan their activities more effectively.

meanings.definition: surrounded by a wall:
examples: Why not visit the beautiful walled city of York?

meanings.definition: a small folding case for carrying paper money, credit cards and other flat objects, that can be carried in a pocket and is used especially by men:
examples: He pulled out a big, fat wallet stuffed with banknotes.

meanings.definition: a small container for carrying coins, paper money, and credit cards, used especially by women
a flat, folding bag that is used for holding documents, for example passports
a small, folding case for paper money, credit cards (= plastic cards you use to buy things), other cards that you want to carry with you, and sometimes coins:
examples: a leather wallet

meanings.definition: a small case for carrying money, credit cards, and small personal documents:
examples: Using video on your website will motivate potential buyers to get out their wallet.

meanings.definition: a large dark yellow or light green fish that lives in rivers in North America, or the flesh of these fish eaten as food:
examples: A walleye's diet consists mainly of other fish.
They like to pan-fry fillets of walleye in breadcrumbs and serve them with a creamy sauce.
There is a group of guys in the village who go fishing for walleye at night.
The freezer was packed with fish, including five walleyes.

meanings.definition: a pleasant smelling garden plant that has yellow, orange, or brown flowers that grow in groups
a shy person, especially a girl or woman, who is frightened to involve herself in social activities and does not attract much interest or attention:
examples: Sooner or later someone would take pity on the poor wallflower and ask her to dance.

meanings.definition: a type of investment that investors are not very interested in because they think it does not have much value:
examples: Because National Savings products are not very competitive, they are widely regarded as the wallflowers of the investment world.

meanings.definition: to hit someone hard, especially with the flat part of the hand or with something held in the hand:
examples: She walloped him across the back of the head.

meanings.definition: to defeat someone easily, especially in sports:
examples: "How did your tennis game go last night?" "Oh, I was walloped again."

meanings.definition: a hard hit, especially with the flat part of the hand or with something held in the hand:
examples: My mother gave me such a wallop when she eventually found me.

meanings.definition: to hit someone or something hard:
examples: Floyd can wallop high pitches as well as low ones.

meanings.definition: (esp. of animals) to lie or roll about slowly in deep, wet earth, sand, or water:
examples: The pig wallowed in the mud.

meanings.definition: fig. To wallow in an emotion or situation is to stay in that state without trying to change:
examples: He was not a fellow to shed tears, or wallow in self-pity.

meanings.definition: to allow yourself to enjoy something completely:
examples: My idea of a holiday is to stay in a five-star hotel and just wallow in luxury for a week.

meanings.definition: to remain in an unhappy emotional state without trying to get out of it, as if you are enjoying it or trying to get sympathy from other people:
examples: I wish she'd do something to help herself instead of just wallowing in self-pity!

meanings.definition: a design or image that you can choose to have as a background (= behind the main information) on a screen of your computer or mobile phone:

walnut cookies

meanings.definition: a tall tree on which walnuts grow:

a lute-like instrument made of walnut

an ordinary person who pretends to have, or dreams about having, a life that is more interesting or exciting:

meanings.definition: a formal dance in which two people holding each other move around a large room, turning as they go, or a piece of music with three beats in a bar, written for this style of dancing:
examples: The competitors must complete five dances, including a Viennese waltz.
He opened the programme with Ravel's "La Valse".

meanings.definition: to walk somewhere quickly and confidently, often in a way that annoys other people:

meanings.definition: abbreviation for Wide Area Network: a system for connecting computers in different areas of a country or the world:
examples: High speed broadband has made real-time WAN communications possible.

meanings.definition: a special thin stick waved by a person who is performing magic tricks:
examples: The fairy godmother waved her wand over the cabbages and they turned into horses.
He stepped back from the cave wall, pointed his wand at the rock, and commanded the hidden door to open.
For the author, the pen is a magician's wand.

meanings.definition: an electronic device that is held in the hand and that is used to find metal, for example when checking whether someone is carrying a weapon:
examples: A security guard uses a metal-detecting wand to check out students entering the school.
Screeners can detect anything metal with the help of hand-held wands.
She had ignored a request to stop and be checked with a hand wand.

meanings.definition: an electronic device that is held in the hand and that is used, for example, to read data and to enter it onto a computer:
examples: A wand reader is used as a hand-held scanner.
Electronic wands are used to check the bar codes on the products.

meanings.definition: a thin stick that is used for putting mascara (= a thick dark liquid make-up) onto your eyelashes (= the short hairs that grow along the edges of the eye):

meanings.definition: a thin stick with a circle at the end that you put into liquid soap and use to blow bubbles:

meanings.definition: a thin stick waved by a person who is performing magic:

meanings.definition: to walk around slowly in a relaxed way or without any clear purpose or direction:
examples: We spent the morning wandering around the old part of the city.
She was found several hours later, wandering the streets, lost.
He was here a minute ago but he's wandered off somewhere.

meanings.definition: If someone's hands or eyes wander, they touch or look in many different places, especially in a sexual way or when they should not do this:
examples: If his hands start to wander, tell him firmly, "No, I'm not ready for this."
He was cruelly described as a creepy old man with wandering hands.
Her gaze wandered around the flat.

meanings.definition: to have sexual relationships or experiences outside of your marriage or usual relationship:
examples: She wrote an article about infidelity called "Wives who wander".
She had enough problems dealing with a wandering husband.

meanings.definition: to start talking about a different subject from the one you were originally discussing:
examples: We've wandered off/from the point somewhat.

meanings.definition: If your mind or your thoughts wander, you stop thinking about the subject that you should be giving your attention to and start thinking about other matters:
examples: Halfway through the meeting my mind started to wander.

meanings.definition: If you say that an old person's mind is beginning to wander, you mean that they are starting to get very confused because of their age:
examples: Her mind is beginning to wander and she doesn't always know who I am.

meanings.definition: a walk done in a slow relaxed way or without any clear purpose or direction:
examples: While you're at your meeting I can go for/have/take a wander around the city.

to wish for a particular thing or plan of action. "Want" is not used in polite requests:
examples: I want some chocolate.
She wants a meeting with you.
He's everything you'd ever want in a man - bright, funny and attractive.
What do you want to eat?
Do you want me to take you to the airport?
This package - do you want it sent today?
Do you want this pie hot?
I don't want you coming in at two a.m., waking me up.
You wait - by next year she'll be wanting a bigger house!

meanings.definition: to wish or need someone to be present:
examples: Am I wanted at the meeting tomorrow?
He is wanted by the police (= they are searching for him).

meanings.definition: to need something:
examples: Do you think this soup wants a bit of salt?
The wine is in the fridge - it just wants cooling for a couple of minutes.

meanings.definition: a lack of something:
examples: For want of anything better to do I watched television for a while.
If we fail it won't be for want of trying (= we have tried even if we fail).

meanings.definition: to feel that you would like to have something or would like something to happen:
examples: Who wants ice cream?
I want the cold weather to end.
She wanted to get new shoes.
I don’t want him talking about me.
I’ve been wanting to thank you for helping me.

meanings.definition: If you are wanted, someone wishes to see or talk with you:
examples: Harry! You’re wanted on the phone.

meanings.definition: to need something:
examples: You want to be careful to stay out of the sun.

to lack something you need:
examples: We didn’t have much, but we never wanted for food.

meanings.definition: to want to start being involved in something:
examples: I want in on the whole venture before it's too late.
He saw it as an up-and-coming market and he wanted in.
He described the show to her and asked if she wanted in.
Lots of people want in on this opportunity, but few folks have the endurance to stay with it.
I know a good investment when I see it. I want in.

meanings.definition: to want to stop being involved in something:
examples: I want out of the whole venture before it's too late.
Marriage felt like a straightjacket and she wanted out of it.
Most of the investors want out of the company after a few years.
He had lost all his money in the stock market, and he wanted out.
I had grown up in the sect, but by the time I was an adult, I wanted out.

meanings.definition: used in giving advice to mean that someone should do something:
examples: She wants to tell him now, before it's too late.
You don't want to put in too much pepper.
What you want to do is get advice from an qualified financial advisor.
They want to get their act together, and soon!
You don't want to listen to anything she tells you.

meanings.definition: used by sports journalists to refer to a football player who publicly says that they want to leave their current club
wished for and loved by other people:
examples: She was a much wanted baby.

meanings.definition: being searched for by the police because of a crime:
examples: He's a wanted man.

meanings.definition: being searched for by the police:
examples: He was one of the ten most wanted criminals in America.

meanings.definition: a section of a newspaper, etc. with classified ads
not having something; lacking:
examples: I think she's perhaps a little wanting in charm.

meanings.definition: missing:
examples: It was a perfect party – nothing was wanting.

meanings.definition: (of something bad, such as damage, cruelty, waste) extreme and showing no care at all:
examples: wanton destruction of human life
a wanton disregard for safety
wanton extravagance

meanings.definition: (of a woman) behaving or appearing in a very sexual way
causing harm or acting without showing care for others, often intentionally:
examples: He displayed a wanton disregard for the facts.

meanings.definition: in a way that is intentional or shows no care about bad things that might result:
examples: Their lives were brutally and wantonly cut short.
I will not hesitate to identify countries which repeatedly and wantonly violate international law.

meanings.definition: in a way that is, or appears to be, very sexual:
examples: She left her blonde hair wantonly loose around her face and shoulders.
She could not believe that she had behaved so wantonly.

meanings.definition: bad behaviour that is intentional or shows no care about bad things that might result:
examples: The chairman this week condemned the bank's wantonness towards other people's money.
We all felt a strong dismay and horror at such an act of wantonness.

meanings.definition: behaviour that is very sexual:
examples: She has been represented as a person of wantonness, vices, and crimes.
The sheer wantonness of our society is depressing.

meanings.definition: products and services that people want and need:
examples: The Marketing Department researches our customers wants and needs.

meanings.definition: abbreviation for Wireless Application Protocol: a system that allows you to use the internet using a type of mobile phone
abbreviation for Wireless Application Protocol: a system for using the internet with a mobile phone:
examples: WAP phones
WAP device/services/technology

meanings.definition: abbreviation for Wireless Access Point: a small piece of equipment that allows computers, mobile phones, etc. to communicate with each other without using wires:
examples: The town has about 100 WAPs that provide "hot spot" coverage.

meanings.definition: a large deer with brownish-red fur and large antlers (= horns like branches) that lives in the forests of North America
armed fighting between two or more countries or groups, or a particular example of this:
examples: nuclear war
a war film/grave/hero/poet
If this country goes to (= starts to fight in a) war we will have to face the fact that many people will die.
Britain and France declared war on Germany in 1939 as a result of the invasion of Poland.
War broke out between the two countries after a border dispute.
They've been at war for the last five years.
He died in the First World War/the Vietnam war.

meanings.definition: any situation in which there is strong competition between opposing sides or a great fight against something harmful:
examples: The past few months have witnessed a price war between leading supermarkets.
The president vowed to wage war on/against terrorism.
For thirty years, the war on drugs has used up enormous human and financial resources.

meanings.definition: armed fighting between two or more countries or groups, or a particular example of such fighting:
examples: Can any country fight two wars at the same time?
War is something to avoid.
Several nations were at war.

meanings.definition: A war can also be any situation in which there is strong competition between opposing sides or a joint effort against something harmful:
examples: Airlines engage in fare wars to attract new customers.
It sometimes seems like the war on cancer has stalled.

meanings.definition: a situation in which businesses, countries, etc. compete against each other very strongly:
examples: In the supermarket war, Asda slashed the price of petrol.
The banks are at war for each other's business accounts.
The EU is in danger of losing the propaganda war.

meanings.definition: a girl or woman who, during a war, marries a member of the armed forces from a different country
money that has been collected or saved to pay for something, especially a long fight to achieve something:
examples: The candidates are gathering money for their election war chests.

meanings.definition: infml money that has been collected or saved to pay for something, esp. a long fight achieve something:
examples: The candidates are gathering money for their election war chests.

meanings.definition: a large amount of money that a company or a government keeps for a particular purpose:
examples: The retail group has raised a $1.6 billion war chest to fund its expansion plans.
a campaign/election war chest

meanings.definition: If you say that war clouds are gathering over a particular country, you mean that a war seems increasingly likely there:
examples: It was the 1930s and war clouds were gathering on the horizon in Europe.

meanings.definition: a crime committed during a war that breaks the accepted international rules of war:
examples: Genocide is a war crime.

meanings.definition: an act, such as harming prisoners or children, that is against the agreed international rules of war
someone who commits war crimes:
examples: He was a Nazi war criminal.

meanings.definition: a phrase or word shouted by people as they start to fight, intended to give them the strength and wish to fight harder:
examples: The phrase "burn your bra!" was the feminists' war cry of the 1970s.

meanings.definition: a formal dance, performed by some tribal people, either before they fight or after they have won a fight
a pretend military battle that is performed only for the purpose of training
practices held by armed forces to test new equipment and test plans for fighting
a large structure, usually made of stone, that is built in honour of those people who died in a particular war
a war that is fought over a long period and only ends when one side has neither the soldiers and equipment nor the determination left to continue fighting:
examples: The war of attrition between the two countries has lasted for decades now.
The fight against cancer is a war of attrition rather than a series of spectacular breakthroughs.
Recent years have seen a war of attrition between developers and residents.
Candidates are preparing themselves for a war of attrition for the nomination.
The war of attrition ended when the two sides eventually reached an agreement.

meanings.definition: a situation, often before a competition or battle, in which each opposing side attempts to frighten or discourage the other by making threats or by showing how strong it is:
examples: Protestors are waging a war of nerves with the police.
Irrespective of the prospect of a shooting war, the war of nerves between the two governments intensified last week.
She realised that her ex-husband was engaging in a war of nerves with her over custody of the children.
He is aware that he is losing the war of nerves with his rival.
She has raised the stakes in her war of nerves with her sister.

meanings.definition: serious or angry discussions about something that people disagree on, especially discussions that continue for a long time:
examples: The war of words over sanctions remains furious.
Politicians in California, Illinois, and other states engaged in an escalating war of words.

meanings.definition: in the past, a group of Native Americans who left their homes to fight a war:
examples: The mural showed a Native American war party encountering a huge bison at a lakefront.
The warparty divided into smaller groups and was ready to take on the enemy.

meanings.definition: a political party that supports or wants war :
examples: A smaller military budget could have allowed more social spending, but the war party did not see it that way.
The downfall of the war party would be the best victory for this country.

meanings.definition: a place where people are fighting in a war:
examples: Some people mistakenly believe that the country is still a war zone.

severely damaged by a long war, especially between different groups from the same country:

meanings.definition: to prevent someone or something unpleasant from harming or coming close to you:

meanings.definition: to keep someone or something away or prevent something from happening or harming you:

meanings.definition: a person who is in charge of a prison

meanings.definition: a person who is in charge of people in prison
a tall cupboard in which you hang your clothes:

meanings.definition: a department in a theatre, film company, etc. that is in charge of the clothes that the actors wear on stage, making certain that they are clean, repairing them and sometimes making them:
examples: He's in charge of wardrobe at the local amateur theatre.

meanings.definition: the clothes that a person owns, or a particular type of clothes that a person owns:

meanings.definition: A wardrobe is also a piece of furniture where clothes are kept.
an occasion when someone shows a private part of their body in public by accident, because a piece of their clothing has moved out of position :
examples: They weren't sure if the dress was an unusual fashion creation or an embarrassing wardrobe malfunction.

meanings.definition: towards the stated place or direction:

meanings.definition: a situation in which a person, usually a child, is legally put under the care of a court or a guardian (= a person who has the legal right and responsibility of taking care of someone who cannot take care of himself or herself):
examples: The teenager became a ward of the court, but the wardship expired on his 18th birthday.
The wardship proceedings, which are still ongoing, will determine who will have custody of the child.

meanings.definition: pottery (= objects made out of clay) of a particular type or make:

meanings.definition: used, especially in stores, to refer to objects of the same material or type:

meanings.definition: a large building for storing things before they are sold, used, or sent out to shops, or :
examples: The goods have been sitting in a warehouse for months because a strike has prevented distribution.

meanings.definition: a large shop selling large numbers of a particular product at a cheap rate:
examples: We bought both sofas from a big furniture warehouse out of town.

meanings.definition: to store something in a warehouse:

meanings.definition: to put people in a large prison, hospital, etc. without trying to help them with their problems:

meanings.definition: a large building used for storing goods:

meanings.definition: A warehouse is also a type of large store where goods are sold at a reduced price.

meanings.definition: small products for selling, especially in a market or on the street:

meanings.definition: a company's products:

meanings.definition: items offered for sale, or a company’s goods:

meanings.definition: products that are for sale:
