meanings.definition: the activity of fighting a war or strongly competing, esp. with reference to the type of weapons used or to the way the fighting is done:
examples: psychological/nuclear warfare
economic warfare

meanings.definition: a brand name for a substance that is used to kill rats and is also used in a slightly different form as a medical treatment in order to prevent blood from clotting (= becoming solid)
the front part of a bomb or missile that contains explosives:
examples: a conventional/nuclear warhead

meanings.definition: the end of a bomb or missile that contains explosives
an old and experienced politician, soldier, or athlete, especially one who is still active:
examples: Manchester City's old warhorse, still fighting fit at 36, was sent off for fouling after half an hour.

meanings.definition: a piece of music, television show, play, or other performed piece of work that has often been performed or shown and is very famous:
examples: I don't understand why a ballet company can't perform fresh new material instead of just bringing out the same old warhorses year after year.

meanings.definition: in a way that is wary (= not completely trusting or certain):
examples: She eyed the dog warily, afraid it might jump.
It is quite wrong that he should have to tread warily while others speak their minds.

meanings.definition: See at wary.
the state or quality of being wary (= not completely trusting or certain):
examples: They eyed each other with wariness and suspicion.

meanings.definition: often involved in and eager to start wars:

meanings.definition: suited to or liking war, or threatening, as if going to fight:

meanings.definition: a man who is believed to have magical powers, usually to do evil
a military leader who controls a country or, more often, an area within a country
a military leader who controls a country or, more frequently, an area within a country, esp. when the central government is not in control
having or producing a comfortably high temperature, although not hot:
examples: Are you warm enough or do you want me to put the heating on?
I put my hands in my pockets to keep them warm.

meanings.definition: Warm clothes and covers are made of a material that keeps you warm:
examples: I don't have a warm winter coat.
Those gloves look nice and warm.

meanings.definition: A warm colour is one that is based on or contains a colour such as red, yellow, or orange that suggests warmth.
friendly and loving:
examples: They're a very warm family.
He has a lovely warm smile.
I'd like to give a warm welcome to our guests this evening.

meanings.definition: (especially in children's games) almost guessing a correct answer or discovering a hidden object:
examples: You're getting warmer!

meanings.definition: to (cause to) become warm (= less cold):
examples: You're so cold - come and warm your hands by the fire.
Your supper's just warming through in the oven.
We can warm (up) the room pretty quickly with this electric heater.

meanings.definition: having a fairly high temperature, but not hot:
examples: Warm bread always tastes better.
Just let me sit in the sun so I can get warm.

meanings.definition: Warm clothes or covers keep out the cold and make you feel comfortable:
examples: a warm winter coat
a warm woolen hat and mittens

meanings.definition: friendly and affectionate:
examples: Grace is a warm, caring woman.

meanings.definition: (of colors) light and bright, and esp. containing red, yellow, or orange
to rise to a higher temperature, or to cause something to rise to a higher temperature:
examples: He rubbed his hands together to warm them.
The water in the kettle warms quickly.

meanings.definition: to become warmer or to make someone or something warmer:
examples: The house soon warms up with the heating on.
I'll just warm up the engine while you're getting your coats on.

meanings.definition: to entertain people while they are waiting for a performance to start, for example by telling jokes:
examples: He's got a job warming up for TV studio audiences.
He was warming the audience up with his world-famous jokes.

meanings.definition: to heat food that has already been cooked:
examples: You can just warm up the leftovers from yesterday's meal in the microwave.

meanings.definition: If an event warms up, it starts to become more interesting, enjoyable, or exciting:
examples: The party was only just starting to warm up as I left.

meanings.definition: to prepare yourself for a physical activity by doing some gentle exercises and stretches:
examples: If you don't warm up before exercising, you risk injuring yourself.

meanings.definition: something that you do to prepare yourself for an activity, especially gentle exercises before a physical activity:
examples: A warm-up is important before a run so you don't strain any muscles.
Let's do a few warm-up exercises.
The coach doesn't like the players listening to music during warmups.

meanings.definition: to make something hotter:
examples: I can warm up the leftover soup for lunch.
We warmed the rolls up in the oven.

meanings.definition: to exercise or practice in order to prepare for something that takes a lot of effort:
examples: Ballet dancers have to warm up before performing.
A new pitcher is warming up in the bullpen.
She warms up her voice by singing scales.

meanings.definition: If you warm up a car, you let the engine get warm enough to work well.
to do some gentle exercises and stretches after you have done some intense physical activity, in order to allow your body to recover:
examples: It’s also important to warm down after exercise, by repeating the stretching and gentle cardiovascular exercise you did in your warm up.

meanings.definition: gentle exercises and stretches done after intense physical activity, in order to allow your body to recover:
examples: All of your runs should start with a warm-up and end with a warm-down.

meanings.definition: to use an idea that has been used before or to discuss a subject that has already been discussed before:
examples: Voters are bored with politicians warming over old policies.

meanings.definition: to start to like someone:
examples: I wasn't sure about Sarah at first, but I warmed to her after we'd been out together a few times.

meanings.definition: If you warm to an idea, you start to become interested in or enthusiastic about it:
examples: Unfortunately, I had to leave just as the speaker was warming to his theme.

meanings.definition: to begin to like or enjoy someone or something:
examples: She was not a person who was easy to warm up to.

meanings.definition: having a body temperature that stays the same and does not change with the temperature of the environment:
examples: Birds and mammals are warm-blooded.

meanings.definition: having a warm body temperature that stays the same
kind and loving:
examples: She's a good, warm-hearted woman.

meanings.definition: kind and affectionate:
examples: He was a warm-hearted man who helped me when I needed a friend.

meanings.definition: in a way that makes or keeps you warm:

meanings.definition: in a very friendly or approving way:

meanings.definition: in a way that protects you with clothes or covers that keep out the cold and make you feel comfortable:

meanings.definition: in a friendly and affectionate way:
examples: He shook my hand warmly.

meanings.definition: a politician or other leader who is often encouraging a country to go to war
the act of encouraging a country to go to war or of threatening violence against another country:
examples: The president was accused of warmongering.
Much of the world is still engaged in senseless warmongering.

meanings.definition: a high temperature that is comfortable but not hot:
examples: I've put a T-shirt on under my sweater for extra warmth.

meanings.definition: a friendly and enthusiastic quality in someone or something:
examples: I still remember the warmth of their welcome.

meanings.definition: a period of exercise or practice to prepare for something:
examples: He injured his knee during pregame warmups.
I bought an exercise video, but I never got further than the warmup exercises.

meanings.definition: to make someone realize a possible danger or problem, especially one in the future:
examples: We were warned not to eat the fish which might upset our stomachs.
Have you warned them (that) there will be an extra person for dinner?
I was warned against/off going to the east coast because it was so full of tourists.
The boating area is marked with buoys to warn off swimmers.
There were signs warning of fog as soon as we got onto the motorway.
This particular curry is extremely hot - be warned!
Put that ball down now, Laura - I'm warning you (= I will punish you if you do not)!

meanings.definition: to make someone aware of a possible danger or problem so that it can be avoided:
examples: I warned her not to waste her money on that movie.
We’d been warned that we should lock our cars in the parking lot.
The radio warned all day of the bad weather coming.

meanings.definition: to tell someone not to do something because of danger or some other reason:
examples: A series of flares had been placed along the pavement to warn off motorists.

meanings.definition:
past simple and past participle of 
        
         warn
to make someone realize a possible danger or problem, especially one in the future:
examples: We were warned not to eat the fish which might upset our stomachs.
Have you warned them (that) there will be an extra person for dinner?
I was warned against/off going to the east coast because it was so full of tourists.
The boating area is marked with buoys to warn off swimmers.
There were signs warning of fog as soon as we got onto the motorway.
This particular curry is extremely hot - be warned!
Put that ball down now, Laura - I'm warning you (= I will punish you if you do not)!

meanings.definition: something that makes you understand there is a possible danger or problem, especially one in the future:
examples: Completely without warning, he turned up at my door with all four children!

meanings.definition: notice of a possible danger or problem, so that it can be prevented or avoided:
examples: Flood warnings were issued by the National Weather Service.
The earthquake struck without warning while the city was asleep.

meanings.definition: a statement or piece of information that tells people that there might be a danger or a problem in the future:
examples: These figures are a warning to the Bank of England not to raise interest rates too quickly.
The telecoms giant issued a warning that profits would be lower than expected.
The Fed gave a blunt warning about America's growing deficit.
The chief executive gave warning that losses on credit cards would get worse in the second half of the year.
adequate/advance/early warning
a blunt/clear/stark warning
These figures come as a warning that the crisis is not over yet.

meanings.definition: a statement that tells an employee that they have done something wrong:
examples: Employees must be given a verbal and a written warning before they can be fired.
a final/formal/official warning

meanings.definition: used to show that there might be danger or a problem in the future:
examples: Regulators were accused of ignoring the warning signs that led to the bank's collapse.

meanings.definition: an early signal that something bad or dangerous might happen:
examples: You should know the warning signs of a stroke.

meanings.definition: an area just in front of the fence at the back of a baseball field where the grass has been removed in order to warn fielders (= players who try to catch or stop the ball) that they are close to the fence:
examples: The hitter sent the ball deep to the warning track in left field.
Rios caught the ball just in front of the warning track.

meanings.definition: in a way that is a warning to others:
examples: She called to me warningly, in case I had not seen the gun.
A dog growled warningly on the other side of the fence.

meanings.definition: If wood warps, or if water or heat warps it, it becomes damaged by bending or twisting:
examples: After being left in the damp garage, the wooden frame had warped.
The heat had warped the boards.

meanings.definition: to make a person or their behaviour strange, in an unpleasant or harmful way:
examples: Prison warps people. Had it warped Kelley enough that he would kill a stranger?

meanings.definition: (of a surface or hard material) to bend or twist so that the surface is no longer flat or straight:
examples: Water poured in, ruining carpets, warping walls, destroying wiring.

meanings.definition: to cause something or someone to no longer do what is usual or right:
examples: The novel is an appraisal of how totalitarianism can warp a society.

meanings.definition: an extremely high speed of change, development, or movement:
examples: Technology is advancing at warp speed.
At that point, his international career hit warp speed.

meanings.definition: a paint used by some tribal people to decorate the face and body before fighting
make-up
strange and unpleasant:
examples: I shouldn't really laugh about the accident - it's my warped sense of humour!
In their warped minds I was to blame for my own victimization.

meanings.definition: bent because of damage by heat or water:
examples: Have you noticed how warped these shelves are?

meanings.definition: to make a particular activity necessary:
examples: Obviously what she did was wrong, but I don't think it warranted such a severe punishment.
It's a relatively simple task that really doesn't warrant a great deal of time being spent on it.

meanings.definition: used to say that you are certain about something:
examples: He's to blame, I'll warrant (you).

meanings.definition: an official document, signed by a judge or other person in authority, that gives the police permission to search someone's home, arrest a person, or take some other action:
examples: a search warrant
Judge La Riva had issued an arrest warrant/a warrant for his arrest.

meanings.definition: a reason for doing something:
examples: There's no warrant for that sort of behaviour!

meanings.definition: to make a particular action necessary or correct, or to be a reason to do something:
examples: His injury was serious enough to warrant an operation.
I can see circumstances in which these types of investigations would be warranted.

meanings.definition: an official document approved by an authority, esp. a judge, which gives the police permission to do certain things:
examples: a search warrant
an arrest warrant

meanings.definition: the right to buy a company's shares at a particular price by a particular date:
examples: The company has the right to exercise warrants for the stock, up to a maximum of 5% of the total shares outstanding.

meanings.definition: a legal document that gives someone, for example, the police, the authority to do something:
examples: an arrest warrant

meanings.definition: to promise that something is true, or say that it is certain that something will happen:
examples: Our products are warranted against defects in materials and workmanship.

meanings.definition: a middle rank in the armed forces:
examples: Warrant Officer First Class

meanings.definition: If an action is warrantable, there is a good reason for it. :
examples: He had no warrantable grounds for using coercive measures to force the workers to do this.
I'm not sure it was warrantable to deny the permit just because they didn't use black ink when they filled out the request form.

meanings.definition: covered by a warranty (= a written promise from a company to repair or replace a product that breaks or does not work within a particular period of time after it is bought):
examples: The bike's chain was damaged in an accident, not in the course of regular use, so it is not warrantable.
This label must be attached to the warrantable product.

meanings.definition: in a way for which there is a good reason :
examples: The plaintiff could warrantably claim that he was endangered by the negligent actions of the defendant.
You might warrantably believe that any fruit that falls off someone's tree is free to take.

meanings.definition: If something is warranted, there is a good reason for it and it can be accepted:
examples: For a severe cough that lasts more than three weeks, a chest X-ray may be warranted to rule out pneumonia.

meanings.definition: having been given official authority to do something, or done with official permission:
examples: They proposed recruiting an extra 50 fully warranted officers to patrol railway stations.
A warranted search of the property found dogfighting training equipment, and more than 60 dogs.

meanings.definition: someone who is given a warranty by a company or another person

meanings.definition: a period of armed fighting between two countries:

meanings.definition: describing or including all the bad qualities in a person's character, with no attempt to hide them:

a county (= area with its own local government) in western central England:

meanings.definition: not completely trusting or certain about something or someone:

meanings.definition: to clean yourself, or a part of yourself, with water and usually soap:
examples: I'd like to wash before dinner.

meanings.definition: If water washes somewhere, it flows there, usually repeatedly:
examples: She stood on the shore and let the water wash over her tired feet.

meanings.definition: the action of washing something or a part of your body:
examples: Those curtains need a good (= careful) wash.
Erik needed a good wash after playing in the garden.

meanings.definition: a thin layer of water or paint mixed with water, especially one that is brushed lightly over a painting to make the lines softer:
examples: a blue wash/ a wash of blue
Just before the paint dries, I give it a light wash.

meanings.definition: an event or situation in which positive and negative things balance each other:
examples: If pollution controls are enforced here, the factories will move to where they're allowed to pollute, so it'll be a wash as far as clear air goes.

meanings.definition: (the sound made) when the sea moves against land, etc.:
examples: Outside the house, she could hear the gentle wash of the waves on the beach.

meanings.definition: used with adjectives and nouns to form verbs that refer to the actions of an organization, etc. that tries to make people believe that they are helping or protecting someone or something, when really they are not doing this or are doing something harmful:
examples: A business or organization is bluewashing when it makes misleading claims about how socially responsible its products or services are.
The Gay Pride organizers refused to let the event be pinkwashed by large corporations.

meanings.definition: to make something or yourself clean, or to become clean, using water and usually soap:
examples: Alex washed his face and combed his hair.
I hate washing dishes.

meanings.definition: (esp. of water) to flow or to cause to flow, often carrying something along:
examples: Waves washed against the boat.
Heavy rains always wash the sand down the hill.

meanings.definition: If something is washed away, it is carried off by heavy rain or a flood:
examples: Even trees and cars were washed away in this flood.

meanings.definition: If something washes up or washes ashore, water has moved it there:
examples: That storm washed a lot of crabs up on the shore.

meanings.definition: an event or situation in which positive and negative things balance each other:
examples: I sold my car for about what it cost me, so it was a wash.

meanings.definition: an act of washing, or clothing, sheets, and other cloth items being cleaned together:
examples: I went days without a wash or a change of clothes.

meanings.definition: If a colour or dirty mark washes out, or if you wash it out, it disappears when you wash it:
examples: Do you think these stains will wash out?

meanings.definition: If an event or sports competition is washed out, it is prevented from happening or stopped early because of heavy rain:
examples: The men's tennis semifinals were washed out this morning.

meanings.definition: to remove something by washing, or to disappear after washing:
examples: I hope this stain will wash out.

meanings.definition: (esp. of bad or violent weather) to cause something to fail, stop, or be destroyed:
examples: Rain washed tonight’s game out.

meanings.definition: to clean the plates, pans, and other things that you have used for cooking and eating:
examples: He washed up his mug and put it back on the shelf.

meanings.definition: to wash your hands, especially before a meal:
examples: Go wash up - your dinner's ready.

meanings.definition: a discussion after an event in which people talk about what happened, what could have been done better, etc.:
examples: The wash-up of his failed campaign will be done in the months to come.

meanings.definition: to clean your hands, esp. before a meal:

meanings.definition: to appear on land because the ocean or a river or lake left it there:

meanings.definition: If an excuse or argument won't wash with someone, they are unlikely to believe or accept it.
to come off the surface of something when water is used:

meanings.definition: to remove something with flowing water:

meanings.definition: a situation in which an investor sells shares, etc. then buys them back again almost immediately

the illegal situation when the buyer and seller of shares, etc. is the same person or organization. The buying and selling at the same time gives the impression that there is a lot of trading activity connected with the shares, and may increase their price:
examples: In a wash trade, no real change of ownership of the securities is involved.

meanings.definition: (of the sea) to carry something or someone to or away from a place:

meanings.definition: If water or rain washes something away, it removes it or carries it away:
examples: The blood on the pavement had been washed away by the rain overnight.

meanings.definition: to clean a large object or surface with a liquid:
examples: He washed the car down with soapy water.

meanings.definition: to eat food or swallow medicine with a drink that helps or improves it:
examples: Supper was fresh salmon and vegetables, washed down with a bottle of white wine.

meanings.definition: to clean something by causing water to flow over it:
examples: I took the hose and washed down the front porch.

meanings.definition: infml If you wash down food, you drink something after eating it:

meanings.definition: especially in the past, warmed beer or wine with spices added that is drunk at Christmas time, usually from a large bowl:

meanings.definition: in the past, an event around Christmas time that involved pouring wassail on the trees in an orchard (= an area of land where fruit trees are grown) in order to encourage the trees to produce a good crop the next year:
examples: The Leominster Morris men performed the age-old wassail ceremony in apple orchards at Aymestrey, Herefordshire.

meanings.definition: in a ceremony around Christmas in the past, to pour wassail on the trees in an orchard (= an area of land where fruit trees are grown) in order to encourage the trees to produce a good crop the next year:
examples: Here's to the old pagan tradition of wassailing the apple trees.

meanings.definition: especially in the past, to go from house to house at Christmas time singing carols (= Christmas songs), traditionally drinking wassail:
examples: By the 19th century bands of rowdy youths were a problem as they wassailed from house to house, demanding handouts from the gentry.

meanings.definition: especially in the past, a person who takes part in the activity of going from house to house at Christmas time singing carols (= Christmas songs), traditionally drinking wassail (= warm beer or wine with spices added):

meanings.definition: a person who took part in a ceremony at Christmas time in the past when wassail (= warm beer or wine with spices added)was poured on the trees in an orchard (= an area of land where fruit trees are grown) in order to encourage the trees to produce a good crop the next year:

meanings.definition: especially in the past, the activity of going from house to house at Christmas time singing carols (= Christmas songs), traditionally drinking wassail (= warm beer or wine with spices added):

meanings.definition: in a ceremony at Christmas time in the past, the activity of pouring wassail (= warm beer or wine with spices added) on the trees in an orchard (= an area of land where fruit trees are grown) in order to encourage the trees to produce a good crop the next year:
examples: Wassailing dates from the Middle Ages, when it was thought to ensure that the trees in the orchards would be awake and ready to bear a good harvest in the autumn.

meanings.definition:
→ 
        
         natural wastage
an unnecessary or wrong use of money, substances, time, energy, abilities, etc.:
examples: That meeting achieved absolutely nothing - it was a complete waste of time.
She's been unemployed for two years and it's such a waste of her talents.
My mother couldn't stand waste - she always made us eat everything on our plates.

meanings.definition: unwanted matter or material of any type, especially what is left after useful substances or parts have been removed:
examples: This city produces 20 million tons of household waste each year.
He opposes any kind of nuclear waste being dumped at sea.
Millions of gallons of untreated human waste (= excrement) flow into the river every day.
Oil spills are common, as is the dumping of toxic industrial wastes.
The Japanese recycle more than half of their waste paper.

meanings.definition: to use too much of something or use something badly when there is a limited amount of it:
examples: You waste a lot of water by taking a bath instead of a shower.
Come on, let's get started - we've wasted enough time already.
Don't waste your money on such junk.

meanings.definition: to kill someone
a bad use of something valuable that you have only a limited amount of:
examples: a waste of time/money
a waste of talent/ability
I felt like being there was just a waste.

meanings.definition: unwanted matter or material of any type, esp. what is left after use:
examples: hazardous/toxic wastes
Most people don’t recycle kitchen waste.

meanings.definition: Human waste is excrement.
Waste disposal is the process or system for getting rid of unwanted material by burying it, burning it, or dropping it in the sea.
to use something without care or thought:
examples: Why should I waste my time on her?
You’re just wasting your money buying that stuff.

meanings.definition: an unnecessary or careless use of resources or skills:
examples: The meeting was a complete waste of time.
All departments have been instructed to avoid waste.

meanings.definition: materials or substances with no use or value, for example, ones that are produced when other products are being made:
examples: the disposal of waste
The company was charged with illegally disposing of toxic waste.
household/industrial waste

meanings.definition: left after what is valuable has been used, and no longer needed:
examples: the collection and recycling of waste materials

meanings.definition: to use more money, time, resources, etc. than is needed:
examples: The board decided it could not waste any more time and money developing the product.

meanings.definition: to not use something in an effective way:
examples: Oftel had the chance to create real competition to BT but it has wasted the opportunity.
wasted skills/talent

meanings.definition: to not make good use of the hours, etc. that you have available:
examples: If you'd done your work instead of wasting time on your phone, you'd be finished by now.
I try not to waste time worrying about things that I have no control over.
Don't waste your time dwelling on the past.
She wasted so much time searching for the perfect outfit when she already owned it.
We need to get started - we've wasted too much time already.
I'm not going to waste my time arguing with these people - they're never going to listen anyway.

meanings.definition: to gradually get thinner and weaker, in a way that is unhealthy:
examples: You get thinner every time I see you, Sara - you're wasting away!

meanings.definition: (of a person or animal) to gradually get thinner and weaker, esp. from disease or lack of food:
examples: It was hard to watch her waste away.

meanings.definition: a container that is used for putting rubbish in:
examples: He threw the draft into a waste bin and set upon writing a new novel.
She put the remains of the fish in a public wastebin a few yards down the road.
She sat with the magazine in her hands, and then dropped it into the waste-bin.

meanings.definition: an electrical machine, connected to a kitchen sink, that cuts up food waste so that it will flow easily through the pipes
an area of ground in or near a city that is not built on or used in any way:
examples: His body had been dumped in an area of waste ground just outside the city.
The kids were playing on a patch of waste ground.
They build a beautiful garden on what had previously been waste ground.
Workers played football at lunch time on a piece of waste ground behind the factory.
We crossed a stretch of waste ground on the outskirts of the town.

meanings.definition: to start doing something immediately:
examples: Caroline wasted no time in tackling her new responsibilities.

meanings.definition: to immediately begin an activity:
examples: Caroline wasted no time in tackling her new responsibilities.

meanings.definition: said to advise someone not to waste anything, because they might need it in the future
a person or thing that is not useful or helpful:
examples: That man is a total waste of space.

meanings.definition: paper that has been used, is no longer wanted, and has been thrown away:
examples: The grass had been trampled into mud, and was strewn with waste paper.
a waste paper recycling plant
He has a business transporting recyclable wastepaper.

meanings.definition: someone who looks through rubbish to find things they can use or sell:
examples: The picture shows a female waste picker at a landfill site in Kathmandu.
Waste pickers are the “invisible heroes” of the country's recycling industry.

meanings.definition: a device like a long stick with two parts on the end that can be opened and pressed together using a handle at the top of the stick, in order to pick up small pieces of rubbish from the ground:
examples: Always carry this useful foldable waste picker with you when walking the dog.

meanings.definition: a substance of no value or use that is made during a process in which something useful is produced:
examples: Cadmium is a toxic waste product of the electronics industry.

meanings.definition: a material or substance with no use or value that is produced when products are being made:
examples: The site offers advice on the responsible disposal of IT waste products.
break down/recycle/remove waste products
biodegradable/hazardous/toxic waste products

meanings.definition: water that is not clean because it has already been used in homes, businesses, factories, etc.:
examples: These new eco-friendly homes recycle waste water in toilet cisterns.

meanings.definition: If you waste your breath, you spend time and energy trying to give advice that is ignored:
examples: Honestly, you're wasting your breath - he doesn't want to hear what anyone else has got to say.

meanings.definition: to say something that will likely be ignored:
examples: Don’t waste your breath arguing with him.

meanings.definition: an open container that stands on the floor inside buildings and is used for putting rubbishin, especially paper
a container to hold paper or other small things you want to get rid of
Wasted time, money, etc. is time, money, etc. that is not used effectively because it does not produce the result you wanted:
examples: He wasn't in when I got there, so it was a completely wasted journey.

meanings.definition: very thin and weak as a result of being ill or having no food:
examples: Underneath the hospital blankets I could see the outline of her poor wasted body.

meanings.definition: very drunk or illfrom drugs:
examples: He was too wasted to drive.
Paula was completely wasted after only one drink.

meanings.definition: If you say that something is wasted on someone, you mean that its quality is too high for that person and they will not understand its true value:
examples: I'm not going to serve that good coffee to Chris and Melanie - it would be wasted on them.

meanings.definition: to not be appreciated by someone:
examples: Your excellent cooking will be wasted on them.

meanings.definition: using something in a careless way and causing some of it to be wasted:
examples: It's wasteful the way you throw so much food away!

meanings.definition: being a bad use of something valuable that you have only a limited amount of:
examples: wasteful spending
a wasteful use of resources

meanings.definition: not being careful about the amount of resources used for something:
examples: Top business advisers have been brought in to identify areas of wasteful government spending.

meanings.definition: in a way that uses more of something than is necessary:
examples: The project is wastefully expensive.
Why are we using energy so wastefully?

meanings.definition: an empty area of land, especially in or near a city, that is not used to grow crops or built on, or used in any way:
examples: The car was dumped in a stretch of wasteland in the south of the city.

meanings.definition: a place, time, or situation that does not contain or produce anything positive, or that is completely without a particular quality or activity:
examples: the spiritual wasteland of the 1980s

meanings.definition: a large area of land that has not been developed, usually because it cannot be easily used:
examples: Rain forests are being transformed into barren wasteland.

meanings.definition: A wasteland can also be anything that seems to lack positive qualities:
examples: Television is a vast wasteland.

meanings.definition: a stupid person or someone who is behaving in a stupid way:
examples: He turned out to be a complete wasteman.
You had your chance and you blew it, you wasteman.

meanings.definition: an open container that stands on the floor inside buildings and is used for putting rubbish in, especially paper:
examples: Most of the letters they receive end up in the wastepaper basket.
She tossed the envelope into the wastepaper bin.

meanings.definition: a person or thing who wastes something:
examples: He's a time waster.
This project is nothing but a money waster.

meanings.definition: a person who does nothing positive with their life, making no use of their abilities or the opportunities that are offered to them:
examples: There were the usual bunch of wasters hanging round the bar.

meanings.definition: large areas of land that are not used to grow crops and have few living animals or plants:
examples: the Arctic wastes of northern Siberia
They journeyed through the rocky wastes of Afghanistan.
They spent several months in the snowy wastes of Antarctica.
They were battered by sandstorms in the desert wastes.
He first encountered the Tuareg people in the wastes of the Sahara.

meanings.definition: water that is not clean because it has already been used in homes, businesses, factories, etc.:
examples: The facility pumped fuel for 101 days before the wastewater pipe leak was detected.

meanings.definition:
present participle of 
        
         waste
to use too much of something or use something badly when there is a limited amount of it:
examples: You waste a lot of water by taking a bath instead of a shower.
Come on, let's get started - we've wasted enough time already.
Don't waste your money on such junk.

meanings.definition: to kill someone
an asset, such as an investment or a piece of equipment, that will continue to lose value over time:
examples: Property leases with less than 50 years to run are seen as wasting assets.

meanings.definition: a disease that causes a person to gradually become very thin and weak:
examples: She suffers from a little-known muscle-wasting disease.

meanings.definition: a person who does nothing positive with their life, making no use of their abilities or the opportunities that are offered to them
in Southeast Asia, a Buddhist temple (= a place of worship) or monastery (= a building in which monks live and worship):
examples: Prabang, the historic royal city, embodies the Buddhist spirit with its 32 wats and hundreds of monks.

meanings.definition: to look at something for a period of time, especially something that is changing or moving:
examples: I had dinner and watched TV for a couple of hours.
He spent the entire afternoon watching a cricket match.
I watched him get into a cab.
I got the feeling I was being watched.
I sit by the window and watch people walking past.
Just watch how he slides that ball in past the goalkeeper.
Bonner watched helplessly as they drove away without him.
She'll pretend that she hasn't seen us - you watch.

meanings.definition: to stay with someone or something, such as a child, for a short time to make certain that he, she, or it is safe:
examples: If you want me to watch the kids for a couple of hours while you go out, just let me know.
Could you watch my bags for me, while I go to the toilet?

meanings.definition: to be careful of something:
examples: I have to watch my weight (= be careful not to become too heavy) now I'm not exercising so much.
Watch your language (= do not use rude words), young man!
Watch (that) you don't get glue on your fingers.
Watch what you're doing with that knife, Jim, it's sharp.
You need to watch him - he's a strange character.

meanings.definition: a small clock that is worn on a strap around the wrist or, sometimes, connected to a piece of clothing by a chain:
examples: My watch seems to have stopped (= stopped working).
He glanced nervously at his watch.

meanings.definition: the activity of watching or giving attention to something or someone, especially to make certain nothing bad happens:
examples: The police keep a close watch on gang members.
The soldiers slept at night, except for one who stayed awake on watch/to keep watch.

meanings.definition: a person or group of soldiers or guards whose duty is to protect a person, place, or thing from danger or attack
a particular period of time during which a person or a group of soldiers or guards has the duty of protecting and warning of danger:
examples: the night watch

meanings.definition: a small clock usually worn on a strap around the wrist, or sometimes carried in a pocket:
examples: She looked at her watch and said, "It’s a quarter to five."

meanings.definition: an act of guarding someone or something to make sure the person or property stays safe and in the right place:
examples: The prison guards kept a close watch on him.

meanings.definition: Watch is also a period during which someone is responsible for guarding or looking around to be sure that property or people are safe, or the person who is responsible:
examples: The soldiers on the night watch had to be careful not to fall asleep.

meanings.definition: to look at something for a period of time:
examples: He spent the evening watching an old movie on TV.
The police were watching to see who left the house.
Do you want me to watch the kids (= notice what they are doing and care for them) when you go out?

meanings.definition: to be careful of something:
examples: We have to watch our bank account to make sure there’s enough money in it to pay our credit card bills.
I’ve got to start watching my weight (= be careful not to become fat).
The sign says "Watch for (= be careful of) falling rocks."

meanings.definition: used to tell someone to be careful:
examples: Watch it - you nearly knocked my head off with that plank!

meanings.definition: a list of people or things that must be watched closely, for example because they might be dangerous or in danger, or because you want to see what happens to them:
examples: They were searching for two men on the government's terrorist watch list who they knew had entered the United States.
These birds are on the Audubon Society's watchlist for species facing threats like loss of habitat.
Start a watch list of companies that you might want to invest in.

meanings.definition: a list of companies, investments, etc. whose activity is being closely followed, for example because there may be problems in the future:
examples: The fund appears on a watch list of investments.
place/put sth on a watch list

meanings.definition: a list of companies, people, etc. whose activity is being closely examined to check that they are not doing something illegal:
examples: A passenger was ordered off the flight because his name appeared on the FBI's watch list.

meanings.definition: to be careful to notice someone or something interesting:
examples: Watch out for his latest movie, out next month.

meanings.definition: to protect someone and make certain that they are safe:
examples: The prince has two bodyguards watching over him every hour of the day.

meanings.definition: to protect someone and make certain that that person is safe:
examples: She had to watch over four young children and take care of a sick husband.

meanings.definition: used to refer to an activity that you consider extremely boring:
examples: "Don't you want to watch the football?" "To be honest, I would rather watch paint dry."

meanings.definition: an occasion when people watch a broadcast event together, for example a sports game or the results of an election, often in a public place:
examples: She said that people who attended watch parties learned as much, if not more, from conversations with other people than from the show itself.
A friend of mine is organizing American-style debate watching parties at local pubs in Liverpool.

meanings.definition: an occasion when people in different places watch a television show, video, etc. at the same time and discuss it using the internet:
examples: To host a virtual watch party you first need to queue up the video you want to play and start a Zoom meeting.
There follows a list of all the streaming services and apps that let you host virtual watch parties.

meanings.definition: to watch someone all the time, usually to make sure they do not do something bad:
examples: When I was at home, mum and dad watched me like a hawk.
It's putting me off, having you watching me like a hawk all the time.

meanings.definition: to pay very close attention to something, usually to make sure nothing bad or unexpected happens:
examples: I watch my online account like a hawk.
The medical supply business is highly competitive and he needs to watch costs like a hawk.
You have to watch the pan like a hawk to make sure it doesn't burn.

meanings.definition: to be ready to protect or defend someone:
examples: On the trip, Tom watched my back in a lot of ways, and I watched his back.
She thanked all her colleagues throughout her career, who she said had always watched her back.

meanings.definition: to be careful of the people around you, making certain that they do nothing to harm you:
examples: I have to watch my back at work - there are a lot of people who would like my job.

meanings.definition: to often notice the time and wish that it was later, especially when you are doing work that you do not like
to look at people as they go past:
examples: I love sitting in the park watching the world go by.

meanings.definition: used to say that there will very soon be an exciting change in the situation.
be careful about how you behave, or you will get into trouble:
examples: He'll have to watch his step if he wants to keep that job of his!

meanings.definition: to be careful about how you behave:
examples: He’ll have to watch his step if he wants to keep his job.

meanings.definition: A television programme or film that is watchable is entertaining:
examples: It's not the best series I've ever seen but it's very watchable.

meanings.definition: a strip of leather or other material or a metal chain that fastens a watch onto your wrist
a person or organization responsible for making certain that companies obey particular standards and do not act illegally:
examples: The Countryside Commission was set up as the government's official watchdog on conservation.

meanings.definition:
a 
        
         guard dog
a person or organization responsible for making certain that companies or other organizations maintain standards and do not act illegally:
examples: a watchdog agency/organization

meanings.definition: a dog trained to protect a place
an official organization that is responsible for checking that companies obey particular rules and laws so that the standard of the products or services they provide is acceptable:
examples: The government created an independent watchdog to monitor the rising overseas aid budget.
a competition/market watchdog
a pollution/safety watchdog
a watchdog agency/group/organization

meanings.definition:
past simple and past participle of 
        
         watch
to look at something for a period of time, especially something that is changing or moving:
examples: I had dinner and watched TV for a couple of hours.
He spent the entire afternoon watching a cricket match.
I watched him get into a cab.
I got the feeling I was being watched.
I sit by the window and watch people walking past.
Just watch how he slides that ball in past the goalkeeper.
Bonner watched helplessly as they drove away without him.
She'll pretend that she hasn't seen us - you watch.

meanings.definition: to stay with someone or something, such as a child, for a short time to make certain that he, she, or it is safe:
examples: If you want me to watch the kids for a couple of hours while you go out, just let me know.
Could you watch my bags for me, while I go to the toilet?

meanings.definition: to be careful of something:
examples: I have to watch my weight (= be careful not to become too heavy) now I'm not exercising so much.
Watch your language (= do not use rude words), young man!
Watch (that) you don't get glue on your fingers.
Watch what you're doing with that knife, Jim, it's sharp.
You need to watch him - he's a strange character.

meanings.definition: a person who watches television or films:
examples: The streaming service is great for the movie watcher.

meanings.definition: used with nouns to describe a person who is interested in and enjoys watching a particular thing:
examples: Royal-watchers have once again been speculating on the health of the princess.

meanings.definition: someone who is interested in the developments and changes of a particular thing:
examples: But the real growth, industry watchers say, will come in the corporate and personal jet sector.

meanings.definition: paying careful attention and ready to deal with problems:
examples: Under the watchful eye of their mother, the two boys played on the beach.
She keeps a watchful eye on her boyfriend.

meanings.definition: giving careful attention so as to notice what is happening and be prepared for something that might happen:
examples: If you invest heavily in the stock market, you have to stay watchful and be ready to move your money quickly.

meanings.definition: a way of treating a medical condition that involves a period of waiting and watching for further symptoms (= signs of disease) to develop, rather than immediate treatment such as surgery or chemotherapy:
examples: More men with low-risk prostate cancer are now opting for watchful waiting rather than undergoing surgery.

meanings.definition: in a watchful way (= paying careful attention):
examples: Slowly and watchfully they walked around the perimeter of the clearing.
They noticed a pale-faced girl and a boy standing watchfully at her side.

meanings.definition: the quality or state of being watchful (= paying careful attention):
examples: There was a certain watchfulness over unattended luggage at railway stations.
Although bread-making seems a simple process, it requires delicate care and watchfulness.

meanings.definition:

         watch

examples: I had dinner and watched TV for a couple of hours.
He spent the entire afternoon watching a cricket match.

I sit by the window and watch people walking past.

Watch your language (= do not use rude words), young man!
Watch (that) you don't get glue on your fingers.
Watch what you're doing with that knife, Jim, it's sharp.
You need to watch him - he's a strange character.

meanings.definition: if someone has or is given a watching brief on something, someone has asked them to check on and give a report about what is happening in a particular situation or in a particular business, etc.:
examples: Potential investors are keeping a watching brief on the fund.

meanings.definition: a person or company that makes or repairs watches:
examples: As her father and grandfather had done, she too became a watchmaker - the first woman in Haarlem to achieve that degree of skill.
Patek Philippe is one of the Big Three historical watchmakers, with a celebrity customer list.

meanings.definition: the job, business, or skill of making and repairing watches:
examples: Switzerland is often called the home of watchmaking.
As a young man, he took a course in watchmaking.

meanings.definition: a person who is employed to guard a building or several buildings
a strip of leather or other material or a metal chain that fastens a watch onto your wrist
a tower built especially around the edges of prisons and army camps, the top of which provides a good position from which to see anyone who is coming close
(a word or phrase that represents) the main ideas or principles directing the way that someone behaves or the way that something is done:
examples: And remember, let caution be your watchword.

meanings.definition: a clear liquid, without colour or taste, that falls from the sky as rain and is necessary for animal and plant life:
examples: a bottle/drink/glass of water
bottled/mineral/tap water
hot/cold water
Can I have a drop of water in my whisky, please?
Is there enough hot water for a bath?
The human body is about 50 percent water.

meanings.definition: an area of water, such as the sea, a lake, or a swimming pool:
examples: The water's warm - are you coming in?
I don't like getting my head under (= in) water.
Dad, I swam a whole length of the pool under water (= with the whole head and body below the surface of the water)!

meanings.definition: the level of an area of water:
examples: The river is difficult to cross during periods of high water.

meanings.definition: a way of referring to urine (= yellowish liquid waste from the body):
examples: Is there any pain when you pass water?
If your water is dark, it may mean you are dehydrated.

meanings.definition: to pour water on to plants or the soil that they are growing in:
examples: I've asked my neighbour to water the plants while I'm away.

meanings.definition: to give an animal water to drink:
examples: The horses had been fed and watered.

meanings.definition: If your mouth waters, it produces a lot of saliva, usually because you can see or smell some food that you would like to eat:
examples: The smell of that bread is making my mouth water!

meanings.definition: When your eyes water, they produce tears but not because you are unhappy:
examples: How do you stop your eyes from watering when you're cutting up onions?

meanings.definition: used to form adjectives:
examples: freshwater fish
a saltwater lagoon

meanings.definition: a clear, colorless liquid that falls from the sky as rain and is necessary for animal and plant life:
examples: a drink/glass of water
bottled/tap water
cold/hot water
I’m boiling water to make some more coffee.

meanings.definition: The water often refers to an area of water, such as the sea or a lake:
examples: The water’s much warmer today – are you coming for a swim?

meanings.definition: Waters is an area of natural water, such as a part of the sea:
examples: coastal waters

meanings.definition: to provide water to a plant or animal:
examples: I’ve asked my neighbor to water the plants while I’m away.

meanings.definition: When your eyes water, they produce tears but not because you are unhappy:
examples: The icy wind made his eyes water.

meanings.definition: If your mouth waters, it produces a lot of saliva, usually because you can see or smell food that you would like to eat:
examples: The smell of that bread is making my mouth water.

meanings.definition: a sport in which a group of people make smooth, attractive movements like dancing in the water at the same time:
examples: She taught water ballet and lifesaving techniques.
Good swimmers can also participate in other sports such as water polo and water ballet.

meanings.definition:
another word for a 
        
         tardigrade
a regular charge that is made to people for the use of their local water supply
any bird that lives near or on water
any kind of waterfowl
a thin, hard biscuit, often eaten with cheese
a container for carrying drinking water
a bottle of water
a person whose job is to give drinking water to sports players, especially in an American football team:
examples: His first job in professional football was water boy for the team.
He claimed he was a football star, but he was nothing but a waterboy.

meanings.definition: a large Asian animal like a cow with horns that curve backwards, often used for pulling farming tools
a large container for collecting rain that can then be used to water plants
a device that sends out a powerful stream of water and is used in order to make large groups of people move away:
examples: Police used water cannons to break up the demonstration.

meanings.definition: a firm, white, round underground part of a plant like grass, used especially in East Asian cooking:
examples: She sliced some water chestnuts and added them to the pak choi and beansprouts.
My grandmother makes a delicious water chestnut soup with pork and carrots.

meanings.definition: in the past, a type of clock that used flowing water to measure time:
examples: The water clock measured time as a result of the force of water falling through it at a constant rate.
The most accurate timekeeping devices of the ancient world were the waterclock or clepsydra, first found in Egypt.

meanings.definition: full form of WC: a toilet, or a room containing a toilet
a vertical section of water from the surface to the bottom of the sea, a lake, a river, etc.:
examples: The water column is a way of describing the different features found in seawater at different depths.

meanings.definition: a machine for cooling and providing drinking water, usually in an office or other public place
a machine that supplies cool water for drinking, usually in an office or other public place:
examples: You can add almost a quarter of a mile to your daily walking schedule simply going from desk to water cooler.

meanings.definition: used to describe something that many people talk about at work, for example when they stop work to drink something:
examples: The company raked in $260 million in profit, and fueled countless water-cooler conversations.
The shocking interview provided one of those water cooler moments that everyone was talking about the next day.

meanings.definition: a fountain or a small area of water in a garden or park
a device for removing unwanted substances such as bacteria or harmful chemicals from drinking water

an electrical device that produces a stream of water under pressure, that you use in your mouth to remove pieces of food or plaque (= a substance containing bacteria that forms on teeth) from around and between your teeth :
examples: A water flosser can clean the spaces that brushing misses.
Some people use string floss first, to scrape and loosen plaque, followed by a water flosser to rinse out any residue.

meanings.definition: a device, usually in a public place, that supplies water for drinking
a device in a public place that allows anyone to drink water without a cup by pushing a button and drinking from a stream of water that comes out
a floating water plant from South America that has large pink flowers and that grows very fast and can cause serious problems in areas where it does not grow naturally:
examples: Some lakes in the area are infested with water hyacinth.
Brazilian water hyacinths are clogging the waterways of Uganda.

meanings.definition:
old-fashioned for
        
         sorbet
an area of water with a fence before it, designed for people or horses to jump over in a competition
a plant whose large, flat leaves and cup-shaped petals float on the surface of lakes and pools
the main underground pipe in a system of pipes supplying water to an area
a large underground pipe that supplies water to buildings in an area of a city or town
a field that floods with water from a river when there is a lot of rain
(of a building development, business, etc.) not using more water than was used in an area before it was built or established, or not removing more water than it replaces :
examples: Going water neutral means that the water footprint of all activities are reduced as far as is practicably possible.
The 160,000 new homes that are planned for south-east England need to be "water neutral" to be sustainable.

meanings.definition: the fact of a building development, business, etc. not using more water than was used in an area before it was built or established, or not removing more water than it replaces:
examples: Water neutrality can be achieved by developers building significant water efficiency measures into new developments.
The company pledged to "water neutrality" by using no more water than it replaces.

meanings.definition: a condition in which there is too much liquid around the knee joint:
