meanings.definition: (of the moon) to gradually appear larger and increasingly round:
examples: fig. Such controversies have waxed and waned (= become stronger and weaker) but continue to this day.

meanings.definition: to become:
examples: Brad waxed eloquent on the subject of free enterprise.

meanings.definition: to put a thin layer of wax on the surface of something:
examples: I just waxed the floor, so don’t go in there yet.

meanings.definition: to grow stronger and then weaker again:
examples: His commitment to democracy and free markets has waxed and waned with his political fortunes.

meanings.definition: a type of green bean with a yellow case that can be eaten:
examples: Wax beans are basically the same as green beans or French beans, but don't have any chlorophyll in them so have a yellowish colour.
It's always possible to substitute wax beans for green beans in a recipe.

meanings.definition: to talk about something with a lot of interest or excitement:
examples: I recall Rosie waxing lyrical about her Italian holiday.
I was fed up with listening to her wax lyrical about the joys of motherhood.
Marcus has been waxing lyrical about his new sound system.
Everyone waxes lyrical about the scenery here.
We listened to them wax lyrical about their days in the army.

meanings.definition: to speak or write in the stated way:
examples: My mother always used to wax lyrical about the lemon trees in her family's garden.
Given his past statements, I'm amazed he can wax so indignant about these reports.
He wasn't able to wax enthusiastic about her most recent book choice.
She tends to wax philosophical about nature.
We spent the evening waxing nostalgic about our schooldays.
The critic waxed poetic about her latest work.

meanings.definition: a shaped piece of wax that contains a pleasant-smelling substance and that is put in a special device and heated so that it melts and releases the smell:
examples: Each of these square wax melts provides up to 12 hours of fabulous fragrance.
a wax melt burner/warmer

meanings.definition: a place where there are a lot of wax models of famous people for the public to look at:
examples: One of London's biggest tourist attractions, Madame Tussaud's, is the oldest and largest wax museum in the world.
Super Mario is the first video game character to be honoured with a wax figure in the legendary Hollywood Wax Museum.

meanings.definition: a bush or small tree that is usually evergreen (= it does not usually lose its leaves) and that has small fruit covered in a substance like wax:
examples: Volunteers will replant the site with native plants including California buckeye, wax myrtle, toyon, willow, and grasses.
Three wax myrtles were planted to catch any runoff from the balcony.

meanings.definition:
→ 
        
         waxed paper
paper that has a thin layer of wax on it and is used for wrapping food
cotton material with wax added to it that is used to cover and protect food, or a piece of this material:
examples: Our vegan wax wrap is a vegan alternative to our handmade beeswax wraps.
Wax wraps are washable, and can be reused many times.
Wax wrap is used as an eco-friendly alternative to cling film .

meanings.definition: covered with a thin layer of wax, either to make something waterproof, or to improve its appearance :
examples: a waxed jacket
waxed cotton thread

meanings.definition: If part of your body is waxed, it has had the hair removed by covering it in a thin layer of wax that is then pulled off:
examples: Her designer luggage was heaped around her freshly waxed legs.
Waxed skin is prone to sunburn if it's not protected with sunscreen.

meanings.definition: a type of paper that has a thin layer of wax on it and is used for wrapping food
A waxen face has pale, shiny skin and does not look healthy:
examples: a waxen complexion

meanings.definition: someone who surfs on waves
a beauty treatment in which hair is removed from someone's body by covering it in a thin layer of warm wax that is then pulled off:
examples: We offer manicures, facials, and waxing.

meanings.definition: a wax model of a person
a a wax museum (= a place where there are a lot of wax models of famous people for the public to look at):
examples: People flocked to the waxworks to see the latest models of the royal family.
The waxworks were bought up by an international entertainment group.
She worked at the waxworks for more than a decade.
They parked their car across the street from the waxworks.
We visited Madame Tussauds, the famous waxworks in London.

meanings.definition: slightly shiny; looking like wax
having the appearance of or feeling like wax:
examples: He had a waxy complexion and looked ill.

meanings.definition: a route, direction, or path:
examples: Do you know the way to the restaurant?
I've only been living in Madrid for a couple of weeks so I don't really know my way around it yet.
We'll have to stop for petrol on the way to the airport.
Can you find your own way out of the building?
He elbowed/pushed his way (= hit/pushed people so that he could go past them) to the front of the crowd.
The bus stopped for us to eat lunch but within half an hour we were on our way/under way (= travelling) again.
There's no way through here - you'll have to go round.
They flew from Los Angeles to Toronto by way of Chicago.
Many people have lost their way (= become lost) in the forest.
Only local people could find their way through the maze of narrow streets.

meanings.definition: used to talk about the direction in which something is facing:
examples: "Which way does the room face?" "North."
Which way up should this box be? (= Which side should be on top?)
The numbers are the wrong way round - it should be 71, not 17.

meanings.definition: a distance or a period of time:
examples: We walked a long way yesterday.
The holiday seems like it's a long way off.
We managed to pull ourselves all the way from 12th place to first place.
They still have a ways to go.

meanings.definition: a particular choice, opinion, belief, or action, especially from among several possibilities:
examples: I like the way you've done your hair.
In some/many ways it would be better if we met on Monday rather than Wednesday.
In a way (= partly), I would rather they didn't come because it will mean extra work.
He might have to resign or he might be demoted, but either way, his career is effectively over.
They don't write songs the way (= as) they used to.

meanings.definition: the manner in which someone behaves or thinks, or in which something happens:
examples: Don't worry - it's just his way.
He looked at me in a sinister way.
It's amazing the way she manages to stay so calm.
The way he was shouting, you'd have thought he was badly hurt.
To my way of thinking, they shouldn't be building so many roads.
It's always the way at work - either I have nothing to do or I'm rushed off my feet!

meanings.definition: an action that can produce the result you want; a method:
examples: There are many ways of solving the problem.
That's not the way to do it - let me show you.
That method hasn't worked, so let's try your way.

meanings.definition: the space needed for a particular movement or action:
examples: "Sorry, am I in your way? I'll move."
I couldn't see the stage because there was a pillar in the way (= between me and the stage).
Make way for some new clothes by clearing out ones you never wear.
You need to get out of the way of that car.
She's determined to succeed and she won't let anything get/stand in her way (= prevent her).

meanings.definition: If someone gets or has their way, what they want happens:
examples: If she doesn't get/have her (own) way, she sulks like a four-year-old.

meanings.definition: the bad condition or state of someone or something, especially the state of a person's health:
examples: He's been in a bad way (= very ill) ever since the operation.

meanings.definition: used to emphasize degree or separation, especially in space or time:
examples: After the third lap, she was way behind the other runners.
She spends way too much money on clothes.

meanings.definition: in the direction of:
examples: I think they live Birmingham way.

meanings.definition: a route or path to follow in order to get to a place:
examples: Do you know the way to the train station?

meanings.definition: If you don’t know your way, can’t find your way, or have lost your way, you are not sure or do not know how to get where you want to go:
examples: I don’t really know my way around town yet.

meanings.definition: Way also means street:
examples: Our office is at 17 Harbor Way.

meanings.definition: Way can mean the direction, position, or order of something:
examples: The numbers should be the other way around – 71, not 17.

meanings.definition: Your way can also be the progress of your life:
examples: He made his way from sales assistant to head of sales.

meanings.definition: distance, or a period of time:
examples: We walked just a short way before he got tired.
When Mom called us for supper, we were still a ways from being finished.

meanings.definition: a particular manner, characteristic, or fashion:
examples: I like the way your hair is fixed.
Jack and Beth feel the same way about animals.
There is no way I can leave her.
They don’t write songs the way they used to.

meanings.definition: Your way is also the ability to do things in the manner you want:
examples: My little sister gets furious if she doesn’t get her way.

meanings.definition: (used for emphasis) far or long:
examples: That skirt’s way too much money.
Come on now, Alexander, it’s way past your bedtime.

meanings.definition: slang Way can also mean very:
examples: That car is way cool!

meanings.definition: a route back to where you have come from, or to a situation that existed before:
examples: I got lost in the woods and couldn't find the way back.
We were delayed on the way back to the airport.
I'll see you soon. I'm on my way back now.
People are searching for a way back to peace negotiations.
The charity offers people coming out of prison a way back into society.
He felt that he had retired too early, and was looking for ways back into regular work.
With only five minutes of the game remaining, there was no way back for the home side (= they could not hope to win the game).

meanings.definition: a long time, or a long time ago:
examples: The issue actually goes way back - to the early 1970s in fact.
The two of us go way back (= we have known each other for a long time).
The company was established way back in 1988.
This information has been in the public domain since way back when (= for a long time).
It happened way back when I was at college.

meanings.definition: the manner in which a person lives:
examples: Sleeping in doorways, begging for food and money - it's not an enviable way of life.
She loved travel, meeting people from other cultures and finding out about their way of life.

meanings.definition: the manner in which a person or society usually lives:
examples: Sleeping in hotels three or four nights a week is not an ideal way of life.

meanings.definition: a way of dealing with or avoiding a problem:
examples: There's no way round this problem.

meanings.definition: a place where people can stop when travelling from one place to another
used to tell someone they have done well, or used humorously when someone has done something stupid:
examples: I heard you girls won the contest. Way to go!
Way to go, John - you broke the chair!

meanings.definition: unusual, especially because very modern in style:
examples: A lot of experimental theatre is too way-out for me.

meanings.definition: If a person tries to discover which way the wind blows/is blowing, they try to discover information about a situation, especially other people's opinions, before they take action:
examples: I think I'll see which way the wind is blowing before I vote at the board meeting.

meanings.definition: the brand name for software that allows you to search internet archives (= old documents, websites, etc.):
examples: Unfortunately, all of the links involved are now not only dead, but they are not even in the Internet Wayback Machine.
The wayback machine at archive.org shows virtually no history, which is odd if your blog was as popular as you claim.

meanings.definition: a way of seeming to go back in time to the past:
examples: I had to jump into the wayback machine and remember my outdated geek lingo.
It's as if they've set the Wayback Machine back to the 1970's.

meanings.definition: a document that shows the details of and instructions relating to goods that are being transported by a company:
examples: a sea/air waybill
He swiped a bar-code wand across the waybill, which showed the contents and destination of the shipment.

meanings.definition: someone who travels on foot

a small tree or large shrub (= bush) that is deciduous (= it loses its leaves in winter) and has small white flowers in groups and red fruit. It often grows in hedges (= a line of bushes or small trees planted very close together, especially along the edge of a garden, field, or road) and is found in parts of Africa, Asia, and Europe:
examples: The wayfaring tree Viburnum lantana is found in southern Britain, usually in old hedges and on the edges of woods.
As its name suggests, the wayfaring tree or wayfarer is a sign, if you aren't already aware, that you are on or near a path.

meanings.definition:
past simple and past participle of 
        
         waylay
to wait for and then stop someone, especially either to attack or talk to that person:
examples: A man on his way to deposit $12,000 in a bank was waylaid by two men who snatched his bag.
I meant to leave earlier but I was waylaid on the way out of a meeting by my manager.

meanings.definition: (used in adverbs) in the stated direction or manner:
examples: edgeways
lengthways

meanings.definition: in some parliaments including the US, UK, and Canada, a group that makes decisions about how money for government budgets will be found, usually through taxes:
examples: He will be appointed chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, which deals with tax and spending issues.

meanings.definition: The ways and means of achieving something are the methods and other things needed to make it happen:
examples: With computer technology, even people working on their own have the ways and means to produce professional-looking documents.

meanings.definition: a low to middle level of ability in a foreign language according to the Common European Framework (= a description of language ability levels created by the Council of Europe)
doing only what you want and often changing your behaviour in a way that is difficult to control
not behaving or moving as expected:
examples: He was a wayward kid.
A wayward ball bounced into the yard.

meanings.definition: If you behave waywardly, you do only what you want, and often change your behaviour in a way that is difficult to control:
examples: His brother might waywardly show up out of the blue and visit for a couple of weeks, then we won't hear from him again for another year.
She was a waywardly eccentric genius on the tennis court.

meanings.definition: the quality of being wayward (= doing only what you want, in a way that is difficult to control):
examples: He was a man of professional brilliance but personal waywardness.
Denied a proper childhood and family life, she behaves with increasing waywardness.

meanings.definition: a person's bottom (= the part of the body you sit on) or anus (= the opening through which solid waste leaves the body):
examples: I told him to take his stupid idea and shove it up his wazoo.

meanings.definition: an act of urinating (= passing urine from the body)
a stupid person

written abbreviation for
        
         waybill
abbreviation for white blood cell
abbreviation for water closet: a toilet, or a room containing a toilet:
examples: The wooden staircase leads to three bedrooms, the bathroom, and a separate WC.

meanings.definition:
written abbreviation for
        
         written-down value
used as the subject of a verb to refer to a group including the speaker and at least one other person:
examples: Can we all go to the swimming pool this afternoon?
If you don't hurry up we'll be late.

meanings.definition: used by a speaker or a writer to refer to themselves and the people listening or reading:
examples: In today's lecture, we will be exploring the world economic situation.

meanings.definition: used as the subject of a verb to refer to all people, especially when considered as a group:
examples: This planet on which we all live should be cherished and not exploited.

meanings.definition: used as the subject of a verb to mean "you", especially when talking to a child or someone who is ill:
examples: We don't want to be late for school, do we?
"How are we this morning, Mrs Flanagan?" said the doctor.

meanings.definition: used by a queen or king when speaking officially to mean "I"
the person speaking and one or more others:
examples: If you don’t hurry up we won’t be on time.

meanings.definition: We can be used by a speaker or a writer to refer to the listener or person reading and the person speaking or writing:
examples: We have to get started now if we’re going to finish this afternoon.

meanings.definition: We can also mean you:
examples: Now everyone, we don’t want to be late, do we?

meanings.definition: all people; everyone:
examples: We live on planet earth.

meanings.definition: short form of we had:
examples: We'd better be more careful in the future.

meanings.definition: short form of we would:
examples: We'd be grateful for an answer.

meanings.definition: contraction of we had or we would:
examples: By then, we’d heard the same story six times.

meanings.definition: short form of we will:
examples: We'll do better next time, I'm sure.

meanings.definition: contraction of we shall or we will:
examples: We’ll be there tomorrow.

meanings.definition: used when you are angry about something that you feel is unfair and that you intend to stop happening:
examples: He wants to park his car on my lawn? Well, we'll soon see about that!

meanings.definition: short form of we are:
examples: We're here, Diane.

meanings.definition: contraction of we are:
examples: We’re ready now.

meanings.definition: short form of we have:
examples: We've been married eight years.

meanings.definition: contraction of we have:
examples: It's been over a year since we've done that.

meanings.definition: not physically strong:
examples: It's not surprising you feel weak if you haven't eaten properly for days.
The electromagnetic field strength becomes weaker as you move further away from high voltage cables.

meanings.definition: not strong in character, so that you are not able to make decisions or to persuade or lead other people:
examples: He was a weak king surrounded by corrupt advisers.

meanings.definition: A weak argument or excuse is one that is not likely to be accepted or believed:
examples: Any evidence that exists to support the hypothesis is fairly weak.
He gave the weakest of excuses when asked why he was late.

meanings.definition: A weak drink contains a lot of water compared to its other contents, so that it does not have a strong flavour:
examples: I can't stand weak coffee.

meanings.definition: A weak acid, alkali, or chemical base does not produce many ions (= atoms with an electrical charge) when it is dissolved in water.
not good enough, especially in ability, skill, or quality:
examples: He was always weak at/in languages but strong in science.
Our quiz team is a bit weak on sport.
In the end I think the film was spoilt by a weak story line.

meanings.definition: A weak chin is small and does not stick out from the face.
lacking strength or energy, or likely to stop working or break:
examples: After having been so sick, it’s not surprising you still feel weak.
That old chair is very weak and needs gluing.

meanings.definition: A drink that is weak lacks flavor:
examples: The coffee was weak and tasteless.

meanings.definition: A weak link is the part of something that is most likely to break:
examples: This year, the team’s only weak link is that third baseman.

meanings.definition: below standard; not good enough:
examples: He was always weak in languages but strong in science.

meanings.definition: too low or not powerful enough to be successful or effective:
examples: There was unexpectedly weak growth in corporate output in May.
Investors are already hesitant to commit because of the company's weak performance.
Consumer spending has been weak.
Investment banks continued weak after low trading volumes in the past few weeks.

meanings.definition: if a market, currency, investment, etc. is weak, it is falling or at a low level and unlikely to rise:
examples: The weak dollar is a huge help to the profitability of the companies.
weak investments/markets/prices
Swiss shares ended a quiet session lower as weak bonds weighed on the market.

meanings.definition: an acid with a pH of 5 or 6 whose molecules do not break down into smaller molecules or atoms in water
an acid with a pH of 5 or 6 whose molecules do not break down into smaller molecules or atoms in water

If you go weak at the knees, you lose your strength and feel you are going to fall over, usually because of seeing or talking about either someone you are very attracted to or because of something unpleasant or frightening:
examples: The thought of kissing him made me go weak at the knees.

meanings.definition: a base whose molecules do not break down into smaller molecules or atoms in water
a base whose molecules do not break down into smaller molecules or atoms in water
a reaction between particles that causes some radioactive substances to break down
a reaction between particles (= very small pieces of matter) that causes some radioactive substances to break down
the way that word is pronounced when there is no stress on it
a weak part, especially the weakest part of something:
examples: They're a fairly good team - their only weak link is a relatively inexperienced goalkeeper.
A chain can only be as strong as its weakest link, so we must look at the least committed country to see if the alliance will hold.

meanings.definition: something that is of poor quality and not as good as expected:
examples: Often you see some pretty weak sauce passing for a debate.

meanings.definition: of poor quality and not as good as you hoped:
examples: He criticized the game's weak-sauce graphics.

meanings.definition: especially in American football, the side of a team formation (= the shape that players play in) that has fewer players:
examples: The hard-hitting linebacker was shifted from the weak side to the middle.
He is expected to win a job as a starting weakside linebacker this season.

meanings.definition: especially in basketball, the side of the court (= playing area) that is away from the ball:
examples: I like coming from the weak side and blocking shots.

meanings.definition: a weak part in something:
examples: Targeting the opponent's weak spots is a typical technique in politics.

meanings.definition: having a very small chin, sometimes thought of as a sign of a weak character
not brave or determined enough to defend your beliefs against others:
examples: Instead of defending traditional values, the church frequently seems weak-kneed and irresolute.

meanings.definition: made to feel weak and likely to fall by emotion:
examples: She stood dazed and weak-kneed beside the coffin.

meanings.definition: showing no determination, or stupid
not having the determination that is needed to continue with a difficult course of action:
examples: My diets are never successful - I'm just too weak-willed.

meanings.definition: to (cause to) become less strong, powerful, determined, or effective:
examples: You could see the poor dog weakening daily as the disease spread through its body.
The bill would seriously weaken environmental protections.
We know that prolonged exposure to vibration can weaken aircraft components.
She's weakening - ask her some more questions and see if she confesses.

meanings.definition: to make or become weak or weaker:
examples: The country’s economy continues to weaken.
Long exposure to vibration can weaken aircraft parts.

meanings.definition: to become or make something or someone become less powerful, successful, effective, etc.:
examples: A series of scandals weakened investor confidence.
The plan has divided the country and weakened the government.
They will reduce interest rates if the economy weakens.
They slashed profit growth forecasts yesterday in the face of poor sales and weakening consumer spending.

meanings.definition: if markets, investments, etc. weaken, or if something weakens them, they fall in value:
examples: Sterling might weaken against the euro if the dollar does.
The shares weakened 2.5p to 225.25p.
German producer prices weakened in July.

meanings.definition:
past simple and past participle of 
        
         weaken
to (cause to) become less strong, powerful, determined, or effective:
examples: You could see the poor dog weakening daily as the disease spread through its body.
The bill would seriously weaken environmental protections.
We know that prolonged exposure to vibration can weaken aircraft components.
She's weakening - ask her some more questions and see if she confesses.

meanings.definition:
present participle of 
        
         weaken
to (cause to) become less strong, powerful, determined, or effective:
examples: You could see the poor dog weakening daily as the disease spread through its body.
The bill would seriously weaken environmental protections.
We know that prolonged exposure to vibration can weaken aircraft components.
She's weakening - ask her some more questions and see if she confesses.

meanings.definition: someone who is weak, either physically or in character:
examples: It would need more than a few exercises to turn a seven-stone weakling into a heavyweight boxer.

meanings.definition: someone who is weak, either physically or in character:
examples: Exercise can turn a weakling into a big, tough guy.

meanings.definition: in a way that is not physically strong:
examples: "Please, get me some water," he said weakly.
She smiled weakly at them.

meanings.definition: in a way that is not strong in character, so that you are not able to make decisions or to persuade or lead other people:
examples: The prisons are too weakly governed to prevent high rates of violence.
They had weakly opposed the proposal.

meanings.definition: in a way that is not likely to be accepted or believed:
examples: He argued weakly that government funding was high enough.
Her claims are only weakly supported by the evidence.

meanings.definition: in a way that lacks strength or energy:
examples: "I’m feeling a little better now," he said weakly.

meanings.definition: the fact or state of not being strong or powerful:
examples: Any change of policy will be interpreted as a sign of weakness.

meanings.definition: a particular part or quality of someone or something that is not good or effective:
examples: There are definite weaknesses in their security arrangements.
His main weakness as a manager is his inability to delegate.
The later novels show none of the weaknesses of his earlier work.

meanings.definition: lack of strength or energy:
examples: The building’s collapse was caused by weakness in several beams.

meanings.definition: Weakness is also a fault in someone’s character:
examples: Is crying always a sign of weakness?

meanings.definition: A weakness is also a strong liking for something:
examples: She admitted to a weakness for desserts.

meanings.definition: a situation in which someone or something is at a low level or is not strong or successful:
examples: The dollar's weakness against the Euro has made European goods more expensive here.
Weakness in the economy is accelerating.
She is concerned by the weakness of Europe's single currency.

meanings.definition: a particular part or quality of someone or something that is not good or effective:
examples: A smart management team knows its company's strengths and weaknesses.
There are definite weaknesses in their security arrangements.
His main weakness is his inability to delegate.

meanings.definition: a strong liking, usually for something that might have unpleasant or unwanted effects:
examples: My diet would be fine if only I didn't have a weakness for cookies.
I have a real weakness for chocolate.
He'd developed a weakness for French patisserie while staying in the country and had gained two or three kilos as a result.
They'd heard about my weakness for shoes and bags and took me to the best leather shop.
His weakness for beautiful women was no secret.
He had a notoriously short temper and a weakness for alcohol.

meanings.definition: a raised mark on the skin caused by being hit or injured in some other way:
examples: His back was covered with weals where he had been repeatedly beaten.

meanings.definition: a large amount of money or valuable possessions that someone has:
examples: During a successful business career, she accumulated a great amount of wealth.

meanings.definition: a large amount of something good:
examples: Jim has a wealth of teaching experience.
Russia has a wealth of coal and timber.

meanings.definition: a large amount of money and other valuable possessions:
examples: His wealth is so great that money doesn’t mean much to him.

meanings.definition: a large amount:
examples: Jim has a wealth of teaching experience.

meanings.definition: a large amount of money, property, or valuable possessions that a person or a country owns:
examples: Leaders in business must create wealth and jobs.
Households accumulate wealth by spending less than they earn.
His personal wealth is estimated at $7 billion.
corporate/economic/financial wealth
consumer/shareholder wealth
Despite the country's oil wealth, most of its citizens live in poverty.
wealth creation/redistribution

meanings.definition: a large amount of something good:
examples: The website gives a wealth of data on a company's stock.
He brings a wealth of industry experience to his new position.

meanings.definition: the theory that when the value of assets such as gold, shares, and property rises, people spend more:
examples: One of the primary drivers of spending by American consumers is the wealth effect of rising share prices.

meanings.definition: the business or activity of advising people, especially rich people, on how to invest and manage their money and property:
examples: There is an increasing demand for after-retirement wealth management.
wealth management firm/division/business

meanings.definition: a tax on personal property and financial assets above a particular level:
examples: The government will levy a wealth tax on those earning more than $100,000 a year.

meanings.definition: in the manner of someone who has a lot of money:
examples: He writes the kind of stories that end with characters living happily and wealthily ever after.
After signing his new hundred-million-dollar contract, the basketball star was wealthily set for life.

meanings.definition: rich:
examples: He's a very wealthy man.
With their natural resources they are potentially a very wealthy country.

meanings.definition: rich:
examples: a wealthy businessman/country/investor

meanings.definition: to cause a baby or young animal to stop feeding on its mother's milk and to start eating other food, especially solid food, instead:
examples: The studies were carried out on calves that had been weaned at five weeks of age.

meanings.definition: a child:
examples: "There is no point wasting money on food that the weans just won't eat," she said.

meanings.definition: to cause a baby or young animal to stop feeding on its mother’s milk and to eat other foods:
examples: She started to wean her baby at six months.

meanings.definition: to make someone gradually stop using something that is bad for them:
examples: It's difficult to wean addicts off cocaine once they're hooked.
The whole scheme is intended to wean people off welfare dependency.

meanings.definition: If someone is weaned on something, they have learned about and been influenced by it when young:
examples: This generation has been weaned on computer games.

meanings.definition: A baby or young animal that is weaned has started to eat other food, especially solid food, instead of only its mother's milk:
examples: You may want to sterilize spoons and bowls once your baby is weaned.
Many farmers sell their weaned calves right away.

meanings.definition: the act or process of causing a baby or young animal to stop feeding on its mother's milk and to start eating other food:
examples: A lot of mothers find early weaning from breast milk more convenient.
Though some toddlers may give up their bottle easily, weaning can take up to six months.

Your luggage must be weighed before it is put on the aircraft.

meanings.definition: (of something such as a fact or an event) to have an influence or be important:
examples: Easy access to a skilled workforce weighed heavily with us when we chose a site for the new factory.

meanings.definition: to carefully consider, especially by comparing facts or possibilities, in order to make a decision:
examples: Only when we have weighed all the factors involved can we decide when would be the best time to start.
Economic benefits must be carefully weighed against the possible dangers of handling radioactive waste.

meanings.definition: (of something such as a fact or an event) to have an influence or be important:

meanings.definition: a piece of equipment that you can stand on to find out your weight, or place an object on to find its weight:
examples: I stared in disbelief at the dial on the weighing machine.

meanings.definition: the amount that something or someone weighs:
examples: What weight can this lorry safely carry?
There was a slight decrease in his weight after a week of dieting.

meanings.definition: a piece of metal of known heaviness that can be used to measure the heaviness of other objects
any object that is heavy, especially one lifted or thrown for exercise:
examples: Try not to lift heavy weights.
I lift weights twice a week at the gym.

meanings.definition: respect, influence, trust, or importance:
examples: Her experience does give her opinions quite a bit of weight.
After he was voted out of office, few people attached much weight to what he said.
Radical views don't carry much weight any more.

meanings.definition: to fasten something heavy to something:
examples: Paper tablecloths need to be weighted down or they blow away in the wind.

meanings.definition: a quality of an object that is a measure of the force by which the earth attracts it, or an object considered as having this quality:
examples: The maximum weight the bridge can support is 15 tons.
You’ve lost some weight since the last time I saw you.
I don’t want to put on weight (= become heavier).
When lifting a heavy weight, keep your back straight and bend your knees.

meanings.definition: A weight is also a piece of metal whose force toward earth has been measured, and by which you can measure other objects:
examples: a one-pound weight

meanings.definition: A weight is also sports equipment, esp. a piece of metal attached to each end of a bar or to a special machine that you move or lift to strengthen your muscles:
examples: He lifts weights.

meanings.definition: influence:
examples: Her word carried weight with her neighbors.

meanings.definition: how heavy something or someone is:
examples: The Directive mandates that 85% of the weight of the vehicle must be reused or recycled.
Metal products for children should not consist of more than 0.06% lead, by weight.
Cars have increased in weight and fuel economy has suffered accordingly.

meanings.definition: any object that is heavy:
examples: The warehouse work involves the lifting of heavy weights.

meanings.definition: the quality of being heavy:
examples: Most fabrics need interfacing to support the weight of buttons.

meanings.definition: a unit or system of units used for expressing how much an object weighs:
examples: Imperial weights and measures were introduced in the 13th century.

meanings.definition: respect, influence, trust, or importance:
examples: The Association's reports carry weight because it stands for independence and integrity.
The guidelines give greater weight to economic potential.
Few people attached much weight to the findings of the enquiry.

meanings.definition: to give greater or lesser values to things to show how important they are compared to each other:
examples: Each country's growth rate is weighted according to its share of world GDP.
Most indexes are weighted by market value.
The results have been weighted to take account of household size.

meanings.definition: to organize something in a way that is likely to produce an advantage or disadvantage:
examples: In the marketplace, costs are weighted against smaller investors.
The labour market is heavily weighted toward skilled jobseekers.

meanings.definition: the fact of a person's or an animal's body weight becoming less:
examples: Weight loss can be achieved by balancing a healthy level of physical activity with eating a nutritious diet.
Such huge weight losses are not easy to sustain.

meanings.definition: designed to help you lose weight:
examples: Weight-loss surgery has become a popular treatment for obesity in recent years.
All weight-loss drugs may have unpleasant side effects.

meanings.definition: a document that shows the weight of goods when they are removed from a ship or aircraft
a worry that you had but that is now gone:
examples: It was a weight off my mind, knowing she arrived home safe.

meanings.definition: a room containing exercise machines, equipment for weight training (= lifting heavy objects for exercise), etc.:
examples: She spends about four hours a day in the pool or weight room.
He works out in the weights room three times a week.

meanings.definition: the activity of lifting heavy objects for exercise, especially to improve the strength of muscles and the appearance of the body:
examples: I do/go weight training in a gym during the week.

meanings.definition: supporting the weight of your body or a building:
examples: weight-bearing joints such as the knees
Weight-bearing exercise is very good for the bones.
a weight-bearing wall

meanings.definition: an operation that makes the stomach smaller so that less food can be eaten and digested
the value or importance of something when compared with another thing:
examples: The entrance test carries 40 percent weightage in the final result.

meanings.definition: prepared and arranged in a way that is likely to produce a particular effect, usually an advantage, rather than any other:
examples: The system is weighted in favour of those who have a good education.

meanings.definition: of information being studied, having a value attached to show its importance compared with all the information being studied
given an influence that would not happen naturally:
examples: Roche's, the most heavily weighted stock in the Swiss Market Index, has climbed 25 percent since Jan. 3.

meanings.definition: an average in which more value is given to some things than others depending on their importance:
examples: The index is a weighted average of growth rates in corporate earnings, consumer spending, and personal income.

meanings.definition: a cover made of heavy material, which is said to help a person feel calmer or less anxious when they lie or sit under it, or to sleep better when they have it over their bed:
examples: A comfort object such as a weighted blanket to ward off panic may be just the thing.
A special education teacher had wrapped him in a weighted blanket to calm him.

meanings.definition: an index that takes into account the importance of particular things, for example the amount of trade between each of the countries involved:
examples: The Russell 2000 Index TR is a total return weighted index.
On the Reserve Bank's Trade Weighted Index the Australian dollar ended on Friday at 55.6, down from 56.8 the previous week.

meanings.definition: in a way that feels very heavy:
examples: As he walked, the keys jingled weightily in the pockets of his trousers.
There's no reason why any of these meals should sit weightily on the stomach.

meanings.definition: in a way that is very serious or important:
examples: The guilt of leaving her sister to deal with the problem of her parents sat weightily upon her soul.
I would prefer people not to talk weightily about things they know next to nothing about.

meanings.definition: a level of importance given to something compared to something else:
examples: When the final grades are given, greater weighting is given to the lab work than to the written work.

meanings.definition: an increase in an amount, especially extra money paid to people because they work in an area where it is expensive to live:
examples: Do they pay London weighting?

meanings.definition: in the UK, extra money paid to someone because they work in an area where it is expensive to live:
examples: The salary of £15,537 increases to £17,778 with London weighting.

meanings.definition: a value given to each thing in a group to show its importance when compared with others in the group:
examples: Index trackers buy shares in proportion to a company's weighting within a particular market index.
Giving each stock equal weighting means that, overall, the fall has been 9.4%.
a heavy/high/neutral weighting
Different auto insurance companies attach different weighting factors and importance to the deductible.

meanings.definition:
→

having or appearing to have no weight:

meanings.definition: being in a state in which gravity (= the force by which the earth attracts objects) does not cause movement of objects:
examples: The astronauts are weightless in space.

meanings.definition: in a weightless way (= having or appearing to have no weight):
examples: Floating weightlessly in a blue, blue world, we dive deeper.
She's petite, delicate, almost weightlessly graceful.

meanings.definition: the state of having or appearing to have no weight; the fact of not being affected by gravity (= the force that makes things fall to the ground):
examples: The animals will be used to study the effects of weightlessness on the brain and nervous system.
After nearly five months of weightlessness, the first tenants of the international space station said they are eager to return to Earth.

meanings.definition: someone who practises the sport of weightlifting (= lifting heavy objects):

He became a champion weight-lifter.

meanings.definition: the activity of lifting heavy objects either as a sport or for exercise:

the International Weightlifting Federation

meanings.definition: the activity of lifting heavy bars to strengthen the muscles, either for exercise or in a competition
heavy:

meanings.definition: a type of large dog from Germany that is a kind of pointer once used for hunting and that has short light grey-brown fur:

meanings.definition: a wall built under the water across a river, over which the water flows from one level to another in a controlled way

meanings.definition: strange and different from anything natural or ordinary:

meanings.definition: in a way that is strange and unusual :

meanings.definition: the quality of being strange and unusual:

meanings.definition: a person who behaves strangely:

meanings.definition: a person who you think is strange and who makes you uncomfortable:
examples: That guy is a real weirdo.

meanings.definition: to avoid doing something you have promised to do, especially not to pay a debt:
examples: He's never welched on a debt - he always pays up.

meanings.definition: to not do something that you have promised to do, for example not pay a debt:

meanings.definition: to be pleased about and encourage or support something:
examples: The new appointment has been widely welcomed.

meanings.definition: to meet and speak to someone in a friendly way when they arrive:
examples: The visitors were warmly welcomed by the head of the department.

meanings.definition: If something is welcome, you are pleased to have or do it:

meanings.definition: the way in which someone is met and spoken to when they arrive in a place:
examples: They were given a warm (= very friendly) welcome.

She referred to his previous visit in her speech of welcome/welcome speech.

meanings.definition: a reaction to a decision or suggestion:

meanings.definition: said as a greeting to someone arriving at a place:

meanings.definition: to be pleased about or support something:
examples: Baseball fans welcomed the end of the players’ strike.

meanings.definition: (of someone who visits) received in a friendly way:

meanings.definition: a small piece of strong material with "welcome" written on it that is put on the floor by the door to greet people as they come in:

meanings.definition: used in phrases such as 'roll out the welcome wagon' and 'be greeted by the welcome wagon' to refer to a happy and friendly way of greeting people who are new to a place:

help given, especially by the state or an organization, to people who need it, especially because they do not have enough money:

After her month's sick leave, she was summoned to see the company's welfare officer.

meanings.definition: physical and mental health and happiness, especially of a person:

meanings.definition: physical and mental health and happiness:

meanings.definition: help given, esp. money, by a government to people who are poor and who do not have jobs:

meanings.definition: the general state of health or degree of success of a person, business, country, etc.:

meanings.definition: help given, especially by the state or another organization, to people who need it, especially because they are poor:
examples: welfare services/programs/workers

meanings.definition: a system of payments by the government to people who are ill, poor, or have no job:

meanings.definition: money paid by the government to people who are ill, poor, or have no job:

meanings.definition: a payment made by the government or an organization to a person who needs help because they do not have enough money:

meanings.definition: a visit made by a police officer or other official person to someone's home in order to check that they are safe and well and do not have any problems:

meanings.definition: a payment made by the government or an organization to a person who needs help because they do not have enough money:

an amount of money that is paid by the government to someone who is ill, poor, or has no job:

a political system in which the government pays for health care and other social benefits for its citizens, or a nation that operates under this system
a system by which a government provides social services such as health care, money, etc. to people who need them:
examples: The ANC established Africa's largest welfare state through the provision of old-age pensions.

meanings.definition: in the UK, a government policy that helps unemployed people who are receiving money from the government to get jobs:

meanings.definition: in a good way, to a high or satisfactory standard:

meanings.definition: very much, to a great degree, or completely:
examples: Knead the dough well, then divide it into four pieces.

I can't catch the bus - there are no buses after midnight, as you well know.

meanings.definition: used to emphasize some prepositions:

meanings.definition: used to emphasize some adjectives:

meanings.definition: very:

meanings.definition: with good reason:

meanings.definition: healthy; not ill:

meanings.definition: used to introduce something you are going to say, often to show surprise, doubt, slight disagreement, or anger, or to continue a story:

"He's decided to give up his job and move to Seattle with her." "Well, well - that's what love does for you."

Well? What did you do next?
Well, after that we went camping in the mountains.
Well/Oh well, it doesn't matter - I can always buy another one.
Very well, if you insist I'll meet him next week.

meanings.definition: healthy:

meanings.definition: to a great degree; much or completely:

meanings.definition: Well is used with some prepositions and adverbs for emphasis:

meanings.definition: Well is used with a few adjectives for emphasis:
examples: The museum is well worth a visit.

meanings.definition: (of a liquid) to come to the surface or into view:

examples: a quiet, well-adjusted man

meanings.definition: showing good judgment:
examples: You would be well advised to buy tickets in advance.

meanings.definition: showing good judgment:
examples: You would be well-advised to reserve a room in advance.

meanings.definition: completely:
examples: The party was well and truly over when he arrived.

meanings.definition: having a good supply of comfortable or necessary furniture and attractive decorations:
examples: The hotel has spacious, well-appointed public rooms and bedrooms.

meanings.definition: described or asked for in an effective and intelligent way:

meanings.definition: If an event is well attended, many people are present at it:

meanings.definition: completely involved in what you are doing: very drunk:

meanings.definition: A well balanced person is calm and reasonable and shows good judgment:

meanings.definition: having the right amounts of all the different parts that make up something:

meanings.definition: behaving in a way that is accepted as correct:
examples: a well-behaved child

meanings.definition: behaving in a way that is considered correct:

meanings.definition: coming from a family that has a high social position:
examples: a well-bred young English woman

meanings.definition: speaking or behaving in a way that is generally considered correct and polite

People, especially children, who are well brought up are polite and act in a quiet and pleasant way, because they have been taught this behaviour at home:
examples: Despite the family's problems, the children were well brought up.
He was a very well-brought-up young man.

meanings.definition: of a person, large and strong:
examples: He is well built and broad-shouldered with fair hair cut short at the sides.

meanings.definition: of an object or a building, produced or built well, so that it will last for a long time:
examples: The cars are well built and comfortable if a little dull inside.

meanings.definition: having an attractive, strong body
carefully chosen:
examples: These debates have been successful, mostly because of well-chosen speakers and lively topics.

meanings.definition: having friends or family members who are important or powerful people, or knowing people who are important or powerful:
examples: He was older, less educated and less well connected socially than most of his fellow officers.

meanings.definition: easily reached by road, train, plane, etc.:
examples: For investors looking for a base close to the United States, Dominica is very well connected.

meanings.definition: clearly expressed, explained, or described:
examples: We were not expecting Mr Levy to give us a clear or well-defined answer.

meanings.definition: that someone completely deserves to have because of the way they have behaved or the qualities they have:
examples: She is working hard and doing a good job, and her promotion is well deserved.
I'm taking a well-deserved break after a very busy week.

meanings.definition: having grown or increased in a positive way:
examples: These areas are less well developed and so less attractive as investment prospects.
She is a physically well-developed teenager with the mental level of a four-year-old.

meanings.definition: friendly and helpful:
examples: If you feel good about yourself, you are more likely to feel well disposed to/towards other people.

meanings.definition: having been often recorded:
examples: The medicinal value of garlic is well documented.

meanings.definition: If meat is well done, it is cooked so that it is firm and has a grey-brown colour all the way through:
examples: "How would you like your steak?" "Well done."
He insists on having his steak well done and will often return it and ask for it to be cooked for longer.

meanings.definition: (of meat) cooked all the way through:
examples: a well-done steak

meanings.definition: wearing attractive and stylish clothes
wearing or usually wearing attractive and stylish clothes
deserved because of what you have done or experienced:
examples: Liz won't be at work next week - she's having a well-earned rest.

meanings.definition: having had a good education:
examples: well-educated and highly motivated workers

meanings.definition: having had a good or a high level of education
having a lot of something, especially money or possessions:
examples: The city is well endowed with modern medical facilities.
It is a very well-endowed college.

meanings.definition: (of a man) having large sexual organs, or (of a woman) having large breasts:
examples: He's very well endowed!

meanings.definition: having a good supply of tools, clothes, equipment, etc.:
examples: We were well equipped for the trip.
Most schools are now well equipped with computers.

meanings.definition: having a recognized position, or being generally known about:
examples: The rules, though not written down, are fairly well established.
World Music is now well established and popular with mass audiences.

meanings.definition: based on facts:
examples: He had to show that he had a well-founded fear of persecution on religious or political grounds to qualify as a refugee.

meanings.definition: based on facts or good reasons:
examples: Her fears were well-founded.

meanings.definition: having a neat and pleasant appearance that is produced with care:
examples: A tall, well groomed man in a business suit walked in.

meanings.definition: having a neat, clean appearance
being based on or having a good knowledge of facts:
examples: The young players all seemed very well grounded in the rich history of the music they were performing.
The claim must be well grounded in fact.
a well-grounded criticism

meanings.definition: rich:
examples: His family was very well heeled.

meanings.definition: wealthy:
examples: The village has become a summer retreat for well-heeled city dwellers.

meanings.definition: to have a good relationship with someone in which they like you and from which you get an advantage:
examples: He's well in with the boss, these days.

meanings.definition: having a lot of knowledge or information about a particular subject or things in general:
examples: He was well informed and shrewd, with good, calm judgment.
How well informed is the customer about the range, quality, and cost of the products on offer?

meanings.definition: having a lot of knowledge:
examples: Marilyn is well-informed about the stock market.

meanings.definition: wanting to have good effects, but sometimes having bad effects that were not expected:
examples: Well-intentioned development projects can have unintended negative effects on population control.

meanings.definition: clean, tidy, and cared for:
examples: He was astonished to find nice streets and well-kept houses.

meanings.definition: A well-kept secret has not been told or shown to anyone:
examples: The details of the new car were a well-kept secret.

meanings.definition: taken care of in a proper way that people notice:
examples: She lives in a neighborhood of well-kept lawns and relatively little crime.

meanings.definition: known or recognized by many people:
examples: Her views on the subject are already well known.
It is well known that he never gives interviews.
The restaurant is well known for its friendly atmosphere and excellent service.
a well-known local artist
a well-known face/voice

meanings.definition: known or recognized by many people:
examples: The book is by a well-known historian.

meanings.definition: used to refer to health services providing advice and checks for men:
examples: It was not seen as macho to attend a well man clinic.
The company offers well-woman and well-man tests.

meanings.definition: behaving in a pleasant and polite way:
examples: The other visitors were too well mannered to complain.

meanings.definition: behaving in a pleasant and polite way:
examples: The other visitors were too well-mannered to complain.

meanings.definition: similar or equal (to something):
examples: At the start of the competition the three teams looked extremely well matched.

meanings.definition: wanting to have a good effect, but not always achieving one:
examples: I know he's well meaning, but I wish he'd leave us alone.

meanings.definition: said or done in order to be helpful, but not always achieving this:
examples: a well-meant suggestion

meanings.definition: intended to be helpful or kind, although not always having a good effect

meanings.definition: having a lot of or a number of:
examples: The city is well off for parks and gardens.

meanings.definition: wealthy
rich:

meanings.definition: used to describe a place where rich people live:

meanings.definition: drunk
working easily and effectively:

meanings.definition: lucky not to be involved:
examples: "Did I tell you the company went bust the month after I left?" "Really? Oh, you're well out of that!"

meanings.definition: earning or paying a lot of money:
examples: She was not well paid and found it difficult to provide for her family.

meanings.definition: used to describe a person or a job with a good salary:
examples: Only relatively well-paid people can afford to buy homes there.
well-paid employees/executives/workers

meanings.definition: (especially of something old) kept in good condition:
examples: It was a pretty town with a picturesque harbour and well-preserved buildings.

meanings.definition: (of an older person) not looking as old as they really are:
examples: A well-preserved male model can go on working into his forties.

meanings.definition: having suitable experience or formal qualifications:
examples: Ken has more than ten years of experience in photography behind him, so he is well qualified to offer advice.
He seems well qualified for the job.

meanings.definition: Someone who is well read has learned a lot of information on different subjects by reading.
having read many important books
involving or having experience in a wide range of ideas or activities:
examples: The article is well rounded and is fair to both sides of the dispute.
She describes herself as a "well-rounded individual" who works hard but has a varied social life.

meanings.definition: having or providing experience and knowledge in a number of different areas:
examples: Some experts say that home-schooled children may not receive a well-rounded education.

meanings.definition: having a pleasant and polite way of speaking that is considered socially acceptable:
examples: The young man was well spoken and polite.

meanings.definition: used to praise someone who has noticed something:
examples: "I've just seen your glasses - they're under the table." "Ah, well spotted!"
"Do I detect a trace of a South African accent?" "Yes, well spotted!"
"I think the decimal point is in the wrong place." "Oh yes, well spotted, Dave."

"You've had your hair cut, haven't you?" "Yes, well spotted."

meanings.definition: considered by other people as good; admired, and approved of:
examples: He was efficient at his job and well thought of by everyone.
It's a well-thought-of school.

meanings.definition: respected by many people for quality, ability, moral character, etc.:
examples: He was well-thought-of as a foreign-policy expert.

meanings.definition: planned in an effective way:
examples: The training schedule wasn't very well thought out.
a well-thought-out system for traffic control

meanings.definition: A well thumbed book, magazine, etc. is one whose slightly damaged appearance shows that it has been used many times.
happening or caused to happen at a suitable or effective time:
examples: A well-timed joke stopped the disagreement developing into something more serious.

meanings.definition: happening or made to happen at a particularly suitable time:
examples: Her appearance was well-timed to coincide with the arrival of the president.

meanings.definition: (of a person) having been to many different places, especially to many different countries:
examples: He was well traveled, spending at least a decade in the United States and in Europe, before settling in Dublin.

meanings.definition: (of a road, route, etc.) used by many people
(of a person) having been to many different places, especially to many different countries:
examples: He was well travelled, spending at least a decade in the United States and in Europe, before settling in Dublin.

meanings.definition: (of a road, route, etc.) used by many people
used many times before and known to be effective:
examples: a well-tried recipe

meanings.definition: much used or visited:
examples: We followed the well-trodden tourist route from Paris to Chartres.

meanings.definition: used to refer to a set of actions that many people have done or a subject that many people have dealt with previously:
examples: The survey showed that people become managers by well-trodden paths.

meanings.definition: expressed in an interesting and intelligent way:
examples: a well-turned phrase

meanings.definition: A well-turned phrase is expressed in a clear and pleasing way:
examples: If asked his opinion, he was always ready with a few well-turned phrases.

meanings.definition: knowing a lot about something:
examples: He was well versed in modern history.

meanings.definition: having a lot of knowledge about something:
examples: He was well-versed in the history of space flight.

meanings.definition: used to refer to health services providing advice and checks for women:

meanings.definition: Well worn clothes have been worn often and are becoming old:

meanings.definition: used very often or too often:

meanings.definition: an expression of complete surprise:
examples: She's marrying a man who she met two months ago? - Well, I'll be damned!

meanings.definition: something you say when you are surprised by a piece of information. This phrase is often used humorously to mean the opposite:
examples: So they're getting married, are they? Well, what do you know!

meanings.definition: said when you are very surprised at something:

meanings.definition: the state of feeling healthy and happy:

meanings.definition: liked by many people

meanings.definition: a person who says or does something that stops other people enjoying themselves
a type of battery (= a device that produces electricity to provide power for electronic devices, cars, etc.) that contains liquid:

to pay to use an aircraft with a crew, fuel, and insurance:

meanings.definition: a disease in older people in which blood vessels leak fluid into the most important part of the retina (= the area at the back of the eye that receives light), making it weaker and leading to problems when looking directly at objects and to loss of sight
especially in Asia, a market where fresh meat, fish, fruit, vegetables, and sometimes live animals are sold to the public:
examples: She shopped at one of the city's many wet markets, that sell everything from slabs of meat to iced fish.
At the city's wet markets, the market floors are constantly washed down.

meanings.definition: in the past, a woman employed to give her breast milk to another woman's baby
to treat someone too carefully as if that person is unable to do anything himself or herself
a bathroom in which the shower is not separated off from the rest of the room, and water from the shower is allowed to fall directly onto the floor and then flow away through a hole in the floor:
examples: A wet room provides the functionality of a traditional bathroom, along with the luxury of a tiled area underneath the shower that is much bigger than normal.

meanings.definition: to urinate in your bed by accident:

I don't generally give Olivia a drink at night because it can make her wet the bed.
Our 7-year-old still wets her bed.
A week after this happened, he started to wet his bed.

meanings.definition: a small piece of wet cloth or paper that is used once for cleaning something, usually sold in a pack:

meanings.definition: to urinate in your clothes:

meanings.definition: to have an alcoholic drink
shiny:

meanings.definition: a type of large insect from New Zealand, with long legs with spines (= sharp points) on them. There are many different species (= types) of wētā, most of which do not have wings:
examples: Wētā range in size, but, with their big bodies and spiny legs, they are one of New Zealand's most recognizable creepy-crawlies.
There are several species of the insect, the most impressive being the giant weta, which is the heaviest insect in the world, weighing up to 71g.
Wetas are a group of around 70 species of large insect from New Zealand, related to grasshoppers and crickets.

meanings.definition: a male sheep that has been castrated (= had its sex organs removed):
examples: He drove around the paddocks checking wethers, ewes and lambs.

meanings.definition: a large area of land covered with swamp or marsh
an area of land that is naturally wet:
examples: Thousands of acres of wetlands are destroyed every year by development.

meanings.definition: in a way that involves water or another liquid:
examples: She sat rigidly in her seat, her clothes clinging wetly to her body.

meanings.definition: in a weak way, without any confidence:
examples: She said wetly that she thought it would probably be too difficult for her.

meanings.definition: the state of containing or being covered with water or another liquid:
examples: The wetness of the land they crossed made travelling difficult.
The cold wetness she felt on her brow was sweat, not blood.

meanings.definition: rain:

meanings.definition: the fact of a person having a weak character:
examples: Edmund, her secret love, could never be suspected of wetness.

meanings.definition: a piece of clothing, usually made from rubber, that covers the whole body closely and is designed to keep you warm when you are swimming, especially in the sea, for long periods:
examples: divers in wetsuits
