examples: He wishes me every morning.

meanings.definition: having no colour, firm ideas, principles, or noticeable qualities of any type:
examples: The candidate gave a few unsatisfactory wishy-washy answers.
Watercolours are too wishy-washy for my taste.

meanings.definition: lacking in firm ideas, principles, or the ability to make a decision:
examples: He’s got TV ads accusing Dole of being wishy-washy on the issues.

meanings.definition: a delicate, thin, and sometimes twisting piece or line of something:
examples: Rita brushed back the stray coppery wisps of hair escaping her braid.
A wisp of smoke from the campfire curled in the air.

meanings.definition: in a way that is thin and delicate, like a small, thin line of cloud, smoke, steam, etc.:
examples: Smoke rose wispily from the end of her cigarette.
The clothes must be intended for wispily thin models since they are only available in small sizes.

meanings.definition: (of hair) thin and not growing thickly:
examples: Her hair drooped wispily over her eyes and she had to tuck it behind her ear.
A wispily bearded young man was at the door.

meanings.definition: in a way that is not loud or strong:
examples: The shy girl wispily gave her name and was asked by the judge to repeat herself.
A few feeble leaves wispily hung off the few dried branches.

meanings.definition: in the form of a wisp or wisps:
examples: a wispy cloud/fringe
wispy hair

meanings.definition: a climbing plant with groups of small purple, blue, or white flowers hanging from it
sad and thinking about something that is impossible or in the past:
examples: a wistful smile
I thought about those days in Spain and grew wistful.

meanings.definition: sad and thinking about something that is impossible or past:
examples: She cast a wistful glance at the bridal gowns in the window.

meanings.definition: in a way that is sad and shows someone is thinking about something that is impossible or in the past:
examples: "I would love to go back to Venice," he said wistfully.
He speaks wistfully of his time in the limelight.

meanings.definition: a feeling of sadness because you are thinking about something that is impossible or in the past:
examples: He admits a certain wistfulness for his days as governor.
A return to the dream of childhood innocence is mere wistfulness.

meanings.definition: the ability to use words in a clever and humorous way:
examples: a woman of great intelligence and wit
Her conversation sparkled with her own subtle blend of wit and charm.
He was known for his dry/ready/sharp wit.

meanings.definition: a person who is skilled at using words in a clever and humorous way:
examples: Sydney Smith, a notable wit, once remarked that he never read a book before he reviewed it because it might prejudice his opinion of it.

meanings.definition: the ability to use words in an amusing and intelligent way, or a person who has this ability:
examples: The warmth and wit of her literary style bring the subject to life.

meanings.definition: a woman who is believed to have magical powers and who uses them to harm or help other people:
examples: a witch on a broomstick
Witches were persecuted all over western Europe from the 15th to the 17th century, as it was claimed that they had dealings with the Devil.

meanings.definition: an unpleasant and ugly woman
a woman who is believed to have magical powers and, esp. in stories, uses them to help or harm people
a person in some societies who cures people using traditional magic or medicine
a small tree that produces flowers, or liquid from this tree, used as a medicine
an attempt to find and punish people whose opinions are unpopular and who are said to be a danger to society:
examples: In America, Senator McCarthy led a witch hunt against people suspected of being communists.

meanings.definition: disapproving an attempt to find and punish people whose opinions are not popular
the activity of performing magic to help or harm other people
the use of magic, esp. in stories, to help or harm people
a mixture of unpleasant or dangerous things:
examples: The smog is composed of a witches' brew of car exhaust and smoke from factories.

meanings.definition: a situation that has many different parts that are difficult and dangerous:
examples: The country is in turmoil, a witches' brew of poverty and warfare.

meanings.definition: a brand name for a type of white liquid used for painting over mistakes in a piece of writing
used to say that people or things are in a place together or are doing something together:
examples: I was with Sylvia at the time.
He lives with his grandmother.
He's impossible to work with.
I'm going to France with a couple of friends.
Ingrid Bergman starred with Humphrey Bogart in the movie "Casablanca".
I left my books with Sandra.
Ice cream with your apple pie?
Mix the butter with the sugar and then add the egg.
I'll be with you (= I will give you my attention) in a second.
She's staying with her parents (= at their house) for a few months.
He's been with the department (= working in it) since 2010.

meanings.definition: using something:
examples: He was shot at close range with a pistol.
She wiped her lipstick off with a tissue.
Join the two pieces together with glue.
Please handle this package with care.
They set up a business with the help of a bank loan.

meanings.definition: having or including something:
examples: a tall woman with dark hair
He's married with three children.
They were divided into two groups, with no girls in one group and no boys in the other.
He spoke with a soft Irish accent.
We're an international company with offices in Paris, New York, and Sydney.
Two coffees please, one with milk and one without.
He arrived in Los Angeles with nothing but the clothes he was wearing.
He woke up with a terrible headache.
I was second in the race with a time of 14.2 seconds.
With a bit of luck, we should be back in time for dinner.
Both their children graduated with degrees in economics.

meanings.definition: used at the beginning of various phrases written at the end of a letter:
examples: With best wishes from Charles.
With love, Roberta.

meanings.definition: including:
examples: With your contribution, that makes a total of £45.

meanings.definition: relating to or in the case of a person or thing:
examples: How are things with you?
Russia has just drawn up a trade agreement with Norway.
This hasn't got anything to do with you (= this is not something you should be interested in).
The government's policies have not been popular with (= among) the voters.
He's very careless with his money.
She talked a lot about her relationship with Charlotte.

meanings.definition: used to show what is on or in something:
examples: She laid the table with the best china.
Her blouse was spattered with blood.
The room was littered with toys.
The trucks were laden with food and medicine.
She filled the jug up with cream.

meanings.definition: because of or caused by someone or something:
examples: He winced with pain.
I was trembling with fear.
She's been at home with a bad cold for the past week.
I can't work with all that noise going on.
Hopes were dashed in the war-torn capital with the news that no aid would be arriving that week.
With exams approaching, it's a good idea to review your class notes.
(What) with all the excitement and confusion, I forgot to say goodbye to her.

meanings.definition: against something:
examples: I ended up having an argument with her.
She has fought a constant battle with depression throughout her career.
The two countries went to war with one another over oil prices.
A truck had collided with a car.

meanings.definition: used with words showing separation:
examples: I'd rather not part with my cash.
He decided to put his failed marriage behind him and make a clean break with the past.

meanings.definition: and, or followed by:
examples: I'd like a steak and fries with apple pie for dessert.
$200 is payable immediately with a further $100 payable on delivery.

meanings.definition: used in comparisons:
examples: I have nothing in common with my brother.
This cake's very light compared with the last one you made.

meanings.definition: supporting someone or something:
examples: If you want to go for a promotion, I'll be with you all the way.
You have to decide where you stand on this issue - you're either with me or against me.

meanings.definition: in the same direction as something:
examples: The wind was with me on the home stretch and I ran well.

meanings.definition: at the same rate or time as something:
examples: This wine will improve with age.
Stopping distances for cars vary with the speed they are travelling at.

meanings.definition: despite something:
examples: With all her faults, she's still a really good friend.

meanings.definition: used to express a wish or instruction:
examples: Away with you! (= Go away!)
Off to bed with you! (= Go to bed!)
On with the show! (= Let it continue.)
Down with school! (= We don't want/like it.)

meanings.definition: used of people or things that are together or doing something together:
examples: She’s in the kitchen with Dad.
He’s an impossible person to work with.
I think I’ll have some ice cream with my pie.
I’ll be with you (= I will give you my attention) in a moment.
She’s been with the magazine (= working for it) for two years.

meanings.definition: using (something) or by means of (something):
examples: I bought it with my gift certificate.
The label on the box says, "Handle with care."
He caught the crabs with a large net.

meanings.definition: having or possessing (someone or something):
examples: I’d like a room with an ocean view.
He’s married with three children.
The doctor spoke with a German accent.
We’re a multinational company with offices in London, Paris, and New York.
With a little luck, we should be back in time for dinner.
Both their children graduated with degrees in economics.

meanings.definition: With can also mean including:
examples: With your contribution, we have a total of $450.

meanings.definition: relating to or in the case of (a person or thing):
examples: How are things with you?
That has nothing to do with the subject.
Her books are popular with teenage girls.
He’s very careless with his money.
The trouble with this skirt is that it wrinkles too easily.
What’s the matter with her?

meanings.definition: because of or caused by (something):
examples: He was trembling with fear.
She’s at home with a bad cold.
His confidence was bolstered with the support of a lot of friends and relatives.
With all the excitement and confusion, I forgot to say goodbye to her.

meanings.definition: against (something):
examples: The company faces a long battle with the software giant.
I always end up arguing with him about politics.

meanings.definition: supporting (someone or something):
examples: If you want to go for a promotion, I’ll be with you all the way.
Where do you stand on this issue – are you with us or against us?

meanings.definition: despite (something):
examples: With all her faults, she’s still one of the best teachers we’ve ever had.

meanings.definition: and; followed by:
examples: I’d like a hamburger and French fries with a small salad.
Two hundred dollars is payable immediately, with a further $100 payable on delivery.

meanings.definition: used to express polite disagreement in a formal situation:
examples: With all due respect, Sir, I cannot agree with your last statement.

meanings.definition: used for expressing polite disagreement:
examples: I’ve been thinking about what you said and, with all due respect, I think you’re mistaken.

meanings.definition: If you describe something as a particular thing with knobs on, you mean it has similar qualities to that thing but they are more extreme:
examples: Disney World was like an ordinary amusement park with knobs on.

meanings.definition: in a completely uncontrolled way:
examples: We danced with wild abandon.
We've been using fossil fuels with gay abandon.
Peter mixed different styles of clothes with wild abandon.
She ordered food and drinks with gay abandon.
They sprawled on the sofa, laughing with wild abandon.

meanings.definition: If something starts, ends, returns, etc. with a bang, it starts, ends, etc. in a very exciting and noticeable way:
examples: She took some time off last year, but she's back with a bang with her new album.

with-a-capital-etc.name: with a capital A, B, etc.

meanings.definition: said after the name of a particular quality to say that it is very strong, using its first letter:
examples: He's trouble with a capital T!

meanings.definition: used to say that something is unusual, and more interesting or better than other things of the same type:
examples: Try new Cremetti - the ice cream with a difference.

meanings.definition: If you do something with a flourish, you do it with one big, noticeable movement:
examples: The waiter handed me the menu with a flourish.
He took off his hat with a flourish.
She signed her name with a flourish.
With a flourish, she uncorked the bottle and presented it to our table.
Our team finished with a flourish, scoring a goal just one minute before the end of the match.
He unveiled the statue with a flourish.

meanings.definition: used to say something is more general or less extreme than the usual meaning:
examples: She is deeply conservative with a small "c" (= has traditional values, rather than being a member or supporter of the Conservative Party).
Management is all about politics with a small "p".

meanings.definition: with great force or extreme energy:
examples: He's been working with a vengeance over the past few weeks to make up for lost time.
Flared trousers are back with a vengeance (= very popular again) this summer.

meanings.definition: using a lot of effort, energy, or time:
examples: She works out every day with a vengeance.

with-a-view-to-doing.name: with a view to doing something

meanings.definition: with the aim of doing something:
examples: These measures have been taken with a view to increasing the company's profits.

meanings.definition: with energy and determination:
examples: They worked with a will and had cleared the path by 10 a.m.

meanings.definition: in a way that is exact or correct:
examples: Experience is needed to use the machine with accuracy.
The pollsters managed to predict the election results with astonishing accuracy.

meanings.definition: completely:
examples: I love you with all my heart.

meanings.definition: very strongly and sincerely:
examples: I love you with all my heart.
He wished with all his heart that he had not done it.
They believe with all their hearts that their country is fighting in a just cause.

meanings.definition: used before describing an event or a result that you are hoping for:
examples: With any luck (= I hope that) we should get to Newcastle by early evening.

meanings.definition: To do something or go somewhere with bells on is to do it or go there eagerly:
examples: "Are you coming to Paul's tonight." "Sure, I'll be there - with bells on."

meanings.definition: in a way that shows that you are completely confident or that you have no doubt about something:
examples: Can you state with certainty that this is the same man you saw on that day?
I'm unable to answer that question with any certainty.

meanings.definition: fml pregnant:
examples: The painting is of a woman with child.

meanings.definition: used for saying that it is difficult for someone to do something:
examples: Benny pulled himself up from the floor with difficulty.
He was restraining his impatience with great difficulty.

meanings.definition: quickly and effectively

with-every-fiber-of-being.name: with every fiber of your being

meanings.definition: If you want or believe something with every fiber of your being, you want or believe it very much:
examples: She wanted to win the race with every fiber of her being.

with-every-fibre-of-being.name: with every fibre of your being

meanings.definition: If you want or believe something with every fibre of your being, you want or believe it very much:
examples: She wanted to win the race with every fibre of her being.

meanings.definition: If you do something such as pass an exam with flying colors, you do it very successfully.
very easily:
examples: She passed the exam with flying colors.

meanings.definition: If you do something such as pass an exam with flying colours, you do it very successfully.

with-friends-like-you-who-needs-enemies.name: with friends like you, who needs enemies?

meanings.definition: said to or about someone who says he or she is your friend but who is treating you very badly
If you do something, especially argue, with guns blazing, you do it with a lot of force and energy:
examples: I went into the meeting with guns blazing, determined not to let him win.

meanings.definition: knowing a lot about new ideas and fashions:
examples: He reads all the style magazines and thinks he's really with it.

meanings.definition: fashionable
To illegally harm someone with malice aforethought is to have thought about it and planned it before acting:
examples: Her crime was malicious and with malice aforethought.
You can only be convicted of murder if the crime was committed with malice aforethought.
It was a classic case of murder with malice aforethought.
They must be able to prove that the defendant acted with malice aforethought.

meanings.definition: with as much effort as possible:
examples: They shouted with might and main but nobody came to rescue them.

meanings.definition: not thinking about a particular thing:
examples: With no thought for his own safety, he rushed towards the burning car.

meanings.definition: If people do something with one accord, they do it together and in complete agreement:
examples: With one accord, the delegates walked out of the conference.
"Let him in!" they shouted with one accord.
On hearing him arrive, we ran with one accord to greet him.
They fell to their knees with one accord and began to pray.
With one accord, the riders drew to a halt.

meanings.definition: If a group of people express an opinion or decide something with one voice, they all agree:
examples: The committee decided with one voice to accept the proposal.

meanings.definition: in a very friendly way

→ 
        
         willing  :
examples: "Would you mind holding the door open for me, please?" "Oh, with pleasure."

meanings.definition: and then, or after doing or saying that:
examples: "I still think you're wrong," he said and with that he drove away.

meanings.definition: using something to help you:
examples: He gets about with the aid of a walking stick.
The tunnel was dug with the aid of heavy machinery.
With the aid of a rope they hauled the planks up the hill.
With the aid of medication, he seemed back to normal.
She was able to find a solution with the aid of her computer skills.

meanings.definition: as well as anyone:
examples: He can dance with the best of them.

with-the-best-will-in-the-world.name: with the best will in the world

meanings.definition: used to mean "I would like to if I possibly could", in a situation where you cannot do something:
examples: With the best will in the world, I can't employ him in the shop unless I can trust him.

meanings.definition: gradually:
examples: With the course of time, I've learned to live with my disability.
It seems that, with the course of time, his ideas about acting changed.
The book describes how early communities increased and concentrated their populations with the course of time.
Everyone changes with the course of time.
We hoped that the problems in their relationship would resolve with the course of time.

meanings.definition: in the same direction as the movement of the water in a river, sea, etc.:
examples: It's much easier to swim with the current than against it.
The boat sank after drifting with the current for a few hours.

meanings.definition: similar to, or the same as, the opinion or feeling that a group of people have:
examples: Nothing is gained by going with the current.
Graduate students are encouraged pick modest, not bold projects, to swim with the current for reasons of career development.

meanings.definition: without using any special device for making images larger:
examples: We live miles away, but on a clear night, you can see the city skyscrapers with the naked eye.

meanings.definition: with your past mistakes or crimes forgotten
with the knowledge that experience gives you:
examples: With the wisdom of hindsight we now know that the old-fashioned aerosol sprays were a mistake.

meanings.definition: without using any type of tool or weapon:
examples: He wrestled the lion to the ground with his bare hands.

meanings.definition: If you give something to someone with your compliments, you give it to that person free:
examples: We enclose a copy of our latest brochure, with our compliments.
Please send the minister a copy of my book with my compliments.
For guests of our hotel, evening cocktails are offered with our compliments.
We will send you a selection of our choicest coffees to try with our compliments.
Please accept this necklace with my compliments.

meanings.definition: very easily:
examples: I can find your house with my eyes closed.

meanings.definition: If you could do something with your eyes closed or shut, you could do it very easily because you have done it many times: noticing nothing:
examples: I could do that journey with my eyes shut.
Half the time you go around with your eyes shut.

meanings.definition: knowing about all the problems there could be with something you want to do:
examples: I went into this marriage with my eyes open.

meanings.definition: just before you die:
examples: She asked him with her dying breath to take care of her child.

meanings.definition: used to say that you have made something yourself:
examples: "Where did you get this cake?" "I made it with my own fair hands."

meanings.definition: used to describe an insurance agreement that pays an agreed amount and also pays a share of the profits the insurance company has made:
examples: More than £400bn is held in with-profits funds.

meanings.definition: in addition:
examples: He was a man of great means, and of great intellect withal.

meanings.definition: in spite of what has been said:
examples: It was, withal, a carefully crafted speech.

meanings.definition: to take or move out or back, or to remove:
examples: This credit card allows you to withdraw up to £200 a day from ATMs.
The UN has withdrawn its troops from the country.
Eleven million bottles of water had to be withdrawn from sale due to a health scare.
Once in court, he withdrew the statement he'd made to the police (= he claimed it was false).
All charges against them were withdrawn after the prosecution's case collapsed.
After lunch, we withdrew into her office to finish our discussion in private.
She had to withdraw from the competition because of a leg injury.
Following his nervous breakdown, he withdrew from public life and refused to give any interviews.

meanings.definition: to stop talking to other people and start thinking thoughts that are not related to what is happening around you:
examples: As a child, she frequently withdrew into her own fantasy world.
After the accident, he withdrew into himself and refused to talk to family or friends.

meanings.definition: to take something back, or to remove something:
examples: He asked that his name be withdrawn from nomination for a Golden Globe Award.
Democrats threatened to withdraw (= stop giving) their support of the tax bill.
I have to withdraw (= take out) some money from an ATM machine.

meanings.definition: to take money out of an account:
examples: This account allows you to withdraw a maximum daily amount of $500.
The economic crisis saw people queuing to withdraw their savings.

meanings.definition: to stop selling a product or offering a service, usually because of a problem or fault:
examples: The product was withdrawn from the market on safety grounds.
The brewery said there was no connection between their decision to withdraw one of their local beers and the dispute with their main competitor.

meanings.definition: to remove something that you previously agreed to provide:
examples: The opposition threatened to withdraw support for the government's pension plans.
Morgan Stanley withdrew the job offer.

meanings.definition: to stop being involved in a situation, having a particular responsibility, or belonging to an organization:
examples: Despite the stock market crash, only one corporate investor has withdrawn from the deal.
He withdrew as a candidate for the Democratic presidential nomination.

meanings.definition: to tell people officially that something you said earlier is not true or correct:
examples: She was advised to withdraw her statement.
The Foreign Office withdrew advice to holidaymakers not to travel to some areas in the Far East.
withdraw an accusation/allegation/complaint

meanings.definition: when you take money out of a bank account:
examples: The bank became suspicious after several large withdrawals were made from his account in a single week.

meanings.definition: the process or action of a military force moving out of an area:
examples: The commander-in-chief was given 36 hours to secure a withdrawal of his troops from the combat zone.

meanings.definition: the act or process of taking something away so that it is no longer available, or of someone stopping being involved in an activity:
examples: Doctors demanded the withdrawal of the drug (from the market) after several cases of dangerous side-effects were reported.
Her sudden withdrawal from the championship caused a lot of press speculation about her health.

meanings.definition: behaviour in which someone prefers to be alone and does not want to talk to other people:
examples: Withdrawal is a classic symptom of depression.

meanings.definition: an act of taking something back, removing something, or moving something back:
examples: a troop withdrawal
He had made several large withdrawals from his bank account (= He had taken out a lot of money).
Her sudden withdrawal from the competition surprised everyone.

meanings.definition: Withdrawal also means the physical and mental effects experienced when a person stops using a drug.
the act of taking money out of an account, or the amount of money taken:
examples: The savings account only allows you to make three withdrawals a year.
There's a cash withdrawal limit of €500 per day.
There are large early withdrawal penalties attached to this mortgage.

meanings.definition: the act of stopping something from happening or being available:
examples: The withdrawal of corporate sponsorship had a damaging impact on the company's performance.
withdrawal of an offer/support

meanings.definition: the process of removing a product from the market, either temporarily or permanently, because there is a problem with it:
examples: The company is still struggling to rebuild its image following the withdrawal of its new cancer drug on safety grounds.
The cost of the product withdrawal was estimated at over $10 million.

meanings.definition: the state of no longer being involved in something:
examples: The scandal led to her withdrawal from politics.

meanings.definition: the act of officially changing something you previously said:
examples: withdrawal of an allegation/statement/complaint

meanings.definition: the unpleasant physical and mental effects that result when you stop doing or taking something, especially a drug, that has become a habit:
examples: He was suffering from all the classic withdrawal symptoms associated with giving up heroin.
I haven't watched any TV for over a week and I'm having withdrawal symptoms.

meanings.definition: shy and quiet and preferring to be alone rather than with other people:
examples: Following her son's death, she became quiet and withdrawn and rarely went out.

meanings.definition: (of a person) preferring to be alone and taking little interest in other people:
examples: During the winter, she became depressed and withdrawn.

meanings.definition:
past simple of 
        
         withdraw
(to cause) to become weak and dry and decay:
examples: Grass had withered in the fields.

meanings.definition: to slowly disappear, lose importance, or become weaker:
examples: This country is in danger of allowing its industrial base to wither away.

meanings.definition: to become, or cause something to become, weak, dry, and smaller:
examples: Hot, dry weather withered the peanut crop in the southeast.
fig. Public interest in the scandal will not wither away any time soon.

meanings.definition: If something withers on the vine, it is destroyed very gradually, usually because no one does anything to help or support it:
examples: When the new resort was built, the tourist trade in smaller hotels withered on the vine.

meanings.definition: dry and decaying:
examples: withered leaves/flowers

meanings.definition: A withered arm or leg has not grown to its correct size because of disease.
A withering look, remark, etc. is one that is intended to make someone feel ashamed:
examples: He said that Lizzie had been drunk at the time and I saw her shoot him a withering glance.

meanings.definition: severe and extremely critical:
examples: He made a withering attack on government policy.

meanings.definition: expressing strong criticism:
examples: She delivered a withering attack on the book and its authors.

meanings.definition: in a way that criticizes someone severely, or that is intended to make someone feel ashamed:
examples: He plays a witheringly cynical alcoholic who works in a law firm.
His final reply was both witheringly sarcastic and gloriously triumphant.

meanings.definition: the highest part of the back of a horse, above its shoulders

past simple and past participle of 
        
         withhold
to refuse to give something or to keep back something:
examples: to withhold information/support
During the trial, the prosecution was accused of withholding crucial evidence from the defence.
Police are withholding the dead woman's name until her relatives have been informed.
She withheld her rent until the landlord agreed to have the repairs done.
The government is planning to withhold benefit payments from single mothers who refuse to name the father of their child.

meanings.definition: to refuse to give something, or to keep back something:
examples: Has the government been withholding crucial information?
The governor said he would withhold judgment until he receives the committee’s report.

meanings.definition: if someone withholds something from someone else, they do not allow them to have something they expected to have:
examples: The director is facing disciplinary action after the inquiry found he deliberately withheld vital information.
The client's name and address have been withheld for security reasons.
withhold approval/support
withhold funding/payment

meanings.definition: money taken from a person's income and paid directly to the government by their employer
a percentage of the money earned from an investment that is kept by a financial organization to pay directly to the government in tax:
examples: Britain remains opposed to an EU-wide withholding tax on cross-border savings.
Many Swiss bank account holders use Jersey to avoid the withholding tax levied on Swiss corporate dividends.

meanings.definition: in the US, a percentage of an employee's income that an employer keeps to pay directly to the government in tax:
examples: Individuals paying too much withholding tax will receive a tax refund in May.

meanings.definition: inside or not further than an area or period of time:
examples: Two thirds of Californians live within 15 miles of the coast.
In 1992 cross-border controls within the EU were dismantled.
For orders within the UK, please enclose £2.50 for post and packing.
The resort lies within easy reach of (= not far from) the ski slopes.
We recommend that this wine should be consumed within six months.
Within hours of the tragedy happening, an emergency rescue team had been assembled.
The tickets should reach you within the week (= before the end of this week).
He's very highly regarded within his profession.
The target was now within range and so she took aim and fired.
He could sense that his goal was within reach (= it could be reached).
The cathedral spire was now within sight (= it could be seen).
We came within five points of beating them (= we would have beaten them if we had had five more points).

meanings.definition: inside the limits of something, for example the law or a set of rules, and allowed by it:
examples: I was acting within the law (= legally).
She managed to complete her last film well within budget.
I am within my rights to refuse their request.

meanings.definition: inside or not beyond (a particular area, limit, or period of time):
examples: Most Californians live within 20 miles of the coast.
The tickets should reach you within a week.
The company has always acted within the law (= legally).

meanings.definition: very close to something:
examples: She came within an inch of losing her life.

meanings.definition: not spending more than the amount planned and agreed or available:
examples: Libraries are finding it increasingly difficult to remain within budget.
Keeping this project on time and within budget will be a challenge.

meanings.definition: to some extent, but not allowing everything:
examples: I'll pay for what you need - within limits.

meanings.definition: if you follow certain rules:
examples: We can wear what we like to work, within limits.

meanings.definition: If something has happened within living memory, it can be remembered by some people who are still alive:
examples: There is possibly less chance of another world war while the last one is within living memory.

meanings.definition: within the limits of what is acceptable and possible:
examples: We can wear anything we like to the office, within reason.
Spend whatever you need to spend, within reason.
We're willing to do anything within reason to ensure its success.
He'd do anything I asked - you know, anything within reason.
People should be allowed to do what they want, within reason.
You can have anything you like, within reason.

meanings.definition: very close:
examples: We live within shouting distance of the station.

meanings.definition: near: very near to getting or achieving something:
examples: We live within striking distance of both Baltimore and Washington.
His victory in the Brazilian Grand Prix puts him within striking distance of the world championship.

meanings.definition: not too difficult for someone or something to do:
examples: Running a two-minute film should be within the capacity of any home computer.
She has done everything within her capacity to help her son to learn to walk again.

meanings.definition: at a time that you are able to remember:
examples: Women gained the vote within my grandmother's memory.

meanings.definition: If you are within your rights to do something, you are legally allowed to do it:
examples: I think I'm quite within my rights to demand a full refund.
You're within your rights to request a particular teacher.
He's perfectly within his rights to refuse to pay for it.
The question is whether the newspaper was within its rights to publish the photographs.
The judge concluded that the defendant was well within their rights.
Surely you're within your rights to send the dish back if it's not what you ordered.

meanings.definition: not having or doing something, or lacking something:
examples: I left without my umbrella.
You look nice without make-up.
He went without my knowledge.
I couldn't have done it without you.
She's strong without being bossy.
Do start without me.
He's not without (= he does have some) good qualities.
This is without a doubt (= certainly) the best Chinese food I've ever had.
You shouldn't drive for more than three hours without taking a break.
Without wanting to be rude (= I don't want to be rude, but), don't you think you need a haircut?

meanings.definition: not having or doing (something), or not having the use or help of (someone or something):
examples: He came out without a coat.
He looks younger without the moustache.
Thanks for your help – I couldn’t have done it without you.
You shouldn’t drive for more than three hours without taking a break.
That was without (a) doubt/without question (= certainly) the best vacation I’ve ever had.
When you have no money, you just have to learn to do without.

meanings.definition: used to emphasize your opinion:
examples: She is without (a) doubt the best student I have ever taught.
It was, without doubt, the worst restaurant I'd ever eaten in.
Coming here has been, without a doubt, the most exciting and important experience of my life.
Without doubt, it is his best book.
It is, without a doubt, the culinary capital of Europe.
Without a doubt, the coastal tour was the highlight of our trip to Portland.

without-so-much-as-a-backward-glance.name: without (so much as) a backward glance

meanings.definition: If you leave without a backward glance, you are completely happy to leave and have no sad feelings about it:
examples: She left the city where she had lived all her life without a backward glance.

without-a-care-in-the-world.name: without a care in the world

meanings.definition: without worrying about anything:
examples: Look at her, not a care in the world!

meanings.definition: without even a small complaint:
examples: For once the children went to bed without a murmur.

meanings.definition: for no reason:
examples: He argues that his clients were dismissed without cause, in violation of their employment contracts.
He believes that the attack was launched without good cause.

meanings.definition: without stopping:
examples: The bells started ringing at midday and continued, without cease, till sunrise.
She talks without cease about her childhood.
The bombing continued without cease till the city lay in ruins.
He had fought without cease to clear his name.
Diana continued, without cease, to berate him till he could bear no more.

meanings.definition: without any particular care or formal, polite behaviour:
examples: The prisoner was escorted without ceremony to the cells.
I handed her my letter of resignation without ceremony.

meanings.definition: quickly or immediately:
examples: This situation needs to be tackled without delay.
The government must now act honourably and either charge or release all those people currently in custody without delay.

meanings.definition: without argument or complaint:
examples: She agreed to his request without demur.
He was used to being obeyed without demur.
Officials' decisions, right or wrong, were accepted without demur.

meanings.definition: used by a supplier in descriptions of goods or services to say that final prices, conditions, etc. in particular orders may not be the same as the ones mentioned:
examples: Prices are in Pounds Sterling net, without engagement, exclusive of VAT and sales taxes.

meanings.definition: If you do something without fail, you always do it:
examples: I go to the gym every Monday and Wednesday, without fail.
This film always makes me smile, without fail.
She attended church every Sunday without fail.
I read his newspaper column, without fail, every Saturday.
Every week, without fail, he brings her flowers.

meanings.definition: used to tell someone that they must do something:
examples: Be there at nine o'clock, without fail.
They need to feed the animals every day, without fail.
We must, without fail, turn our country into a flourishing and democratic state.
The money must be paid by Friday, without fail.
I want you to give Paul this message, without fail.

meanings.definition: in an equal and fair way:
examples: The appointments are made without fear or favour.

meanings.definition: with no more delay:
examples: And now, without further ado, here is our special guest speaker.

meanings.definition: without wasting more time:
examples: And so, without further ado, let me introduce tonight's speaker.
Without more ado, here's my recipe.

meanings.definition: with nothing unpleasant or unusual happening:
examples: Despite fears of violence, the demonstration passed off without incident.
She gave birth to three children without incident.
The journey to Penang proceeded without incident.
The visit happened as planned and without incident.
The convoy made it across the border without incident.

meanings.definition: If someone dies without issue, they have no children.
without being prevented from doing something:
examples: People will be able to travel from country to country without let or hindrance.
Anyone can explore the whole area without let or hindrance.
We need tighter regulations, or this pollution will continue without let or hindrance.
We don't want anyone to be able to set up a university without let or hindrance.
This document allows the bearer to pass through the checkpoint without let or hindrance.

meanings.definition: In Britain, a minister without portfolio is an important government official who is not in charge of a particular department, but who still takes part in the decisions of the government:
examples: He knows that life will not be simple when he takes up his post as minister without portfolio in the cabinet.
He received enough votes to gain a place in Cabinet as a minister without portfolio.
Several new members of the Cabinet were sworn in as ministers without portfolio.
The reshuffle included the appointment of a second Minister without Portfolio.
He was appointed without portfolio to represent the Serbian population.

meanings.definition:
→ 
        
         prejudice noun
If a decision or action is made without prejudice to a right or claim, it is made without having an effect on that right or claim:
examples: My client accepts the formal apology without prejudice to any further legal action she may decide to take.
We asked for the motion to be withdrawn without prejudice to it being renewed at a future date.
The judge will hear the petition without prejudice to any ruling of this court.
The flexibility of these course options enables students to optimize their opportunities without prejudice to their progression through the examination system.
The payments were made without prejudice to any right to recover the money as a result of future legal proceedings.

meanings.definition: used to describe an insurance agreement that only pays an agreed amount rather than one where some of the profits are also added:
examples: The company also issues endowment insurances, with and without profits.

meanings.definition: a phrase written on a bill of exchange (= signed document promising to pay someone money) in order to express that the buyer accepts the risk that the money might not be paid back

without-so-much-as-a-by-your-leave.name: without so much as a by-your-leave

meanings.definition: without asking for permission:
examples: That's twice now he's just walked in here without so much as a by-your-leave and picked a book off the shelf!

meanings.definition: to be strong enough, or not be changed by something, or to oppose a person or thing successfully:
examples: a bridge designed to withstand earthquakes
Our toys are designed to withstand the rough treatment of the average five-year-old.
The aircraft base is protected with specially designed shelters which are built to withstand ground and air attacks.
She is an artist whose work will undoubtedly withstand the test of time (= it will still be popular in the future).

meanings.definition: to receive without being changed or damaged by something powerful; bear:
examples: The building has to be strong enough to withstand severe winds and storms.
Coaches have to be tough to withstand the constant pressure to win.

meanings.definition:
past simple and past participle of 
        
         withstand
stupid or showing no intelligence:
examples: In the book, Anna is forced to take care of her witless cousin.

meanings.definition: in a way that is stupid, or that shows no intelligence:
examples: Her style has been both witlessly admired and widely copied.
The shop assistant was just staring witlessly into space and didn't even notice that customers had come in.

meanings.definition: a vegetable with white leaves that taste bitter and are eaten cooked, or uncooked in salads:
examples: Serve steaks on a bed of braised witlof with potatoes and parsnips on the side.
In a salad like this the witloof must be pale yellow, not green, as then it will be bitter and unpalatable.

meanings.definition: a person who sees an event happening, especially a crime or an accident:
examples: Police are appealing for witnesses to the accident to come forward.
According to (eye) witnesses, the robbery was carried out by two teenage boys.

meanings.definition: someone who is asked to be present at a particular event and sign their name in order to prove that things have been done correctly:
examples: He signed the treaty in the presence of two witnesses.
They were married a year after they first met, with two friends acting as witnesses.

meanings.definition: a person in a law court who says what they know about a legal case or a particular person:
examples: Ten witnesses are expected to testify at the trial today.
The key witness for the prosecution was offered police protection after she received death threats.

meanings.definition: to see something happen, especially an accident or crime:
examples: Did anyone witness the attack?
They were staying in the capital at the time of the riots and witnessed several street battles.
He arrived home just in time to witness his brother being taken away by the police.

meanings.definition: to be present at an event and to sign your name as proof that it happened or that it was done correctly:
examples: Her will was witnessed by two colleagues.

meanings.definition: When a place or period witnesses a particular event, the event happens in that place or during that period:
examples: This university has witnessed quite a few changes over the years.
Those years witnessed momentous changes throughout Europe.

meanings.definition: to show or give proof of something:
examples: This year's charity ball was the most successful one ever, as witnessed by the number of tickets sold.
The programme aroused strong feelings - witness the number of letters received.

meanings.definition: a person who sees an event happening, esp. a crime or an accident:
examples: According to witnesses, the car used in the robbery was a green van with Pennsylvania license plates.

meanings.definition: Someone who is witness to something sees it:
examples: She was witness to the tragic event.

meanings.definition: If you are a witness, you are asked to be present at a particular event and to sign (= write your name on) a document in order to prove that things have been done correctly:
examples: The will has to be signed by two witnesses.

meanings.definition: a person in a law court who promises to tell the truth and answers questions about something that was seen or is known:
examples: defense/prosecution witnesses
Five witnesses are expected to testify at the trial today.

meanings.definition: to see something happen:
examples: We were there at the time and witnessed the accident.
The university has witnessed (= experienced) quite a few changes over the years.

meanings.definition: Witness also means to show or give proof of something:
examples: The program aroused strong feelings, as witnessed by the number of letters the station received.
Rock music is becoming a health problem – witness the loss of hearing (= for proof, look at the loss of hearing) in some of our youth.

meanings.definition: If you are asked to witness an event, you are asked to be present at it and sign your name to prove that things have been done correctly.
someone who gives information in a court of law about a particular person or event, usually when there has been a crime or an accident:
examples: The key witness for the prosecution was given police protection.
Doctors confirmed that he was not fit to be called as a witness in the trial.
The police are appealing for witnesses.
a credible/material witness
a witness account/statement

meanings.definition: someone who signs an official document to prove that an event has happened or that someone is who they say they are:
examples: He signed the treaty in the presence of six witnesses.

meanings.definition: to see something happen, especially an accident or a crime:
examples: The police want to hear from anyone who witnessed the incident.
witness an attack/crime

meanings.definition: to sign your name on an official document to prove that an event has happened or that someone is who they say they are:
examples: She asked a colleague to witness the contract.

meanings.definition: to experience something happening:
examples: India witnessed significant jumps in its growth rates as it opened up its economy to international trade.

meanings.definition: the place in which a person stands in a law court when they are being asked questions:
examples: He showed no emotion as he walked into the witness box.
She was asked to take the witness box and was then cross-examined.

meanings.definition: the place in which a person stands in a court to answer questions:
examples: She spent over an hour in the witness box giving evidence.
enter/step down from the witness box
The judge asked him to take the witness stand.

meanings.definition: methods of protecting someone who may be in danger as a result of agreeing to tell the courts or police what they know about a crime:
examples: an expert in witness protection

meanings.definition: a system in which someone who has agreed to tell the courts or police what they know about a crime is protected, usually by preventing their address and identity from becoming known:
examples: The FBI told Cullotta that Spilotro had ordered a hit on him, and Cullotta entered witness protection.
Brennan and his family were put into a witness protection programme with new identities.

meanings.definition: the place in which a person sits in a law court when they are being asked questions:
examples: The defendant's lawyers don't want him on the witness stand answering questions.
She was asked to take the witness stand and was then cross-examined.

meanings.definition: a raised place, usually near the judge, where someone who is giving information about a case sits

→ 
        
         witness box
a legal document ordering someone to appear in a court of law to give information about a particular person or event:
examples: Witness summonses can be served by post.

meanings.definition: to say publicly, especially in a law court, that something is true or that it happened:
examples: A handwriting expert witnessed to the authenticity of the letter.
She witnessed to having seen the robbery take place.

meanings.definition:
past simple and past participle of 
        
         witness
to see something happen, especially an accident or crime:
examples: Did anyone witness the attack?
They were staying in the capital at the time of the riots and witnessed several street battles.
He arrived home just in time to witness his brother being taken away by the police.

meanings.definition: to be present at an event and to sign your name as proof that it happened or that it was done correctly:
examples: Her will was witnessed by two colleagues.

meanings.definition: When a place or period witnesses a particular event, the event happens in that place or during that period:
examples: This university has witnessed quite a few changes over the years.
Those years witnessed momentous changes throughout Europe.

meanings.definition: to show or give proof of something:
examples: This year's charity ball was the most successful one ever, as witnessed by the number of tickets sold.
The programme aroused strong feelings - witness the number of letters received.

meanings.definition:

meanings.definition: to succeed in moving along in a difficult or crowded situation, by moving your body slowly and carefully:
examples: Because he was so small, he could worm (his way) through the crowd.
She wormed herself under the fence.

meanings.definition: to give an animal, especially a pet dog or cat, medicine to kill any worms that might be living inside it:
examples: Has your dog been wormed?

meanings.definition: a small animal with a long, narrow, soft body without legs or bones
to move slowly or carefully through a crowd or tight space:
examples: He wormed his way through the crowd as quickly as he could.
fig. He was a distant relation who wormed his way into the confidence of the family.

meanings.definition: a computer program that can send copies of itself to other computers and is designed to prevent the computers from working normally:
examples: When users click an infected attachment, the worm opens a "back door" that hackers can use.

meanings.definition: a small pile of earth or sand pushed up to the surface of the ground by a worm
to try and get information from someone that they are trying to keep secret:
examples: He wasn't going to tell me, but I managed to worm it out of him.

meanings.definition: to gradually achieve a position of trust, possibly by being dishonest:
examples: He wormed himself into her affections without her ever suspecting he only did it for her money.

meanings.definition: containing small holes that were made by the young of particular types of insect, especially woodworm:
examples: a worm-eaten table/beam

meanings.definition: containing worms, or infected or damaged by worms:

         wear
damaged because of continuous use:
examples: His clothes were dirty and worn.

meanings.definition: very tired, and seeming old :
examples: The period of bad health had left her looking tired and worn.

meanings.definition: past participle of wear
Something that is worn out can no longer be used because it is so old or because it has been damaged by continued use:
examples: My jeans are almost worn out because I've worn them so much.
worn-out clothes/carpet/equipment

meanings.definition: extremely tired:
examples: I've been working all night and I'm worn out.

meanings.definition: no longer usable because of too much use:
examples: The city is looking for a place to dump its worn-out equipment.

meanings.definition: extremely tired:
examples: They were worn out after their long walk.

meanings.definition: unhappy because you are thinking about problems or unpleasant things that might happen:
examples: She was sitting behind her desk with a worried expression/look on her face.
They don't seem particularly worried about the situation.
You had me worried (= you made me feel anxious) back there - I thought for a second that you wouldn't be able to stop in time.
He was worried sick (= extremely worried) when he heard that there had been an accident.

meanings.definition: anxious because you're thinking about problems or other unpleasant things that are happening or may happen:
examples: We were very worried when he did not answer his phone.
She had a worried look on her face.

meanings.definition: people who are healthy but see a doctor because they think that they may have a disease or medical problem:
examples: Too much money is spent treating the worried well rather than people who are actually sick.
Nearly 500 people died of the disease and more than 6,600 were "worried well", concerned that they, too, were infected.

meanings.definition: in an unhappy way because you are thinking about problems or unpleasant things that might happen:
examples: "I can't find my passport," she said worriedly.
He looked back worriedly over his shoulder.

meanings.definition: someone who worries a lot:
examples: I can't help being a worrier - some people are just born that way.

meanings.definition: worrying:
examples: Alcohol and tobacco consumption by young people is especially worrisome because habits formed early are likely to persist.

meanings.definition: causing worry:
examples: The possibility of fire is especially worrisome for people who live on the edge of the forest.

meanings.definition: in a way that is worrying:
examples: Unemployment claims have been trending worrisomely upward across the country for the last several months.
Most worrisomely, the country's army is equipped with state-of-the-art artillery.

meanings.definition: to think about problems or unpleasant things that might happen in a way that makes you feel unhappy and frightened:
examples: Try not to worry - there's nothing you can do to change the situation.
Don't worry, she'll be all right.
It's silly worrying about things which are outside your control.
She's worried (that) she might not be able to find another job.

meanings.definition: to make someone feel unhappy and frightened because of problems or unpleasant things that might happen:
examples: You worried your mother by not writing.
It worries me that he hasn't phoned yet.
The continued lack of rain is starting to worry people.

meanings.definition: If a dog worries another animal, it chases and frightens it and might also bite it:
examples: Any dog caught worrying sheep in these fields will be shot.

meanings.definition: a problem that makes you feel unhappy and frightened:
examples: health/financial worries
Keeping warm in the winter is a major worry for many old people.

meanings.definition: a feeling of being unhappy and frightened about something:
examples: Unemployment, bad health - all sorts of things can be a cause of worry.
It was clear that Anna had no worries about her husband's attempts to flirt.

meanings.definition: to think about problems or unpleasant things that make you anxious, or to make someone feel anxious:
examples: If you get a monthly train ticket, you won’t have to worry about buying a ticket every day.
My mother always worries about me when I don’t come home by midnight.
"Will you be all right walking home?" "Don’t worry – I’ll be fine."
She worried that she might not be able to find another job.
A lot of things worried him about his roommate.

meanings.definition: to shake, pull at, or touch something repeatedly:
examples: The dog was worrying at its bone.

meanings.definition: to keep trying to find a way of solving a problem:
examples: She'll worry at those figures until she's sure they've been done correctly.

meanings.definition: a string of beads (= little decorative balls) that someone can play with in their hands when they are bored or worried:
examples: Worry beads, carried by many Greek men to calm the nerves, are not strictly jewellery but they are very decorative.

meanings.definition: making you feel unhappy and frightened:
examples: It's a very worrying situation.

meanings.definition: in a way that makes you feel worried:
examples: Worryingly, the gun was never found.
The exam has a worryingly high failure rate.

meanings.definition: a person who often worries, especially about things that are not important:
examples: Don't listen to him - he's just an old worrywart.

meanings.definition:
comparative of 
        
         bad  : more unpleasant, difficult, or severe than before or than something else that is also bad:
examples: The conditions they're living in are worse than we thought.
If the rain gets any worse we'll have to go back.
His manners are even worse than his sister's.
The heat is much worse in the daytime.

meanings.definition: something that is more unpleasant or difficult:
examples: By the third month of the expedition they had endured many hardships, but worse was to follow.
"What about the bride's dress - wasn't it terrible?" "I don't know, I've seen worse."

meanings.definition:
comparative of 
        
         badly  :
examples: He did worse than he was expecting in the exams.
He was treated much worse than I was.

meanings.definition: more unpleasant, difficult, or severe than before or than something else; comparative ofbad:
examples: Annette may be bad at math, but Bill is even worse.
If this sore throat gets any worse, I’ll have to see a doctor.

meanings.definition: comparative ofbadly:
examples: The storm grew worse.
Walking only made the cough worse.

meanings.definition: said at the end of a statement to show unhappiness or anger about what has been stated:
examples: I have to work on Saturday, worse luck.

meanings.definition: poorer or in a more difficult situation:
examples: If Rick loses his job we'll be even worse off.

meanings.definition: to become worse or to make something become worse:
examples: As the company's financial problems worsened, several directors resigned.
The continued supply of arms to the region will only worsen the situation.

meanings.definition:
past simple and past participle of 
        
         worsen
to become worse or to make something become worse:
examples: As the company's financial problems worsened, several directors resigned.
The continued supply of arms to the region will only worsen the situation.

meanings.definition: becoming worse:
examples: He had to give up all sport because of worsening back problems.
the country's worsening political situation

meanings.definition: the process of becoming worse:
examples: Any worsening of air quality is likely to harm public health.
No one could have predicted such a dramatic worsening of the economy.

meanings.definition: to have or show a strong feeling of respect and admiration for God or a god:
examples: On the island the people worshipped different gods.

meanings.definition: to go to a religious ceremony:
examples: They socialize together and worship in the same mosque.
The poll showed that over 40 percent of Americans worship on a weekly basis.

meanings.definition: to love, respect, and admire someone or something very much, often without noticing the bad qualities of that person or thing:
examples: Her parents worship her.
As a child, I worshipped my older brother.

meanings.definition: the act of worshipping God or a god, often through praying or singing:
examples: Daily acts of worship do not occur in very many schools.
Christian/Sikh/Muslim worship
For Jews, the synagogue is the centre for community worship and study.
Local people have complained about improperly dressed tourists entering places of worship (= buildings for religious ceremonies or private prayer).

meanings.definition: a lot of love or admiration for a particular thing or person, often when this is considered too much:
examples: We're in an era of fitness and health worship.

meanings.definition: to pray to God or a god:
examples: They went on a pilgrimage to India to worship at the holy Buddhist shrines there.

meanings.definition: To worship is also to go regularly to a place for religious ceremonies:
examples: They work for the same company, socialize together, and worship at the same church.

meanings.definition: to feel a lot of love and admiration for someone or something:
examples: As kids, we worshiped our Aunt Martha, who let us sleep late and took us to great places.

meanings.definition: A house/place of worship is a building for religious ceremonies and prayer.

worship-at-the-shrine-altar-of.name: worship at the shrine/altar of something

meanings.definition: to completely support or follow a particular idea, principle, etc.:
examples: She thinks that young people today are becoming increasingly selfish, and worship at the shrine of individual happiness and gratification.
He may not worship at the altar of government intervention in business, but he is in favour of limited support for industry.

worship-the-ground-walks-on.name: worship the ground someone walks on

meanings.definition: to love and admire someone very much:
examples: I worship the ground you walk on - you must know that by now.

meanings.definition: someone who goes to a religious ceremony to worship God:
examples: At 11 a.m. on Sunday morning, worshipers began to stream out of the cathedral.

meanings.definition: someone who worships and performs religious ceremonies to a particular god or object:
examples: devil/idol worshipers

meanings.definition: someone who enjoys or values a particular thing very much or too much:
examples: sun worshipers

meanings.definition: someone who goes regularly to a place for religious ceremonies:
examples: By noon, worshipers had begun streaming out of the cathedral.

meanings.definition: someone who loves and admires someone or something or enjoys something very much:
examples: fig. Sun worshipers were at the beach all day long.

meanings.definition: giving someone or something great respect or admiration
in a way that shows great respect or admiration for someone or something :
examples: Tech entrepreneurs are often worshipfully described as visionaries.
Now a best-selling author, Julie speaks worshipfully of her former teacher, who instilled in her a love for writing.

superlative of 
        
         bad  : of the lowest quality, or the most unpleasant, difficult, or severe:
examples: That was the worst meal I've ever eaten.
"It was the worst moment of my life," she admitted.
He is my worst enemy.

meanings.definition: the most unpleasant or difficult thing, person, or situation:
examples: That was the worst I've seen him play in several years.

meanings.definition: the most badly:
examples: Small businesses have been worst hit by the recession.
Roads in rural areas were worst affected by the snow.
The students voted him the school's worst-dressed teacher.

meanings.definition: to defeat someone in a fight or argument:
examples: He was worsted in a fight with a bigger boy.

meanings.definition: of the lowest quality, or the most unpleasant, difficult, or severe; superlative ofbad and badly:
examples: That was the worst meal I’ve ever eaten.

meanings.definition: used to emphasize what is worst about a situation:
examples: We had no food or light, but worst of all, we had no water.
Worst of all was being separated from our families.
Worst of all, I had to pay £50 for the experience.
I found him arrogant, rude and - worst of all - deeply boring.
The beds were uncomfortable and the rooms cold but worst of all was the food, which was almost inedible.

meanings.definition:
superlative of 
        
         badly off
involving the worst situation that is possible:
examples: a worst-case analysis of the possible outcomes

meanings.definition: (of situations) as bad as possible:
examples: Emergency services need to be prepared for a worst-case scenario.

meanings.definition: the most unpleasant or serious thing that could happen in a situation:
examples: The study concludes that in a worst-case scenario there might be 80,000 cases of the disease.

meanings.definition: used to describe a company, product, etc. that is the least successful of its type:
examples: Shipping was one of the worst-performing industries last year.

meanings.definition: a type of cloth made from wool and used to make jackets, trousers, and skirts:
examples: a pale grey worsted suit

meanings.definition: a type of woolen cloth used to make clothes
