meanings.definition: a liquid produced from the grain when making beer or whiskey
having a particular value, especially in money:
examples: Our house is worth £200,000.
Heroin worth about $5 million was seized.

meanings.definition: having a particular amount of money:
examples: She must be worth at least half a million.

meanings.definition: the amount of money that something can be sold for; value:
examples: The estimated worth of the plastics and petrochemical industry is about $640 billion.

meanings.definition: the importance or usefulness of something or someone:
examples: He felt as though he had no worth.
She has proved her worth on numerous occasions.
The study proved that women were paid less than men holding jobs of comparable worth.

meanings.definition: the amount of money that something can be sold for:
examples: The estimated worth of her jewels alone is about $30 million.

meanings.definition: A particular amount of money’s worth of something is the amount of money that it costs:
examples: $20 worth of gasoline

meanings.definition: the importance or usefulness of something or someone:
examples: a sense of personal worth
Some people are modest to the point of not realizing their true worth.

meanings.definition: an amount of something that will last a stated period of time or that takes a stated amount of time to do:
examples: We got a week’s worth of diapers at the supermarket.
When the computer crashed, we lost six month’s worth of work.

meanings.definition: important or useful enough to have or do:
examples: There are only two things worth reading in this newspaper – the TV listings and the sports page.
I don’t think it’s worth talking about any more.

meanings.definition: having a value in money of:
examples: They’re asking $10,000 for the car, but I don’t think it’s worth that much.
It is an expensive restaurant, but for special occasions it’s worth it (= the value of what you get is equal to the money spent).

meanings.definition: If a person is worth a particular amount of money, the person has that amount or owns things that would cost that amount:
examples: She must be worth at least half a million.

meanings.definition: having a particular value:
examples: The shares are worth 262p.
Tax cuts worth $10 billion should give businesses a boost.

meanings.definition: owning a particular amount of money:
examples: As owner of almost 25% of the company, she's worth an estimated $10 billion.

meanings.definition: the value of something:
examples: They were forced to sell their shares for one-tenth of their worth.

meanings.definition: the amount of something that you can buy with a particular amount of money:
examples: She bought $200 worth of clothes.

meanings.definition: enjoyable or useful despite the fact that you have to make an effort:
examples: It was a long climb to the top of the hill, but the view from the top was worth it.

meanings.definition: good at your job:
examples: Any accountant worth their salt should be aware of the latest changes in taxation.

meanings.definition: important, useful, or satisfying enough to be worth the effort you make:
examples: It would be worth your while to see if you can still get tickets to the show.

meanings.definition: in a way that deserves respect, admiration, or support:
examples: For the past four years, he worthily and bravely carried out his duty before his own people.
It was a very bad move, however worthily made.

meanings.definition: in a way that is not very interesting but should be admired for its good and useful qualities:
examples: He speaks worthily of his commitment to development.
"Conscious rappers" are the ones who rap worthily about politics and black awareness.

meanings.definition: how suitable someone or something is:
examples: She persuaded the board of her worthiness to run the company.

meanings.definition: the quality of deserving respect or attention:
examples: the worthiness of a project/cause/aim

meanings.definition: having no value in money:
examples: The company's shares are now virtually worthless.
He said the jewels were worthless fakes.

meanings.definition: not important or not useful:
examples: She was criticized so much by her employers that she began to feel worthless.

meanings.definition: having no value in money:
examples: Now that the company has gone bankrupt, your contract is worthless.

meanings.definition: unimportant or useless:
examples: Examples of this artist’s early works remind me that he was not worthless, as some reviewers seemed to feel.

meanings.definition: having no value:
examples: The stock is virtually worthless, trading at less than 6 cents a share.

meanings.definition: not important or useful:
examples: The security system he bought turned out to be worthless.

meanings.definition: in a way that has no worth or value in money:
examples: If you don't exercise the stock option by midnight tonight, it will expire worthlessly.
They objected to the idea of spending billions of dollars on worthlessly ineffective missile defence systems.

meanings.definition: in a way that is not important or useful:
examples: His lazy son spent his whole afternoon worthlessly scrolling around on the internet.
I have never felt treated so worthlessly before!

meanings.definition: the feeling or fact of not being important or useful:
examples: People who have been abused as children often experience feelings/a sense of worthlessness.
She started to sound off about the worthlessness of most television.

meanings.definition: the fact of having no financial value:
examples: Shares in the company collapsed to worthlessness.
The insurance company has acknowledged the worthlessness of critical illness cover.

meanings.definition: the state or quality of having no value in money:
examples: He held on to his investments in spite of their worthlessness.

meanings.definition: the state or quality of being unimportant or useless:
examples: Feelings of worthlessness overwhelmed him.

meanings.definition: useful, important, or good enough to be a suitable reward for the money or time spent or the effort made:
examples: She considers teaching a worthwhile career.
The time and expense involved in keeping up to date with all the changes has been worthwhile.
If you need him on this project, you've got to make it financially worthwhile for him (= you will have to pay him a suitable amount of money for the amount of work involved).

meanings.definition: useful, important, or helpful enough to be a suitable reward for the money or time spent or the effort made:
examples: She considers teaching a worthwhile career.

meanings.definition: deserving respect, admiration, or support:
examples: He is unlikely to succeed in getting his bill through Congress, however worthy it is.
Every year she makes a large donation to a worthy cause.

meanings.definition: Something that is worthy is not very interesting but should be admired for its good and useful qualities:
examples: a worthy book

meanings.definition: a person who is important, especially in a small town:
examples: The front row of chairs was reserved for local worthies.

meanings.definition: suitable or deserving to receive a particular thing:
examples: trustworthy
creditworthy
newsworthy

meanings.definition: used to describe a boat, aircraft, or vehicle that is suitable to be used safely in a particular substance or environment:
examples: seaworthy
roadworthy

meanings.definition: deserving respect, admiration, or support:
examples: a worthy goal/project
It was a worthy cause, and we were glad to make a contribution.
She soon proved herself worthy of the trust we placed in her.

meanings.definition: deserving or suitable for:
examples: Each of the ten chapters is worthy of a separate book.
After viewing the damage, the president decided that the area was worthy of federal disaster relief.

meanings.definition: deserving to be given attention, noticed, etc.:
examples: Two points in this report are especially worthy of notice.
Three or four tracks on the album are worthy of attention.
Two performances especially were worthy of note.
The following points are worthy of note.
The third chapter is especially worthy of attention.
One or two comments were worthy of notice.

meanings.definition: suitable for or characteristic of something:
examples: He threw a party worthy of a millionaire.
Truly, it was a feat worthy of a superhero.
The action is worthy of a Bond movie.
I thought she showed patience worthy of a saint.
He showed us around a villa that was worthy of a prince.
This, it was generally agreed, was a performance worthy of an Oscar nomination.

meanings.definition: used in writing for what or that:
examples: Wot? No food?
It's him wot won it.

meanings.definition: used as an informal greeting, especially between friends:
examples: Wotcha, mate!

meanings.definition: used to refer to future time from the point of view of the past:
examples: He said he would see his brother tomorrow.
They knew there would be trouble unless the report was finished by the next day.
We realized it wouldn't be easy to find another secretary.

meanings.definition: used to refer to an intention from the point of view of the past:
examples: He said he would always love her .
They promised that they would help.
There was nobody left who would (= was willing to) do it.
I asked him to move his car but he said he wouldn't (= he refused).

meanings.definition: used to refer to a situation that you can imagine happening:
examples: I would hate to miss the show.
I'd go myself but I'm too busy.
It would have been very boring to sit through the whole speech.

meanings.definition: used with if in conditional sentences (= sentences that refer to what happens if something else happens):
examples: What would you do if you lost your job?
If I'd had time, I would have gone to see Graham.

meanings.definition: used in polite requests and offers:
examples: Would you mind sharing a room?
Would you like me to come with you?
Would you like some cake?

meanings.definition:
past simple of
        
         will  : used to talk about what someone was willing to do or what something was able to do:
examples: The car wouldn't start this morning.

meanings.definition: used to talk about things in the past that happened often or always:
examples: He would always turn and wave at the end of the street.

meanings.definition: used to suggest that what happens is expected because it is typical, especially of a person's behaviour:
examples: "Madeleine called to say she's too busy to come." "She would - she always has an excuse."

meanings.definition: used to express an opinion in a polite way without being forceful:
examples: I would think we need to speak to the headteacher about this first.
It's not what we would have expected from a professional service.

meanings.definition: used after "I" when giving advice:
examples: I wouldn't (= I advise you not to) worry about it, if I were you.

meanings.definition: used after "why" when giving or asking the reason for something:
examples: Why would anyone want to eat something so horrible?

meanings.definition: used to refer to what is very likely:
examples: "The guy on the phone had a Southern accent." "That would be Tom."

meanings.definition: used to refer to future time after a verb in the past tense:
examples: He said he would see his brother tomorrow.
They hoped they would go to France for their next vacation.

meanings.definition: used to express an intention or plan after a verb in a past tense:
examples: He said he would love her forever.
They promised that tomorrow they would help.

meanings.definition: used as a form of will in requests and offers:
examples: "Would you like some cake?" "Yes, I would."
Would you pick up a newspaper on your way home?

meanings.definition: used to refer to a possibility or likelihood:
examples: I would hate to miss the show.

meanings.definition: Would is used with if in sentences that show what will happen if something else happens:
examples: What would you do if you lost your job?

meanings.definition: used to suggest that in the past something happened often or always:
examples: In summer my dad would sit on the back porch after supper and read the newspaper.

meanings.definition: past simple of will :
examples: The car wouldn’t start this morning.

meanings.definition: If you would (just) as soon do something or would sooner do something, you would prefer to do it rather than something else that is possible:
examples: "Would you like to go out for dinner?" "I'd just as soon stay in - I'm not feeling very well."
I would sooner have you hate me for telling you the truth than adore me for telling you lies.

meanings.definition: someone would rather do something:
examples: He'd just as soon use the computer to play video games as go outside with his friends.
That was a journey I would just as soon forget.

meanings.definition: used when you are politely asking for something:
examples: I would appreciate it if you could let me know (= please let me know) in advance whether or not you will be coming.
I would appreciate hearing from you now and then.
They said they would appreciate if the minister withdrew his statement immediately.
If you could send some food up to our room, we would really appreciate it.
I'd appreciate any help you can offer.

would-be-well-advised-to-do.name: would be (well) advised to do something

meanings.definition: If you tell someone that they would be advised or well advised to do something, you warn them that they should do it:
examples: You would be well advised to have the appropriate vaccinations before you go abroad.
You would be advised to board up your windows before the storm hits.
Fans would be well advised to stay until the end of the show.
Anyone who publicly disagrees with her would be advised to get a good lawyer.
Cautious people would be well advised to avoid this sort of investment.

would-do-well-to.name: would do well to do something

meanings.definition: used to say that something is the right or wisest thing to do:
examples: You would do well to take some professional advice on this matter.
They would do well to save their energy for the really important work.

would-give-eyeteeth-for.name: would give your eyeteeth for something

meanings.definition: If you would give your eyeteeth for something, you would like it very much:
examples: Most people would give their eyeteeth for hair like yours.
I'd give my eye teeth to see that.
A 44% approval rating is something any political party would give its eye teeth for.

meanings.definition: used, often in requests, to say that you would very much like something:
examples: I'd love a cup of coffee if you're making one.
She would dearly love to start her own business.
I'd love you to come to dinner next week.
I'd love for you to come to dinner next week.
I'd love to come with you, if you don't mind.

would-not-do-for-all-the-tea-in-china.name: would not do something for all the tea in China

meanings.definition: used to say that nothing could persuade you to do something:
examples: I wouldn't take that job for all the tea in China.

meanings.definition: used to show that you prefer to have or do one thing more than another:
examples: I'd rather have a beer.
Which would you rather do - go swimming or play tennis?
Wouldn't you rather finish it tomorrow?
He'd rather die than (= he certainly does not want to) let me think he needed help.
I'd rather have rice than potatoes.
I know we discussed going next week but, to be honest, I'd rather go this weekend.

meanings.definition: used when offering something or inviting someone:

meanings.definition: an argument, especially one that continues for a long time:

meanings.definition: to argue with someone about something, especially for a long time:
examples: They had been wrangling with the authorities about parking spaces.

meanings.definition: to take care of, control, or move animals, especially large animals such as cows or horses:
examples: The young rancher goes wrangling cattle to earn some money.

meanings.definition: to move a person or thing somewhere, usually with difficulty or using force:
examples: She wrangled the children into their seats in the back of the car.

meanings.definition: to take care of or deal with someone or something, usually when this is difficult:
examples: I was raised in a house where my father worked long hours, and my mother stayed home, wrangling kids, cooking, cleaning, washing clothes.

meanings.definition: to succeed in getting something by persuading someone or by being clever in some way:

examples: We have been wrangling with the management for weeks over parking spaces for employees.

meanings.definition: to twist your body, or move part of your body, with small, quick movements:
examples: A large worm wriggled in the freshly dug earth.
Baby Martha was wriggling her toes in the sand.

meanings.definition: to move somewhere using short, quick twisting movements:
examples: The tunnel was low and dark, but she managed to wriggle through to the other side.
After twisting and turning for a while, he managed to wriggle free.

meanings.definition: an act of wriggling:
examples: With a wriggle, she managed to crawl through the gap.

meanings.definition: to make small quick movements with the body, turning from side to side:
examples: Somehow he twisted himself about and wriggled free of Farkas’s grip and danced away.

meanings.definition: If someone wriggles off the hook, they avoid a responsibility.
to avoid doing something that you do not want to do:
examples: He promised he'd help me paint the living room, but now he's trying to wriggle out of it.

meanings.definition: to twist something by holding it tightly and turning your hands in opposite directions:

meanings.definition: to force or persuade someone to give or tell you something:
examples: Congress is seeking to wring concessions from a weakened President.

meanings.definition: to force or persuade someone to give you something:
examples: They managed to wring a few concessions from the bosses.

meanings.definition: to kill a bird or other animal by twisting and breaking its neck:
examples: I hated doing it but I had to wring their necks or they'd have suffered long, agonising deaths.
My grandma used to wring the birds' necks with her bare hands.
If she found an injured bird, she would finish it off by wringing its neck.
The trappers wring their necks when they find them.
I've no idea how anyone can wring an animal's neck.

meanings.definition: If you wring your hands, you show that you are worried or unhappy:
examples: Car dealers are wringing their hands over low sales this summer.

meanings.definition: to be anxious or worried about something but not do anything about it:
examples: We should do something to help rather than just wringing our hands about it.

meanings.definition: a machine used for pressing water out of clothes by putting the clothes between two heavy, smooth, round bars
a small line in the skin caused by old age:
examples: fine wrinkles around the eyes
anti-wrinkle creams

meanings.definition: a small line or fold in cloth
a problem, usually a small one:
examples: There are still a few wrinkles to iron out (= solve) before the agreement can be signed.

meanings.definition: If skin or material wrinkles, or if something wrinkles it, it gets small lines or folds in it:
examples: Sunbathing can prematurely age and wrinkle the skin.

meanings.definition: a small line in the skin, or a small fold in cloth:
examples: You need to iron out the wrinkles in your skirt.
fig. We still need to iron out a few wrinkles (= slight problems) in our agreement.

meanings.definition: to show that you dislike something or that you disapprove of something by tightening the muscles in your nose so that small lines appear in the skin:
examples: She wrinkled up her nose at the strange smell coming from the kitchen.
Amy wrinkled her nose in disapproval.
"I don't fancy it," she said, wrinkling up her nose.
"No, thanks," he replied, wrinkling his nose.
Holly wrinkled up her nose at the plate of food put in front of her.
"The food was inedible," she said, wrinkling her nose in disgust at the memory.

meanings.definition: to make folds appear on your face above your eyes to show that you are surprised or confused:
examples: She wrinkled her brow and laughed.
Imogen wrinkled her brow thoughtfully.
He wrinkled his brow in concentration and started to write.
She shook her head in disbelief and wrinkled her brow.
"I have absolutely no idea what she means," said James, wrinkling his brow.
He wrinkled his brow inquisitively.

meanings.definition: to show surprise, uncertainty, or disgust at something:
examples: "Oooh, yuck!" 7-year-old Pamela says, wrinkling her nose as she wipes gooey paste from her fingers onto her sweat pants.

the part of the body between the hand and the arm:

meanings.definition: the narrow part of the arm above the hand that can bend to move the hand in different directions:

meanings.definition: in ice hockey, a way of hitting the puck in which the puck is touching the front of the stick and the player moves the stick forward quickly and sharply:

meanings.definition: a style of arm-wrestling (= a competition between two people who place the elbow of one of their arms on a table, hold hands, and try to push the other person's hand down onto the table) in which competitors link their thumbs:

meanings.definition: a watch that is worn on the wrist

meanings.definition: If one thing is another thing writ large, it is similar to it but larger or more obvious:

meanings.definition: a court order that gives an official the right to do something such as take a person's property in order to pay someone the money that person owes them:

meanings.definition: (of a computer disk) able to have new information written and stored on it by a user:

Since the advent of cloud computing, we have less need to use writable disks to store our data.
You can back up your videos with an external hard drive or on a writeable CD .

meanings.definition: able to be written, or written on:
examples: There are so many hours in a day, and I can only find about a page of writable stuff.

meanings.definition: to make marks that represent letters, words, or numbers on a surface, such as paper or a computer screen, using a pen, pencil, or keyboard, or to use this method to record thoughts, facts, or messages:

Why not write (down) your ideas on a piece of paper before you start?

meanings.definition: to send a letter or message to someone, giving them information or expressing your thoughts or feelings:

meanings.definition: to create and record something, such as a book, poem, song, or computer program, on paper or on a computer:

meanings.definition: to say something in a book, newspaper, magazine, or document:

meanings.definition: to record information in the memory of a computer:

meanings.definition: to create something for other people to read or use, such as a book, poem, letter, or piece of music:

examples: Please write your name on the dotted line.

meanings.definition: to add an amount to a company's profit for a particular period relating to a possible future cost that will not now have to be paid:

meanings.definition: an amount added to a company's profit for a particular period relating to a possible future cost that will not now have to be paid:

meanings.definition: to write a letter to a newspaper, television company, or other organization, to express an opinion or ask something:
examples: People have written in to complain about the show.

to write something on a piece of paper so that you do not forget it:

meanings.definition: to show in a company's accounts (= financial records) that something is worth less than it was before:
examples: The building cost £700,000 to build, but it was written down to £300,000.

meanings.definition: to record information on paper:
examples: If I don’t write it down, I’ll forget it.

meanings.definition: to show a reduction in the value of an asset in a company's accounts, usually because it is no longer worth as much as it was before:
examples: The company was forced to write down $450m after a revaluation of its assets.

meanings.definition: to record something on a piece of paper:

meanings.definition: to add a particular detail or rule to a document:

meanings.definition: to include a particular instruction, rule, etc. in an agreement:

meanings.definition: to accept that an amount of money has been lost or that a debt will not be paid:

meanings.definition: to be able to use the cost of something you have bought to reduce the amount of tax you owe:

meanings.definition: to damage a vehicle so badly that it cannot be repaired:
